revision.text:
'''Bacterial phylodynamics''' is the study of [[immunology]], [[epidemiology]], and [[phylogenetics]] of [[bacteria]]l [[pathogen]]s to better understand the [[evolutionary]] role of these pathogens.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Volz|first=Erik M.|last2=Koelle|first2=Katia|last3=Bedford|first3=Trevor|date=2013-03-21|title=Viral Phylodynamics|url=http://journals.plos.org/ploscompbiol/article?id=10.1371/journal.pcbi.1002947|journal=PLOS Computational Biology|volume=9|issue=3|pages=e1002947|doi=10.1371/journal.pcbi.1002947|issn=1553-7358|pmc=3605911|pmid=23555203}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Grenfell|first=Bryan T.|last2=Pybus|first2=Oliver G.|last3=Gog|first3=Julia R.|last4=Wood|first4=James L. N.|last5=Daly|first5=Janet M.|last6=Mumford|first6=Jenny A.|last7=Holmes|first7=Edward C.|date=2004-01-16|title=Unifying the epidemiological and evolutionary dynamics of pathogens|journal=Science |volume=303|issue=5656|pages=327–332|doi=10.1126/science.1090727|issn=1095-9203|pmid=14726583}}</ref><ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Frost|first=Simon D.W.|last2=Pybus|first2=Oliver G.|last3=Gog|first3=Julia R.|last4=Viboud|first4=Cecile|last5=Bonhoeffer|first5=Sebastian|last6=Bedford|first6=Trevor|title=Eight challenges in phylodynamic inference|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.epidem.2014.09.001|journal=Epidemics|volume=10|pages=88–92|doi=10.1016/j.epidem.2014.09.001| pmc=4383806 |pmid=25843391}}</ref> Phylodynamic analysis includes analyzing [[genetic diversity]], [[natural selection]], and population dynamics of infectious disease pathogen phylogenies during pandemics and studying intra-host evolution of viruses.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Norström|first=Melissa M.|last2=Karlsson|first2=Annika C.|last3=Salemi|first3=Marco|date=2012-04-01|title=Towards a new paradigm linking virus molecular evolution and pathogenesis: experimental design and phylodynamic inference|journal=The New Microbiologica|volume=35|issue=2|pages=101–111|issn=1121-7138|pmid=22707126}}</ref> Phylodynamics combines the study of [[phylogenetic analysis]], ecological, and evolutionary processes to better understand of the mechanisms that drive spatiotemportal incidence and phylogenetic patterns of bacterial pathogens.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> Bacterial phylodynamics uses [[genome]]-wide [[single-nucleotide polymorphism]]s (SNP) in order to better understand the evolutionary mechanism of bacterial pathogens.<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Azarian|first=Taj|last2=Ali|first2=Afsar|last3=Johnson|first3=Judith A.|last4=Mohr|first4=David|last5=Prosperi|first5=Mattia|last6=Veras|first6=Nazle M.|last7=Jubair|first7=Mohammed|last8=Strickland|first8=Samantha L.|last9=Rashid|first9=Mohammad H.|date=2014-12-31|title=Phylodynamic Analysis of Clinical and Environmental Vibrio cholerae Isolates from Haiti Reveals Diversification Driven by Positive Selection|url=http://mbio.asm.org/content/5/6/e01824-14|journal=mBio|language=en|volume=5|issue=6|pages=e01824–14|doi=10.1128/mBio.01824-14|issn=2150-7511|pmc=4278535|pmid=25538191}}</ref> Many phylodynamic studies have been performed on viruses, specifically [[RNA viruses]] (see [[Viral phylodynamics]]) which have high mutation rates. The field of bacterial phylodynamics has increased substantially due to the advancement of [[next-generation sequencing]] and the amount of data available.
== Methods ==
=== Novel hypothesis (study design) === Studies can be designed to observe intra-host or inter-host interactions. Bacterial phylodynamic studies usually focus on inter-host interactions with samples from many different hosts in a specific geographical location or several different geographical locations.<ref name=":1" /> The most important part of a study design is how to organize the sampling strategy.<ref name=":1" /> For example, the number of sampled time points, the sampling interval, and the number of sequences per time point are crucial to phylodynamic analysis.<ref name=":1" /> [[Sampling bias]] causes problems when looking at a diverse taxological samples.<ref name=":3" /> For example, sampling from a limited geographical location may impact effective population size.<ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|last=Biek|first=Roman|last2=Pybus|first2=Oliver G.|last3=Lloyd-Smith|first3=James O.|last4=Didelot|first4=Xavier|title=Measurably evolving pathogens in the genomic era|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0169534715000683|journal=Trends in Ecology & Evolution|volume=30|issue=6|pages=306–313|doi=10.1016/j.tree.2015.03.009|pmc=4457702|pmid=25887947}}</ref>
=== Generating data ===
==== Experimental settings ==== Sequencing of the genome or genomic regions and what sequencing technique to use is an important experimental setting to phylodynamic analysis. Whole genome sequencing is often performed on bacterial genomes, although depending on the design of the study, many different methods can be utilized for phylodynamic analysis. Bacterial genomes are much larger and have a slower evolutionary rate then RNA viruses, limiting studies on the bacterial phylodynamics. The advancement of sequencing technology has made bacterial phylodynamics possible but proper preparation of the whole bacterial genomes is mandatory.
===== Alignment ===== When a new dataset with samples for phylodynamic analysis are obtained, the sequences in the new data set are aligned.<ref name=":1" /> A [[BLAST|BLAST search]] is frequently executed to find similar strains of the pathogen of interest. Sequences collected from BLAST for an alignment will need the proper information to be added to a data set, such as sample collection date and geographical location of the sample. [[Multiple sequence alignment|Multiple sequence alignment algorithms]] (e.g., MUSCLE,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Edgar|first=Robert C.|date=2004-01-01|title=MUSCLE: multiple sequence alignment with high accuracy and high throughput|journal=Nucleic Acids Research|volume=32|issue=5|pages=1792–1797|doi=10.1093/nar/gkh340|issn=1362-4962|pmc=390337|pmid=15034147}}</ref> [[MAFFT]],<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Katoh|first=Kazutaka|last2=Misawa|first2=Kazuharu|last3=Kuma|first3=Kei-ichi|last4=Miyata|first4=Takashi|date=2002-07-15|title=MAFFT: a novel method for rapid multiple sequence alignment based on fast Fourier transform|journal=Nucleic Acids Research|volume=30|issue=14|pages=3059–3066|issn=0305-1048|pmc=135756|pmid=12136088}}</ref> and [[Clustal|CLUSAL W]]<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Larkin|first=M. A.|last2=Blackshields|first2=G.|last3=Brown|first3=N. P.|last4=Chenna|first4=R.|last5=McGettigan|first5=P. A.|last6=McWilliam|first6=H.|last7=Valentin|first7=F.|last8=Wallace|first8=I. M.|last9=Wilm|first9=A.|date=2007-11-01|title=Clustal W and Clustal X version 2.0|journal=Bioinformatics|volume=23|issue=21|pages=2947–2948|doi=10.1093/bioinformatics/btm404|issn=1367-4811|pmid=17846036}}</ref>) will align the data set with all selected sequences. After the running a multiple sequence alignment algorithm, manual editing the alignment is highly recommended.<ref name=":1" /> Multiple sequence alignment algorithms can leave a large amount of indels in the sequence alignment when the indels do not exist.<ref name=":1" /> Manually editing the indels in the data set will allow a more accurate phylogenetic tree.<ref name=":1" />
===== Quality control ===== In order to have an accurate phylodynamic analysis, quality control methods must be performed. This includes checking the samples in the data set for possible contamination, measuring phylogenetic signal of the sequences, and checking the sequences for possible signs of recombinant strains.<ref name=":1" /> Contamination of samples in the data set can be excluded with by various laboratory methods and by proper DNA/RNA extraction methods. There are several way to check for phylogenetic signal in an alignment, such as likelihood mapping, transition/transversions versus divergence plots, and the Xia test for saturation.<ref name=":1" /> If phylogenetic signal of an alignment is too low then a longer alignment or an alignment of another gene in the organism may be necessary to perform phylogenetic analysis.<ref name=":1" /> Typically substitution saturation is only in issue in data sets with viral sequences. Most algorithms used for phylogenetic analysis do not take into recombination into account, which can alter the molecular clock and coalescent estimates of a multiple sequence alignment.<ref name=":1" /> Strains that show signs of recombination should either be excluded from the data set or analyzed on their own.<ref name=":1" />
=== Data analysis ===
==== Evolutionary model ====
The best fitting [[Models of DNA evolution|nucleotide or amino acid substitution model]] for a [[multiple sequence alignment]] is the first step in phylodynamic analysis. This can be accomplished with several different algorithms (e.g., IQTREE,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Nguyen|first=Lam-Tung|last2=Schmidt|first2=Heiko A.|last3=von Haeseler|first3=Arndt|last4=Minh|first4=Bui Quang|date=2015-01-01|title=IQ-TREE: A Fast and Effective Stochastic Algorithm for Estimating Maximum-Likelihood Phylogenies|url=https://academic.oup.com/mbe/article/32/1/268/2925592/IQ-TREE-A-Fast-and-Effective-Stochastic-Algorithm|journal=Molecular Biology and Evolution|volume=32|issue=1|pages=268–274|doi=10.1093/molbev/msu300|issn=0737-4038|pmc=4271533|pmid=25371430}}</ref> MEGA<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Kumar|first=Sudhir|last2=Stecher|first2=Glen|last3=Tamura|first3=Koichiro|date=2016-07-01|title=MEGA7: Molecular Evolutionary Genetics Analysis Version 7.0 for Bigger Datasets|journal=Molecular Biology and Evolution|volume=33|issue=7|pages=1870–1874|doi=10.1093/molbev/msw054|issn=1537-1719|pmid=27004904}}</ref>).
==== Phylogeny inference ====
There are several different methods to infer phylogenies. These include methods include tree building algorithms such as [[UPGMA]], [[neighbor joining]], [[maximum parsimony]], [[maximum likelihood]], and [[Bayesian analysis]].<ref name=":1" />
=== Hypothesis testing ===
==== Assessing phylogenetic support ====
Testing the reliability of the tree after inferring its phylogeny, is a crucial step in the phylodynamic pipeline.<ref name=":1" /> Methods to test the reliability of a tree include [[Bootstrapping (statistics)|bootstrapping]], [[maximum likelihood estimation]], and [[Posterior probability|posterior probabilities]] in [[Bayesian inference|Bayesian analysis]].<ref name=":1" />
==== Phylodynamics inference ====
Several methods are used to assess phylodynamic reliability of a data set. These methods include estimating the data set's [[molecular clock]], demographic history, population structure, [[gene flow]], and selection analysis.<ref name=":1" /> Phylodynamic results of a data set can also influence better study designs in future experiments.
== Examples ==
=== Phylodynamics of cholera === [[Cholera]] is a diarrheal disease that is caused by the bacterium ''[[Vibrio cholerae]].'' ''[[Vibrio cholerae|V. cholerae]]'' has been a popular bacterium for phylodynamic analysis after the [[2010 Haiti cholera outbreak|2010 cholera outbreak in Haiti]]. The cholera outbreak happened right after the [[2010 Haiti earthquake|2010 earthquake in Haiti]], which caused critical infrastructure damage, leading to the conclusion that the outbreak was most likely due to the ''[[Vibrio cholerae|V. cholerae]]'' bacterium being introduced naturally to the waters in Haiti from the earthquake. Soon after the earthquake, the [[United Nations|UN]] sent [[United Nations Stabilisation Mission in Haiti|MINUSTAH]] troops from Nepal to Haiti. Rumors started circulating about terrible conditions of the [[United Nations Stabilisation Mission in Haiti|MINUSTAH]] camp, as well as people claiming that the [[United Nations Stabilisation Mission in Haiti|MINUSTAH]] troops were deposing of their waste in the [[Artibonite River]], which is the major water source in the surrounding area. Soon after the MINUSTAH troops arrival, the first cholera case was reported near the location of the [[United Nations Stabilisation Mission in Haiti|MINUSTAH]] camp.<ref name=":5">{{Cite journal|last=Piarroux|first=Renaud|title=Understanding the Cholera Epidemic, Haiti|url=https://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/17/7/11-0059_article|journal=Emerging Infectious Diseases|language=en-us|volume=17|issue=7|pages=1161–1168|doi=10.3201/eid1707.110059|pmc=3381400|pmid=21762567}}</ref> Phylodynamic analysis was used to look into the source of the Haiti cholera outbreak. Whole genome sequencing of ''[[Vibrio cholerae|V. cholerae]]'' revealed that there was one single point source of the cholera outbreak in Haiti and it was similar to O1 strains circulating in South Asia.<ref name=":5" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Orata|first=Fabini D.|last2=Keim|first2=Paul S.|last3=Boucher|first3=Yan|date=2014-04-03|title=The 2010 Cholera Outbreak in Haiti: How Science Solved a Controversy|url=http://journals.plos.org/plospathogens/article?id=10.1371/journal.ppat.1003967|journal=PLOS Pathogens|volume=10|issue=4|pages=e1003967|doi=10.1371/journal.ppat.1003967|issn=1553-7374|pmc=3974815|pmid=24699938}}</ref> Before the MINUSTAH troops from Nepal were sent to Haiti, a cholera outbreak had just occurred in Nepal. In the original research to trace the origin of the outbreak, the Nepal strains were not available.<ref name=":5" /> Phylodynamic analyses were performed on the Haitian strain and the Nepalese strain when it became available and affirmed that the Haitian cholera strain was the most similar to the Nepalese cholera strain.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Katz|first=Lee S.|last2=Petkau|first2=Aaron|last3=Beaulaurier|first3=John|last4=Tyler|first4=Shaun|last5=Antonova|first5=Elena S.|last6=Turnsek|first6=Maryann A.|last7=Guo|first7=Yan|last8=Wang|first8=Susana|last9=Paxinos|first9=Ellen E.|date=2013-08-30|title=Evolutionary Dynamics of Vibrio cholerae O1 following a Single-Source Introduction to Haiti|url=http://mbio.asm.org/content/4/4/e00398-13|journal=mBio|language=en|volume=4|issue=4|pages=e00398–13|doi=10.1128/mBio.00398-13|issn=2150-7511|pmc=3705451|pmid=23820394}}</ref> This outbreak strain of cholera in Haiti showed signs of an altered or hybrid strain of ''[[Vibrio cholerae|V. cholerae]]'' associated with high virulence.<ref name=":2" /> Typically high quality single-nucleotide polymorphisms (hqSNP) from whole genome ''[[Vibrio cholerae|V. cholerae]]'' sequences are used for phylodynamic analysis.<ref name=":2" /> Using phylodynamic analysis to study cholera helps prediction and understanding of ''V. cholerae'' evolution during bacterial epidemics.<ref name=":2" />
==See also== *[[2010 Haiti cholera outbreak]] *[[Computational phylogenetics]] *[[MAFFT]] *[[United Nations Stabilisation Mission in Haiti]] *[[Viral phylodynamics]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Bacteriology]] [[Category:Evolutionary biology]] [[Category:Phylogenetics]]

revision.text:
'''Biblical grammarians''' were linguists whose understanding of the [[Bible]] at least partially related to the science of [[Hebrew language]]. [[Tannaitic]] and Ammoraic [[exegesis]] rarely toiled in [[grammatical]] problems; grammar was a borrowed science from the [[Arab world]] in the [[medieval period]]. Despite its foreign influence, however, [[Hebrew grammar]] was a strongly [[Jewish]] product and developed independently.<ref>{{cite web|title=Jewish Encyclopedia|url=http://jewishencyclopedia.com/articles/6854-grammar-hebrew#anchor4|accessdate=March 10, 2013}}</ref> Scholars have continued to study grammar throughout the ages, until the present. Those mentioned in this article are a few of the most eminent grammarians.
== Early influences == === Masoretes === The [[Masoretes]], who solidified the [[Masoretic Text]] of the [[Hebrew Bible]], vocalized and punctuated the biblical text.<ref>{{cite web|title=Encyclopædia Britannica|url=http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/64496/biblical-literature|accessdate=March 10, 2013}}</ref> Most of the work of the Masoretes is generally anonymous, though we know several names of Masoretes.<ref>{{cite book|title=Encyclopedia Judaica, s.v. "Masorah"|edition=2nd}}</ref> While their work essentially focused on establishing the correct text and not the principles of grammar, the Masoretes contributed to the future study of biblical language.<ref>{{cite web|title=Jewish Encyclopedia| url=http://jewishencyclopedia.com/articles/6854-grammar-hebrew#anchor4|accessdate=March 10, 2013}}</ref> Many future grammarians continued the efforts of the Masorah and gave it a “central place in their works.” <ref>{{cite book|title=Encyclopedia Judaica, s.v. "Masorah"|edition=2nd}}</ref>
== Medieval grammarians == === Saadia Ga’on === Saadia Ga’on dealt with [[inflections]] and roots in his grammatical work. These contributions laid essential foundations for future grammarians. He also wrote about exceptions. His contemporary, [[Menahem ben Saruk]], elaborated upon the study of roots, and was also the first grammarian to write in Hebrew. A pupil of Saadia’s, [[Dunash ben Labrat]], criticized both [[Menahem]] and Saadia’s works but made many important contributions to understanding roots. Defenses of both sides by scholars such as Rabben Tam and ibn Ezra continued for centuries.<ref>{{cite web|title=Jewish Encyclopedia| url=http://jewishencyclopedia.com/articles/6854-grammar-hebrew#anchor4|accessdate=March 10, 2013}}</ref>
=== Rashi === [[Rashi]]'s commentary attempted to explain the simple meaning of the biblical text. In many places in his commentary, Rashi explains a linguistic or grammatical rule, providing several examples of other places in which that rule applies. Many of his principles he derives from the work of Menahem and Dunash. Evidence shows that Rashi understood the difference between [[biblical Hebrew]] and [[rabbinic Hebrew]]. Rashi also utilized [[Old French]] to explain the meaning of words that could not be otherwise explained.<ref>{{cite book|title=Encyclopedia Judaica, s.v. "Rashi"|edition=2nd}}</ref>
=== Abraham ibn Ezra === In his introduction to the [[Pentateuch]], [[Abraham ibn Ezra|Ibn Ezra]] writes that his commentary is “bound by the cords of grammar.” The way to appreciating the text is to understand the simple meaning, and he opposed explanations of the text that do not explain the original intent. Generally, he limited applying predecessors’ laws to understanding the text and avoided outlandish explanations of exceptions. A specific opposition ibn Ezra had was to the explanation of “plene versus defective spelling.” The Spanish commentator also wrote several grammatical works outside his biblical commentary.<ref>{{cite book|title=Encyclopedia Judaica, s.v. "Ibn Ezra, Abraham"|edition=2nd}}</ref>
=== Joseph Kimhi === [[Joseph Kimhi]] of the 12th century composed Sefer Zikkaron, introducing a new understanding of vowels. His two sons, Moses and David, also were grammarians.<ref>{{cite web|title=Jewish Encyclopedia| url=http://jewishencyclopedia.com/articles/6854-grammar-hebrew#anchor4|accessdate=March 10, 2013}}</ref> The Kimhis were exegets who relied most on [[peshat]] and avoided homileteical interpretations, and especially for David, [[philology]] played a large role in that.<ref>{{cite book|title=Encyclopedia Judaica, s.v. "Kimhi, David"|edition=2nd}}</ref>
== Modern grammarians == === The ''maskilim'' === The ''maskilim'' abandoned the use of rabbinic Hebrew and returned to biblical Hebrew. They felt serious grammar was of major import for modernization. [[Naphtali Herz Wessely]] and Judah Leib Ben Ze’ev were major perpetrators of this movement of Hebrew, which may have led to modern Hebrew.<ref>{{cite book|title=Encyclopedia Judaica, s.v. "Hebrew Language"|edition=2nd}}</ref> Study of Hebrew grammar had been neglected for nearly two centuries until the arrival of Moses Mendelssohn.<ref>{{cite web|title=Jewish Encyclopedia| url=http://jewishencyclopedia.com/articles/6854-grammar-hebrew#anchor4|accessdate=March 10, 2013}}</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Grammarians of Hebrew]] [[Category:Biblical scholars| Grammarians]]

revision.text:
[[File:BelemnitesJurassicWyoming.jpg|thumb|[[calcite|Calcitic]] skeletal parts of [[Belemnitida|belemnites]] ([[Jurassic]] of [[Wyoming]])]] '''Biomineralization''' is the process by which living organisms produce [[mineral]]s,{{efn|The [[International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry]] defines biomineralization as "mineralization caused by cell-mediated phenomena" and notes that it "is a process generally concomitant to [[biodegradation]]".<ref name=IUPAC1>{{cite journal|title=Terminology for biorelated polymers and applications (IUPAC Recommendations 2012)|journal=[[Pure and Applied Chemistry]]|year=2012|volume=84|issue=2|pages=377–410|doi=10.1351/PAC-REC-10-12-04|url=http://pac.iupac.org/publications/pac/pdf/2012/pdf/8402x0377.pdf}}</ref>}}<ref>{{cite book|last1=Harris, Ph.D.|first1=Edward D.|title=Minerals in Food Nutrition, Metabolism, Bioactivity|date=1 January 2014|publisher=DEStech Publications, Inc.|location=Lancaster, PA|isbn=978-1-932078-97-8|page=378|edition=1st|url=https://www.destechpub.com/index.php?fuseAction=catalogs.viewItem&catalogID=1&catalogLevelID=&catalogItemID=267#reviews|accessdate=30 January 2015}}</ref> often to harden or stiffen existing tissues. Such tissues are called [[mineralized tissues]]. It is an extremely widespread phenomenon; all six taxonomic kingdoms contain members that are able to form minerals, and over 60 different minerals have been identified in organisms.<ref>{{cite book |title=Biomineralization: From Nature to Application|editor1=Astrid Sigel |editor2= Helmut Sigel |editor3=Rol, K.O. Sigel |publisher=Wiley|year=2008|series=Metal Ions in Life Sciences|volume=4 | isbn=978-0-470-03525-2}}</ref><ref name=Weiner1989>{{cite book |author1=Weiner, Stephen |author2=Lowenstam, Heinz A. | title=On biomineralization | publisher=Oxford University Press |location=Oxford [Oxfordshire] |year=1989 |pages= |isbn=0-19-504977-2}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Biominerals and fossils through time|author1=Jean-Pierre Cuif |author2=Yannicke Dauphin |author3=James E. Sorauf |publisher=Cambridge|year=2011| isbn=978-0-521-87473-1}}</ref> Examples include [[silicates]] in [[algae]] and [[diatoms]], [[carbonate]]s in [[invertebrates]], and [[calcium phosphates]] and [[calcium carbonate|carbonates]] in [[vertebrates]]. These minerals often form structural features such as sea [[animal shell|shells]] and the [[bone]] in [[mammals]] and [[birds]]. [[Organism]]s have been producing mineralised [[skeleton]]s for the past 550 million years. Other examples include [[copper]], [[iron]] and [[gold]] deposits involving bacteria. Biologically-formed minerals often have special uses such as magnetic sensors in [[magnetotactic bacteria]] (Fe<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub>), gravity sensing devices (CaCO<sub>3</sub>, CaSO<sub>4</sub>, BaSO<sub>4</sub>) and iron storage and mobilization (Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>•H<sub>2</sub>O in the protein [[ferritin]]).
In terms of taxonomic distribution, the most common biominerals are the [[phosphate]] and [[carbonate]] salts of [[calcium]] that are used in conjunction with organic polymers such as [[collagen]] and [[chitin]] to give structural support to bones and shells.<ref name=Vinn2013>{{cite journal | author = Vinn, O. | year = 2013 | title = Occurrence formation and function of organic sheets in the mineral tube structures of Serpulidae (Polychaeta Annelida) | journal = PLoS ONE | volume = 8 | issue = 10 | pages = e75330 | url = http://dx.plos.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0075330 | accessdate = 2013-10-27 | doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0075330 |bibcode = 2013PLoSO...875330V | pmid=24116035 | pmc=3792063}}</ref> The structures of these biocomposite materials are highly controlled from the [[nanometer]] to the macroscopic level, resulting in complex architectures that provide multifunctional properties. Because this range of control over mineral growth is desirable for materials engineering applications, there is significant interest in understanding and elucidating the mechanisms of biologically controlled biomineralization.<ref name=Boskey>{{Cite journal | pmid = 9893259 | year = 1998 | last1 = Boskey | first1 = A. L. | title = Biomineralization: conflicts, challenges, and opportunities | volume = 30–31 | pages = 83–91 | journal = Journal of Cellular Biochemistry. Supplement }}</ref><ref name=Sarikaya1999>{{Cite journal | pmid = 10588672 | year = 1999 | last1 = Sarikaya | first1 = M. | title = Biomimetics: Materials fabrication through biology | volume = 96 | issue = 25 | pages = 14183–14185 | pmc = 33939 | journal = Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America | doi = 10.1073/pnas.96.25.14183 |bibcode = 1999PNAS...9614183S }}</ref>
{{Quote box |title =[[International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry| IUPAC]] definition |quote = '''Biomineralization''': Complete conversion of organic substances to inorganic derivatives by living organisms, especially micro-organisms. <ref>{{cite journal |last1=Vert |first1=Michel |last2=Doi |first2=Yoshiharu |last3=Hellwich |first3=Karl-Heinz |last4=Hess |first4=Michael |last5=Hodge |first5=Philip |last6=Kubisa |first6=Przemyslaw |last7=Rinaudo |first7=Marguerite |last8=Schué |first8=François |title=Terminology for biorelated polymers and applications (IUPAC Recommendations 2012) |journal=Pure and Applied Chemistry |date=11 January 2012 |volume=84 |issue=2 |pages=377–410 |doi=10.1351/PAC-REC-10-12-04}}</ref>}}
==Biological roles== Among [[metazoan]]s, biominerals composed of [[calcium carbonate]], [[calcium phosphate]] or [[silica]] perform a variety of roles such as support, defense and feeding.<ref name=Livingston2006>{{Cite journal| doi = 10.1016/j.ydbio.2006.07.047| pmid = 16987510| year = 2006| last1 = Livingston | first1 = B.| last2 = Killian | first2 = C.| last3 = Wilt | first3 = F.| last4 = Cameron | first4 = A.| last5 = Landrum | first5 = M.| last6 = Ermolaeva | first6 = O.| last7 = Sapojnikov | first7 = V.| last8 = Maglott | first8 = D.| last9 = Buchanan | first9 = A.| last10 = Ettensohn | first10 = C. A.| title = A genome-wide analysis of biomineralization-related proteins in the sea urchin ''Strongylocentrotus purpuratus''| volume = 300| issue = 1| pages = 335–348| journal = Developmental Biology }}</ref> It is less clear what purpose biominerals serve in bacteria. One hypothesis is that cells create them to avoid entombment by their own metabolic byproducts. Iron oxide particles may also enhance their metabolism.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Fortin|first1=D.|title=Enhanced: What Biogenic Minerals Tell Us|journal=Science|date=12 March 2004|volume=303|issue=5664|pages=1618–1619|doi=10.1126/science.1095177}}</ref>
==Biology== If present on a super-cellular scale, biominerals are usually deposited by a dedicated organ, which is often defined very early in the embryological development. This organ will contain an organic matrix that facilitates and directs the deposition of crystals.<ref name=Livingston2006/> The matrix may be collagen, as in deuterostomes,<ref name=Livingston2006/> or based on chitin or other polysaccharides, as in molluscs.<ref name='Checa2009'>{{Cite journal| doi = 10.1007/s00114-008-0461-1| pmid = 18843476| year = 2009| last1 = Checa | first1 = A.| last2 = Ramírez-Rico | first2 = J.| last3 = González-Segura | first3 = A.| last4 = Sánchez-Navas | first4 = A.| title = Nacre and false nacre (foliated aragonite) in extant monoplacophorans (=Tryblidiida: Mollusca)| volume = 96| issue = 1| pages = 111–122| journal = Die Naturwissenschaften|bibcode = 2009NW.....96..111C }}</ref>
===Shell formation in molluscs=== {{further|Mollusc shell}} [[File:Shells-IZE-006-Black.jpg|thumb|Variety of mollusc shells (gastropods, snails and seashells).]] The mollusc shell is a biogenic composite material that has been the subject of much interest in materials science because of its unusual properties and its model character for biomineralization. Molluscan shells consist of 95–99% calcium carbonate by weight, while an organic component makes up the remaining 1–5%. The resulting composite has a fracture toughness ~3000 times greater than that of the crystals themselves.<ref name="Currey1999">{{Cite journal | pmid = 10562511 | year = 1999 | last1 = Currey | first1 = J. D. | title = The design of mineralised hard tissues for their mechanical functions | volume = 202 | issue = Pt 23 | pages = 3285–3294 | journal = The Journal of Experimental Biology }}</ref> In the biomineralization of the mollusc shell, specialized proteins are responsible for directing crystal nucleation, phase, morphology, and growths dynamics and ultimately give the shell its remarkable mechanical strength. The application of biomimetic principles elucidated from mollusc shell assembly and structure may help in fabricating new composite materials with enhanced optical, electronic, or structural properties.
=== Mineral production and degradation in fungi === [[Fungus|Fungi]] are a diverse group of organisms that belong to the [[Eukaryote|eukaryotic]] domain. Studies of their significant roles in geological processes, "geomycology", has shown that fungi are involved with biomineralization, [[biodegradation]], and metal-fungal interactions.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Gadd|first=Geoffrey M.|date=2007-01-01|title=Geomycology: biogeochemical transformations of rocks, minerals, metals and radionuclides by fungi, bioweathering and bioremediation|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0953756206003364|journal=Mycological Research|volume=111|issue=1|pages=3–49|doi=10.1016/j.mycres.2006.12.001}}</ref>
In studying fungi's roles in biomineralization, it has been found that fungi deposit minerals with the help of an organic matrix, such as a protein, that provides a nucleation site for the growth of biominerals.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Li|first=Qianwei|last2=Gadd|first2=Geoffrey Michael|date=2017-08-10|title=Biosynthesis of copper carbonate nanoparticles by ureolytic fungi|journal=Applied Microbiology and Biotechnology|doi=10.1007/s00253-017-8451-x|issn=1432-0614|pmc=5594056|pmid=28799032}}</ref> Fungal growth may produce a copper-containing mineral precipitate, such as [[Basic copper carbonate|copper carbonate]] produced from a mixture of [[Ammonium carbonate|(NH<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub>]] and [[Copper(II) chloride|CuCl<sub>2</sub>]].<ref name=":0" /> The production of the copper carbonate is produced in the presence of proteins made and secreted by the fungi.<ref name=":0" /> These fungal proteins that are found extracellularly aid in the size and morphology of the [[carbonate minerals]] precipitated by the fungi.<ref name=":0" />
In addition to precipitating carbonate minerals, fungi can also precipitate [[uranium]]-containing phosphate biominerals in the presence of organic [[phosphorus]] that acts a substrate for the process.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Liang|first=Xinjin|last2=Hillier|first2=Stephen|last3=Pendlowski|first3=Helen|last4=Gray|first4=Nia|last5=Ceci|first5=Andrea|last6=Gadd|first6=Geoffrey Michael|date=2015-06-01|title=Uranium phosphate biomineralization by fungi|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/1462-2920.12771/abstract|journal=Environmental Microbiology|language=en|volume=17|issue=6|pages=2064–2075|doi=10.1111/1462-2920.12771|issn=1462-2920}}</ref> The fungi produce a hyphal matrix, also known as [[mycelium]], that localizes and accumulates the uranium minerals that have been precipitated.<ref name=":1" /> Although uranium is often deemed as toxic towards living organisms, certain fungi such as ''[[Aspergillus niger]]'' and ''Paecilomyces javanicus'' can tolerate it.
Though minerals can be produced by fungi, they can also be degraded; mainly by [[Oxalic acid|oxalic-acid]] producing strains of fungi.<ref name=":2" /> Oxalic acid production is increased in the presence of [[glucose]] for three organic acid producing fungi – ''Aspergillus niger'', ''[[Serpula himantioides]]'', and ''[[Trametes versicolor]]''.<ref name=":2" /> These fungi have been found to corrode [[apatite]] and [[galena]] minerals.<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Adeyemi|first=Ademola O.|last2=Gadd|first2=Geoffrey M.|date=2005-06-01|title=Fungal degradation of calcium-, lead- and silicon-bearing minerals|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10534-005-1539-2|journal=Biometals|language=en|volume=18|issue=3|pages=269–281|doi=10.1007/s10534-005-1539-2|issn=0966-0844}}</ref> Degradation of minerals by fungi is carried out through a process known as neogenesis.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Adamo|first=Paola|last2=Violante|first2=Pietro|date=2000-05-01|title=Weathering of rocks and neogenesis of minerals associated with lichen activity|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0169131799000563|journal=Applied Clay Science|volume=16|issue=5|pages=229–256|doi=10.1016/S0169-1317(99)00056-3}}</ref> The order of most to least oxalic acid secreted by the fungi studied are ''Aspergillus niger'', followed by ''Serpula himantioides'', and finally ''Trametes versicolor''.<ref name=":2" /> These capabilities of certain groups of fungi have a major impact on [[corrosion]], a costly problem for many industries and the economy.
==Chemistry== Because extracellular<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.jhc.org/cgi/content/abstract/11/6/799|vauthors=Gabbiani G, Tuchweber B|title=The role of iron in the mechanism of experimental calcification|journal=J Histochem Cytochem|year=1963|volume=11|issue=6|pages=799–803|doi=10.1177/11.6.799}}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> iron is strongly involved in inducing calcification,<ref>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1038/nature02631 | pmid = 15295599 | year = 2004 | last1 = Schulz | first1 = K. | last2 = Zondervan | first2 = I. | last3 = Gerringa | first3 = L. | last4 = Timmermans | first4 = K. | last5 = Veldhuis | first5 = M. | last6 = Riebesell | first6 = U. | title = Effect of trace metal availability on coccolithophorid calcification. | volume = 430 | issue = 7000 | pages = 673–676 | journal = Nature |bibcode = 2004Natur.430..673S }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | pmid = 8312724 | year = 1993 | last1 = Anghileri | first1 = L. J. | last2 = Maincent | first2 = P. | last3 = Cordova-Martinez | first3 = A. | title = On the mechanism of soft tissue calcification induced by complexed iron | volume = 45 | issue = 5–6 | pages = 365–368 | journal = Experimental and Toxicologic Pathology | doi=10.1016/S0940-2993(11)80429-X }}</ref> its control is essential in developing shells; the protein [[ferritin]] plays an important role in controlling the distribution of iron.<ref name='Jackson2007'>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1186/1471-2148-7-160 | title = Dynamic expression of ancient and novel molluscan shell genes during ecological transitions | year = 2007 | last1 = Jackson | first1 = D. J. | last2 = Wörheide | first2 = G. | last3 = Degnan | first3 = B. M. | journal = BMC Evolutionary Biology | volume = 7 | pages = 160| pmid = 17845714 | pmc = 2034539 }}</ref> The most common mineral present in biomineralization is [[hydroxyapatite]] (HA), which is a naturally occurring [[mineral]] form of calcium [[apatite]] with the formula Ca<sub>10</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>6</sub>(OH)<sub>2</sub>. Hydroxyapatite crystals are found in many biological materials including bones,<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Roy|first=Della M. |title=Hydroxyapatite formed from coral skeletal carbonate by hydrothermal exchange |journal=Nature |volume=247 |pages=220–222 |year=1974|doi=10.1038/247220a0|bibcode=1974Natur.247..220R}}</ref> fish scales,<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Onozato|first=Hiroshi |title=Studies on fish scale formation and resorption |journal=Cell and Tissue Research |volume=201 |issue=3 |pages=409–422 |year=1979|doi=10.1007/BF00236999}}</ref> and cartilage.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Ohirta|first=T|title=Hydroxyapatite deposition in articular cartilage by intra-articular injections of methylprednisolone. A histological, ultrastructural, and x-ray-microprobe analysis in rabbits. |journal=The Journal of Bone and Joint Surgery |volume=68|issue=4 |pages=509–520 |year=1986}}</ref> Each material has a mineral content which corresponds with the required mechanical properties, where increasing HA content typically leads to increased stiffness but reduced extensibility.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Sherman |first=Vincent R. |title=The materials science of collagen |journal=Journal of the Mechanical Behavior of Biomedical Materials |volume=61 |issue=5 |pages=529–534 |year=2008 |doi=10.1016/j.bjps.2007.06.004 |pmid=17652049}}</ref>
==Evolution== [[File:Haeckel Calcispongiae.jpg|thumb|Some calcareous sponges ([[Ernst Haeckel]], ''[[Kunstformen der Natur]]'').]] The first evidence of biomineralization dates to some {{Ma|750}},<ref name="Porter2011">{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1130/focus062011.1 | last1 = Porter | first1 = S. | title = The rise of predators | journal = Geology | volume = 39 | issue = 6 | pages = 607–608 | year = 2011 |bibcode = 2011Geo....39..607P }}</ref><ref name="Cohen2011">{{Cite journal | last1 = Cohen | first1 = P. A. | last2 = Schopf | first2 = J. W. | last3 = Butterfield | first3 = N. J. | last4 = Kudryavtsev | first4 = A. B. | last5 = MacDonald | first5 = F. A. | title = Phosphate biomineralization in mid-Neoproterozoic protists | doi = 10.1130/G31833.1 | journal = Geology | year = 2011 | pmid = | pmc = |bibcode = 2011Geo....39..539C | volume=39 | pages=539–542}}</ref> and sponge-grade organisms may have formed [[calcite]] skeletons {{Ma|630}}.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Maloof | first1 = A. C. | last2 = Rose | first2 = C. V. | last3 = Beach | first3 = R. | last4 = Samuels | first4 = B. M. | last5 = Calmet | first5 = C. C. | last6 = Erwin | first6 = D. H. | last7 = Poirier | first7 = G. R. | last8 = Yao | first8 = N. | last9 = Simons | first9 = F. J. | title = Possible animal-body fossils in pre-Marinoan limestones from South Australia | journal = Nature Geoscience | volume = 3 | issue = 9 | pages = 653–659 | year = 2010 | doi = 10.1038/ngeo934|bibcode = 2010NatGe...3..653M }}</ref> But in most lineages, biomineralization first occurred in the [[Cambrian]] or [[Ordovician]] periods.<ref name="Wood2002">{{cite journal|last1=Wood|first1=R. A.|title=Proterozoic Modular Biomineralized Metazoan from the Nama Group, Namibia|journal=Science|volume=296|issue=5577|year=2002|pages=2383–2386|issn=0036-8075|doi=10.1126/science.1071599|pmid=12089440|bibcode = 2002Sci...296.2383W }}</ref> Organisms used whichever form of calcium carbonate was more stable in the [[water column]] at the point in time when they became biomineralized,<ref name=Zhuravlev2008/> and stuck with that form for the remainder of their biological history<ref name='Porter2007'>{{Cite journal| first1 = S. M.| title = Seawater chemistry and early carbonate biomineralization| journal = Science| volume = 316| issue = 5829| last1 = Porter| page = 1302| date=Jun 2007 | issn = 0036-8075| pmid = 17540895| doi = 10.1126/science.1137284|bibcode = 2007Sci...316.1302P }}</ref> (but see <ref name="Maloof2010">{{Cite journal | last1 = Maloof | first1 = A. C. | last2 = Porter | first2 = S. M. | last3 = Moore | first3 = J. L. | last4 = Dudas | first4 = F. O. | last5 = Bowring | first5 = S. A. | last6 = Higgins | first6 = J. A. | last7 = Fike | first7 = D. A. | last8 = Eddy | first8 = M. P. | title = The earliest Cambrian record of animals and ocean geochemical change | journal = Geological Society of America Bulletin | volume = 122 | issue = 11–12| pages = 1731–1774| year = 2010 | doi = 10.1130/B30346.1|bibcode = 2010GSAB..122.1731M }}</ref> for a more detailed analysis). The stability is dependent on the Ca/Mg ratio of [[seawater]], which is thought to be controlled primarily by the rate of [[sea floor spreading]], although atmospheric {{co2}} levels may also play a role.<ref name=Zhuravlev2008>{{Cite journal| doi = 10.1130/G25094A.1| title = Eve of biomineralization: Controls on skeletal mineralogy| year = 2008| last1 = Zhuravlev | first1 = A. Y.| last2 = Wood | first2 = R. A.| journal = Geology| volume = 36| issue = 12| pages = 923 | url = http://wzar.unizar.es/murero/activos/pdfs/2008_Zhuravlev&Wood_Geology.pdf|bibcode = 2008Geo....36..923Z }}</ref>
Biomineralization evolved multiple times, independently,<ref name="Murdock2011">{{Cite journal | last1 = Murdock | first1 = D. J. E. | last2 = Donoghue | first2 = P. C. J. | title = Evolutionary Origins of Animal Skeletal Biomineralization | journal = Cells Tissues Organs | volume = 194 | issue = 2–4 | pages = 98–102 | year = 2011 | pmid = 21625061 | doi = 10.1159/000324245}}</ref> and most animal lineages first expressed biomineralized components in the Cambrian period.<ref name="Kouchinsky2011">{{Cite journal | last1 = Kouchinsky | first1 = A. | last2 = Bengtson | first2 = S. | last3 = Runnegar | first3 = B. | last4 = Skovsted | first4 = C. | last5 = Steiner | first5 = M. | last6 = Vendrasco | first6 = M. | title = Chronology of early Cambrian biomineralization | journal = Geological Magazine | pages = 1 | year = 2011 | doi = 10.1017/S0016756811000720 | volume=149| bibcode = 2012GeoM..149..221K }}</ref> Many of the same processes are used in unrelated lineages, which suggests that biomineralization machinery was assembled from pre-existing "off-the-shelf" components already used for other purposes in the organism.<ref name=Knoll2004>{{Cite book |url = http://www.geochem.geos.vt.edu/bgep/pubs/Chapter_11_Knoll.pdf |author = Knoll, A.H. |year = 2004 |chapter = Biomineralization and evolutionary history |editor = P.M. Dove |editor2 = J.J. DeYoreo |editor3 = S. Weiner |title = Reviews in Mineralogy and Geochemistry |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100620222809/http://www.geochem.geos.vt.edu/bgep/pubs/Chapter_11_Knoll.pdf |archivedate = 2010-06-20 |df = }}</ref> Although the biomachinery facilitating biomineralization is complex – involving signalling transmitters, inhibitors, and transcription factors – many elements of this 'toolkit' are shared between phyla as diverse as [[coral]]s, [[molluscs]], and [[vertebrate]]s.<ref name='Westbroek1998'>{{Cite journal| volume = 392| title = A marriage of bone and nacre.| issue = 6679| pages = 861–862| journal = Nature | first2 = F.| last2 = Marin| pmid = 9582064| year = 1998| last1 = Westbroek | first1 = P.| doi = 10.1038/31798 |bibcode = 1998Natur.392..861W }}</ref> The shared components tend to perform quite fundamental tasks, such as designating that cells will be used to create the minerals, whereas genes controlling more finely tuned aspects that occur later in the biomineralization process – such as the precise alignment and structure of the crystals produced – tend to be uniquely evolved in different lineages.<ref name=Livingston2006/><ref name=Jackson2010>{{Cite journal| doi = 10.1093/molbev/msp278| pmid = 19915030| year = 2010| last1 = Jackson | first1 = D.| last2 = McDougall | first2 = C.| last3 = Woodcroft | first3 = B.| last4 = Moase | first4 = P.| last5 = Rose | first5 = R.| last6 = Kube | first6 = M.| last7 = Reinhardt | first7 = R.| last8 = Rokhsar | first8 = D.| last9 = Montagnani | first9 = C.| last10 = Joubert | first10 = C.| last11 = Piquemal | first11 = D.| last12 = Degnan | first12 = B. M.| title = Parallel evolution of nacre building gene sets in molluscs| volume = 27| issue = 3| pages = 591–608| journal = Molecular Biology and Evolution }}</ref> This suggests that [[Precambrian]] organisms were employing the same elements, albeit for a different purpose — perhaps to ''avoid'' the inadvertent precipitation of calcium carbonate from the supersaturated [[Proterozoic]] oceans.<ref name=Westbroek1998/> Forms of [[mucus]] that are involved in inducing mineralization in most [[metazoan]] lineages appear to have performed such an anticalcifatory function in the ancestral state.<ref name=Marin1996>{{cite journal|doi=10.1073/pnas.93.4.1554|url=http://www.pnas.org/content/93/4/1554|pmid=11607630|year=1996|last1=Marin|first1=F|last2=Smith|first2=M|last3=Isa|first3=Y|last4=Muyzer|first4=G|last5=Westbroek|first5=P|title=Skeletal matrices, muci, and the origin of invertebrate calcification|volume=93|issue=4|pages=1554–9|pmc=39979|journal=[[Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America]]|bibcode = 1996PNAS...93.1554M }}</ref> Further, certain proteins that would originally have been involved in maintaining calcium concentrations within cells<ref>{{Cite journal|author1=H. A. Lowenstam |author2=L. Margulis |journal=[[BioSystems]] |volume=12 |year=1980 |doi=10.1016/0303-2647(80)90036-2 |pmid=6991017|title=Evolutionary prerequisites for early phanerozoic calcareous skeletons|issue=1–2|pages=27–41}}</ref> are homologous to all metazoans, and appear to have been co-opted into biomineralization after the divergence of the metazoan lineages.<ref>{{Cite journal| doi = 10.1016/0303-2647(80)90036-2| title = Evolutionary prerequisites for early phanerozoic calcareous skeletons| year = 1980| last1 = Lowenstam | first1 = H.| last2 = Margulis | first2 = L.| journal = Biosystems| volume = 12| pages = 27–41| pmid = 6991017| issue = 1–2 }}</ref> The ''galaxins'' are one probable example of a gene being co-opted from a different ancestral purpose into controlling biomineralization, in this case being 'switched' to this purpose in the [[Triassic]] [[scleractinian corals]]; the role performed appears to be functionally identical to the unrelated pearlin gene in molluscs.<ref name='Reyes2009'>{{Cite journal| doi = 10.1186/1471-2148-9-178| pmid = 19638240| year = 2009| last1 = Reyes-Bermudez | first1 = A.| last2 = Lin | first2 = Z.| last3 = Hayward | first3 = D.| last4 = Miller | first4 = D.| last5 = Ball | first5 = E.| title = Differential expression of three galaxin-related genes during settlement and metamorphosis in the scleractinian coral Acropora millepora| volume = 9| pages = 178| pmc = 2726143| journal = BMC Evolutionary Biology }}</ref> [[Carbonic anhydrase]] serves a role in mineralization in [[sponges]], as well as metazoans, implying an ancestral role.<ref>{{Cite journal| doi = 10.1126/science.1141560| pmid = 17540861| year = 2007| last1 = Jackson | first1 = D.| last2 = Macis | first2 = L.| last3 = Reitner | first3 = J.| last4 = Degnan | first4 = B.| last5 = Wörheide | first5 = G.| title = Sponge paleogenomics reveals an ancient role for carbonic anhydrase in skeletogenesis.| volume = 316| issue = 5833| pages = 1893–1895| journal = Science |bibcode = 2007Sci...316.1893J }}</ref> Far from being a rare trait that evolved a few times and remained stagnant, biomineralization pathways in fact evolved many times and are still evolving rapidly today; even within a single genus it is possible to detect great variation within a single gene family.<ref name=Jackson2010/>
The [[homology (biology)|homology]] of biomineralization pathways is underlined by a remarkable experiment whereby the [[nacreous]] layer of a molluscan shell was implanted into a [[human tooth]], and rather than experiencing an immune response, the molluscan nacre was incorporated into the host bone matrix. This points to the [[exaptation]] of an original biomineralization pathway.
The most ancient example of biomineralization, dating back 2 billion years, is the deposition of [[magnetite]], which is observed in some bacteria, as well as the teeth of [[chiton]]s and the brains of vertebrates; it is possible that this pathway, which performed a [[magnetosensory]] role in the common ancestor of all [[bilaterians]], was duplicated and modified in the Cambrian to form the basis for calcium-based biomineralization pathways.<ref name=Kirschvink2000>{{Cite book|author1=Kirschvink J.L. |author2=Hagadorn, J.W. |lastauthoramp=yes |chapter= 10 A Grand Unified theory of Biomineralization. |editor=Bäuerlein, E. |title=The Biomineralisation of Nano- and Micro-Structures, |publisher=[[Wiley-VCH]] |location=Weinheim, Germany|pages=139–150|year=2000}}</ref> Iron is stored in close proximity to magnetite-coated chiton teeth, so that the teeth can be renewed as they wear. Not only is there a marked similarity between the [[magnetite]] deposition process and enamel deposition in vertebrates but some vertebrates even have comparable iron storage facilities near their teeth.<ref>{{Cite journal| doi = 10.1016/S0022-5320(67)80015-7| title = Ultrastructure and development of iron mineralization in the radular teeth of Cryptochiton stelleri (mollusca)| year = 1967| last1 = Towe | first1 = K.| last2 = Lowenstam | first2 = H.| journal = Journal of Ultrastructure Research| volume = 17| pages = 1–13| pmid = 6017357| issue = 1 }}</ref>
[[File:Glomerula piloseta tube microstructure.jpg|thumb|''Glomerula piloseta'' ([[Sabellidae]]), longitudinal section of the tube, [[aragonite|aragonitic]] spherulitic prismatic structure]] {| |- valign="top" |} {| class="wikitable" style="font-size:95%" |- ! Type of mineralization !! Examples of organisms |- align="left" | '''[[Calcium carbonate]]''' ([[calcite]] or [[aragonite]]) || *[[foraminifera]] *[[coccolithophores]] *[[calcareous sponge]] [[spicule (sponge)|spicule]]s *[[corals]] *[[Archaeocyatha]] *[[bryozoans]] *[[brachiopod]] and [[mollusc shells]] *[[Echinoderms]] *[[Serpulidae]] |- align="left" |'''[[Silica]]''' || *[[radiolarians]] *[[diatoms]] *most [[sponge]] spicules |- align="left" |'''[[Apatite]]''' (phosphate carbonate) || *[[tooth enamel|enamel]] ([[Vertebrate]] teeth) *Vertebrate [[bone]] *[[conodont]]s |}
==Astrobiology== It has been suggested that biominerals could be important indicators of extraterrestrial life and thus could play an important role in the search for past or present life on [[Mars]]. Furthermore, [[Organic compounds (minerals)|organic components]] ([[biosignature]]s) that are often associated with biominerals are believed to play crucial roles in both pre-biotic and [[Biotic material|biotic]] reactions.<ref name=SSG >{{Cite book | editor2-first=David| editor2-last= Beaty | contribution=Final report of the MEPAG Astrobiology Field Laboratory Science Steering Group (AFL-SSG)| title=The Astrobiology Field Laboratory | editor1-first=Andrew | editor1-last=Steele | publisher=[[Mars Exploration Program Analysis Group]] (MEPAG) - NASA| place=U.S.A.| pages=72| date=September 26, 2006| id= | contribution-url=http://mepag.jpl.nasa.gov/reports/AFL_SSG_WHITE_PAPER_v3.doc| chapter-format=.doc| accessdate=2009-07-22 |authors=MEPAG Astrobiology Field Laboratory Science Steering Group}}</ref>
On January 24, 2014, NASA reported that current studies by the [[Curiosity (rover)|''Curiosity'']] and [[Opportunity (rover)|''Opportunity'']] [[Mars rover|rovers]] on the planet [[Mars]] will now be searching for evidence of ancient life, including a [[biosphere]] based on [[autotroph]]ic, [[chemotroph]]ic and/or [[Lithotroph#Chemolithotrophs|chemolithoautotrophic]] [[microorganism]]s, as well as ancient water, including [[Lacustrine plain|fluvio-lacustrine environments]] ([[plain]]s related to ancient [[river]]s or [[lake]]s) that may have been [[Planetary habitability|habitable]].<ref name="SCI-20140124a">{{cite journal |last=Grotzinger |first=John P.|title=Introduction to Special Issue - Habitability, Taphonomy, and the Search for Organic Carbon on Mars|url=http://www.sciencemag.org/content/343/6169/386 |journal=[[Science (journal)|Science]] |date=January 24, 2014 |volume=343 |number=6169 |pages=386–387 |doi=10.1126/science.1249944 |accessdate=January 24, 2014|bibcode = 2014Sci...343..386G |pmid=24458635}}</ref><ref name="SCI-20140124special">{{cite journal |authors=Various |title=Special Issue - Table of Contents - Exploring Martian Habitability |url=http://www.sciencemag.org/content/343/6169.toc#SpecialIssue|date=January 24, 2014|journal=[[Science (journal)|Science]] |volume=343 |number=6169 |pages=345–452|accessdate=January 24, 2014 }}</ref><ref name="SCI-20140124">{{cite journal |authors=Various |title=Special Collection - Curiosity - Exploring Martian Habitability|url=http://www.sciencemag.org/site/extra/curiosity/|date=January 24, 2014 |journal=[[Science (journal)|Science]] |accessdate=January 24, 2014 }}</ref><ref name="SCI-20140124c">{{cite journal|author=Grotzinger, J.P. |title=A Habitable Fluvio-Lacustrine Environment at Yellowknife Bay, Gale Crater, Mars |url=http://www.sciencemag.org/content/343/6169/1242777 |date=January 24, 2014 |journal=[[Science (journal)|Science]] |volume=343 |number=6169 |doi=10.1126/science.1242777 |accessdate=January 24, 2014 |bibcode = 2014Sci...343A.386G |display-authors=etal |pmid=24324272 |pages=1242777}}</ref> The search for evidence of [[Planetary habitability|habitability]], [[taphonomy]] (related to [[fossils]]), and [[organic carbon]] on the planet [[Mars]] is now a primary [[NASA]] objective.<ref name="SCI-20140124a"/><ref name="SCI-20140124special"/>
==Potential applications== Most traditional approaches to synthesis of nanoscale materials are energy inefficient, requiring stringent conditions (e.g., high temperature, pressure or pH) and often produce toxic byproducts. Furthermore, the quantities produced are small, and the resultant material is usually irreproducible because of the difficulties in controlling agglomeration.<ref name="isbn1-55899-181-6">{{cite book |author1=Thomas, George Brinton |author2=Komarneni, Sridhar |author3=Parker, John |title=Nanophase and Nanocomposite Materials: Symposium Held December 1–3, 1992, Boston, Massachusetts, U.S.A. (Materials Research Society Symposium Proceedings) |publisher=Materials Research Society |location=Pittsburgh, Pa |year=1993 |pages= |isbn=1-55899-181-6 |oclc= |doi= |accessdate=}}</ref> In contrast, materials produced by organisms have properties that usually surpass those of analogous synthetically manufactured materials with similar phase composition. Biological materials are assembled in aqueous environments under mild conditions by using macromolecules. Organic macromolecules collect and transport raw materials and assemble these substrates and into short- and long-range ordered composites with consistency and uniformity. The aim of [[biomimetics]] is to mimic the natural way of producing minerals such as [[apatite]]s. Many man-made crystals require elevated temperatures and strong chemical solutions, whereas the organisms have long been able to lay down elaborate mineral structures at ambient temperatures. Often, the mineral phases are not pure but are made as [[Composite material|composites]] that entail an organic part, often [[protein]], which takes part in and controls the biomineralisation. These composites are often not only as hard as the pure mineral but also tougher, as the micro-environment controls biomineralisation.
===Uranium contaminants in groundwater=== [[File:Autunite-69257.jpg|thumb|Autunite crystal.]] Biomineralization may be used to remediate groundwater contaminated with [[uranium]].<ref name=Newsome2014>{{cite journal|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0009254113004907|author1=Newsome, L. |author2=Morris, K. |author3=Lloyd, J. R. |last-author-amp=yes |title=The biogeochemistry and bioremediation of uranium and other priority radionuclides|journal=Chemical Geology|year=2014|volume=363|pages=164–184|doi=10.1016/j.chemgeo.2013.10.034|bibcode=2014ChGeo.363..164N}}</ref> The biomineralization of uranium primarily involves the precipitation of uranium phosphate minerals associated with the release of phosphate by microorganisms. Negatively charged [[ligands]] at the surface of the cells attract the positively charged uranyl ion (UO<sub>2</sub><sup>2+</sup>). If the concentrations of phosphate and UO<sub>2</sub><sup>2+</sup> are sufficiently high, minerals such as [[autunite]] (Ca(UO<sub>2</sub>)<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>•10-12H<sub>2</sub>O) or polycrystalline HUO<sub>2</sub>PO<sub>4</sub> may form thus reducing the mobility of UO<sub>2</sub><sup>2+</sup>. Compared to the direct addition of inorganic phosphate to contaminated groundwater, biomineralization has the advantage that the ligands produced by microbes will target uranium compounds more specifically rather than react actively with all aqueous metals. Stimulating bacterial phosphatase activity to liberate phosphate under controlled conditions limits the rate of bacterial hydrolysis of organophosphate and the release of phosphate to the system, thus avoiding clogging of the injection location with metal phosphate minerals.<ref name=Newsome2014/> The high concentration of ligands near the cell surface also provides nucleation foci for precipitation, which leads to higher efficiency than chemical precipitation.<ref>{{cite book |author1=Lloyd, J. R. |author2=Macaskie, L. E |last-author-amp=yes |title=Environmental microbe-metal interactions: Bioremediation of radionuclide-containing wastewaters|publisher=ASM Press|location=Washington, DC|year=2000|pages=277–327|isbn=1-55581-195-7}}</ref>
== List of minerals == Examples of biogenic minerals include:<ref name=Corliss>{{cite journal|last1=Corliss|first1=William R.|title=Biogenic Minerals|journal=Science Frontiers|date=Nov-Dec 1989|volume=66|url=http://www.science-frontiers.com/sf066/sf066g13.htm}}</ref> * [[Apatite]] in bones and teeth. * [[Aragonite]], [[calcite]], [[fluorite]] in [[vestibular system]]s (part of the [[inner ear]]) of vertebrates. * [[Aragonite]] and [[calcite]] in [[travertine]] and [[biogenic silica]] (siliceous sinter, [[opal]]) deposited through [[algal]] action. * [[Hydroxylapatite]] formed by [[mitochondria]]. * [[Magnetite]] and [[greigite]] formed by [[magnetotactic bacteria]]. * [[Pyrite]] and [[marcasite]] in sedimentary rocks deposited by sulfate-reducing bacteria. * [[Quartz]] and [[diamond]]s formed from bacterial action on [[fossil fuel]]s (gas, oil, coal). * [[Goethite]] found as filaments in [[limpet]] teeth.
==See also== {{div col|colwidth=30em}} * [[Biocrystallization]] * [[Biointerface]] * [[Biomineralising polychaetes]] * [[Bone mineral]] {{div col end}}

Tohoku Univ. Museum |year=2001 |volume=1 |pages=144–151 }} *{{cite journal |author= Dauphin, Y. |title=Structures, organo mineral compositions and diagenetic changes in biominerals |journal=Current Opinion in Colloid & Interface Science |year=2002 |volume=7 |pages=133–138 |doi=10.1016/S1359-0294(02)00013-4 }} *{{cite journal |authors=Kupriyanova, E.K., Vinn, O., Taylor, P.D., Schopf, J.W., Kudryavtsev, A.B. and Bailey-Brock, J. |title=Serpulids living deep: calcareous tubeworms beyond the abyss |journal=Deep-Sea Research Part I |year=2014 |volume=90 |pages=91–104 |url=https://www.academia.edu/8904126/Serpulids_living_deep_calcareous_tubeworms_beyond_the_abyss |accessdate = 2014-01-09 |doi=10.1016/j.dsr.2014.04.006 |bibcode = 2014DSRI...90...91K }} *{{cite journal |authors=Vinn, O., ten Hove, H.A. and Mutvei, H. |title=Ultrastructure and mineral composition of serpulid tubes (Polychaeta, Annelida) |journal=Zoological Journal of the Linnean Society |year=2008 |volume=154 |pages=633–650 |url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/222089798_Ultrastructure_and_mineral_composition_of_serpulid_tubes_%28Polychaeta_Annelida%29 |accessdate = 2014-01-09 |doi=10.1111/j.1096-3642.2008.00421.x }} *{{cite journal |author=Vinn, O. |title=Occurrence, Formation and Function of Organic Sheets in the Mineral Tube Structures of Serpulidae (Polychaeta, Annelida) |journal=PLoS ONE |year=2013 |volume=8 |pages=e75330 |url=http://www.plosone.org/article/info%3Adoi%2F10.1371%2Fjournal.pone.0075330 |accessdate = 2014-01-09 |doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0075330 |bibcode = 2013PLoSO...875330V |pmid=24116035 |pmc=3792063}}

revision.comment: /* Etiological heterogeneity */
revision.text:
{{redirect2|Etiologies|etiologic|other uses|etiology}} '''Cause''', also known as '''etiology''' ({{IPAc-en|iː|t|i|ˈ|ɒ|l|ə|dʒ|i}}) and '''aetiology''', is the [[Causality|reason]] or origination of something.<ref>{{cite book |first=Kenneth J. |last=Rothman |authorlink=Kenneth Rothman (epidemiologist) |first2=Sander |last2=Greenland |authorlink2=Sander Greenland |first3=Charles |last3=Poole |first4=Timothy L. |last4=Lash |chapter=Causation and Causal Inference |title=Modern Epidemiology |location=Philadelphia |publisher=Lippincott Williams & Wilkins |edition=Third |year=2008 |isbn=978-0-7817-5564-1 |pages=6–7 |chapterurl=https://books.google.de/books?id=Z3vjT9ALxHUC&pg=PA6 }}</ref>
The word is derived from the [[Ancient Greek|Greek]] {{lang|grc|αἰτιολογία}}, ''aitiologia'', "giving a reason for" ({{lang|grc|αἰτία}}, ''aitia'', "cause"; and {{lang|grc|-λογία}}, ''[[wiktionary:-logia|-logia]]'').<ref>{{cite book | title = Aetiology | work = Oxford English Dictionary | edition = 2nd | year = 2002 | publisher = Oxford University Press | isbn = 0-19-521942-2}}</ref>
==Description== In medicine, the term refers to the causes of [[disease]]s or [[pathology|pathologies]].<ref>{{cite web | author = Greene J | url = http://www.widesmiles.org/cleftlinks/WS-364.html | title = The three C's of etiology | work = Wide Smiles | year = 1996 | accessdate = 2007-08-20 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070630061038/http://www.widesmiles.org/cleftlinks/WS-364.html <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2007-06-30}} Discusses several examples of the medical usage of the term ''etiology'' in the context of [[cleft lip]]s and explains methods used to study causation.</ref> Where no etiology can be ascertained, the disorder is said to be [[idiopathic]]. Traditional accounts of the causes of disease may point to the "[[evil eye]]".<ref> {{cite journal | last = Meleis | first = Afaf Ibrahim | authorlink = Afaf Meleis | date = June 1981 | url = http://pt.wkhealth.com/pt/re/lwwgateway/landingpage.htm;jsessionid=bDDBfXgg3KJcTTqqXlL2ZbWy1z7GlG5hvwk8LCFZ9CffYb7Dntbf!418189076!181195629!8091!-1?sid=WKPTLP:landingpage&an=00000446-198106000-00037 | title = The Arab American in the health care system | journal = American Journal of Nursing | volume = 81 | issue = 06 | pages = 1180–1183 | format = PDF | quote = While germ theory is not refuted, it does exist side by side with other disease etiologies. The evil eye (al hassad or al ain al Weh- sha) is one causative agent for the Arab. | doi=10.1097/00000446-198106000-00037 }}<!--| accessdate = 2010-09-12--> </ref> The [[Ancient Rome|Ancient Roman]] scholar [[Marcus Terentius Varro]] put forward early ideas about [[microorganism]]s in a 1st-century BC book titled ''On Agriculture''.<ref>''Varro On Agriculture'' 1, xii Loeb</ref>
Medieval thinking on the etiology of disease showed the influence of [[Galen]] and of [[Hippocrates]].<ref>[http://pmj.bmj.com/cgi/content/abstract/83/979/352 Maimonides: an early but accurate view on the treatment of hemorrhoids -- Magrill and Sekaran 83 (979): 352 -- Postgraduate Medical Journal]</ref> Medieval [[Europe]]an doctors generally held the view that disease was related to the air and adopted a [[Miasma theory of disease|miasmatic approach]] to disease etiology.<ref>[http://www.springerlink.com/index/w44720475g378602.pdf Case study: the history and ethics clean air]</ref>
Etiological discovery in medicine has a history in [[Robert Koch]]'s demonstration that the tubercle bacillus (''[[Mycobacterium tuberculosis]]'' complex) causes the disease [[tuberculosis]], ''[[Bacillus anthracis]]'' causes [[anthrax]], and ''[[Vibrio cholerae]]'' causes [[cholera]]. This line of thinking and evidence is summarized in [[Koch's postulates]]. But proof of causation in infectious diseases is limited to individual cases that provide experimental evidence of etiology.
In [[epidemiology]], several lines of evidence together are required to infer causation. [[Austin Bradford Hill|Sir Austin Bradford-Hill]] demonstrated a causal relationship between smoking and lung cancer, and summarized the line of reasoning in the epidemiological criteria for causation. Dr. Al Evans, a US epidemiologist, synthesized his predecessors' ideas in proposing the Unified Concept of Causation.
==Chain of causation and correlation==
Further thinking in epidemiology was required to [[correlation is not causation|distinguish causation from association or statistical correlation]]. Events may occur together simply due to [[Randomness|chance]], [[bias]] or [[confounding]], instead of one event being caused by the other. It is also important to know which event is the cause. Careful sampling and measurement are more important than sophisticated statistical analysis to determine causation. Experimental evidence involving interventions (providing or removing the supposed cause) gives the most compelling evidence of etiology.
Related to this, sometimes several symptoms always appear together, or more often than what could be expected, though it is known that one cannot cause the other. These situations are called [[syndrome]]s, and normally it is assumed that an underlying condition must exist that explains all the symptoms.
Other times there is not a single cause for a disease, but instead a chain of causation from an initial trigger to the development of the clinical disease. An etiological agent of disease may require an independent co-factor, and be subject to a promoter (increases expression) to cause disease. An example of all the above, which was recognized late, is that [[peptic ulcer disease]] may be induced by stress, requires the presence of acid secretion in the stomach, and has primary etiology in ''[[Helicobacter pylori]]'' infection. Many chronic diseases of unknown cause may be studied in this framework to explain multiple epidemiological associations or [[risk factor]]s which may or may not be causally related, and to seek the actual etiology.{{r to section}}
==Etiological heterogeneity==
Some diseases, such as [[diabetes]] or [[hepatitis]], are syndromically defined by their signs and [[symptom]]s, but include different conditions with different etiologies. These are called [[heterogeneous condition]]s.
Conversely, a single etiology, such as [[Epstein-Barr virus]], may in different circumstances produce different diseases such as [[Infectious mononucleosis|mononucleosis]], [[nasopharyngeal carcinoma]], or [[Burkitt's lymphoma]].
===Endotype=== {{main|endotype}} An '''endotype''' is a subtype of a condition, which is defined by a distinct functional or [[Pathobiology|pathobiological]] mechanism. This is distinct from a [[Phenotype (clinical medicine)|phenotype]], which is any observable characteristic or trait of a [[disease]], such as [[morphology (biology)|morphology]], development, biochemical or physiological properties, or behavior, without any implication of a mechanism. It is envisaged that [[patient]]s with a specific endotype present themselves within phenotypic clusters of diseases.
One example is asthma, which is considered to be a [[syndrome]], consisting of a series of endotypes.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Lötvall |first=J. |last2=Akdis |first2=C. A. |last3=Bacharier |first3=L. B. |last4=Bjermer |first4=L. |last5=Casale |first5=T. B. |last6=Custovic |first6=A. |last7=Lemanske |first7=R. F. Jr. |last8=Wardlaw |first8=A. J. |last9=Wenzel |first9=S. E. |last10=Greenberger |first10=P. A. |title=Asthma endotypes: A new approach to classification of disease entities within the asthma syndrome |journal=[[Journal of Allergy and Clinical Immunology|J Allergy Clin Immunol]] |year=2011 |volume=127 |issue=2 |pages=355–60 |doi=10.1016/j.jaci.2010.11.037 }}</ref> This is related to the concept of [[disease entity]].
Other example could be [[AIDS]], where an HIV infection can produce several [[clinical stage]]s. AIDS is defined as the clinical stage IV of the HIV infection.<ref>{{cite journal |first=Kenneth G. |last=Castro |first2=John W. |last2=Ward |first3=Laurence |last3=Slutsker |first4=James W. |last4=Buehler |first5=Harold W. |last5=Jaffe |first6=Ruth L. |last6=Berkelman |title=1993 Revised Classification System for HIV Infection and Expanded Surveillance Case Definition for AIDS among Adolescents and Adults |journal=Clinical Infectious Diseases |volume=17 |issue=4 |year=1993 |pages=802–810 |jstor=4457386 |doi=10.1093/clinids/17.4.802}}</ref>
== See also == *[[Bradford Hill criteria]] *[[Causal inference]] *[[Epidemiology]] *[[Molecular pathological epidemiology]] *[[Molecular pathology]] *[[Pathogenesis]] *[[Pathology]]
== References == {{reflist|30em}}

revision.comment: added [[Category:Cell biology]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
'''Cell biophysics''' (or '''cellular biophysics''') is a sub-field of [[biophysics]] that focuses on physical principles underlying [[cell (biology)|cell]] function. Sub-areas of current interest include statistical models of intracellular signaling dynamics, intracellular transport, [[cell mechanics]] (including [[membrane]] and [[cytoskeleton|cytoskeletal]] mechanics), [[molecular motors]], biological electricity and genetic network theory. <ref>{{cite book |last1=Phillips |first1= Rob|last2=Kondev |first2= Jan|last3= Theriot|first3=Julie|title= Physical Biology of the Cell|publisher= Garland Science, Taylor and Francis group|publication-date=2008}}</ref> The field has benefited greatly from recent advances in live-cell molecular imaging techniques that allow spatial and temporal measurement of macromolecules and macromolecular function. Specialized imaging methods like [[Förster resonance energy transfer|FRET]], [[Fluorescence recovery after photobleaching|FRAP]], [[Photoactivated localization microscopy|photoactivation]] and single molecule imaging have proven useful for mapping macromolecular transport, dynamic conformational changes in proteins and macromolecular interactions. Super-resolution microscopy allows imaging of cell structures below the optical resolution of light. Combining novel experimental tools with mathematical models grounded in the physical sciences has enabled significant recent breakthroughs in the field. Multiple centers across the world are advancing the research area<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bio.ph.tum.de/|title=Molecular and Cellular Biophysics|accessdate=April 4, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Center for the Physics of Living Cells|url=http://cplc.illinois.edu/|accessdate=April 4, 2014}}</ref>
==References== <references/>
[[Category:Biophysics]] [[Category:Cell biology]]
