revision.text:
{{peacock|date=November 2017}}[[File:Rudolf, Leopold and Caroline Blaschka in garden.tif|thumb|Rudolf (standing), Caroline, and Leopold Blaschka in the garden of their Dresden home]] '''Leopold Blaschka''' (27 May 1822 – 3 July 1895) and his son '''Rudolf Blaschka''' (17 June 1857 – 1 May 1939) were [[Dresden, Germany]] glass artists native to the Bohemian (Czech)–German borderland, known for the production of biological models such as the [[glass sea creatures]] and Harvard University's [[Glass Flowers]].
==Born to glass== The Blaschka family traces its roots to [[Josefův Důl (Jablonec nad Nisou District)|Josefuv Dul]] (Antoniwald) in the Iser or [[Izera Mountains]], a region known for processing glass, metals and gems<ref name="urania"/> and members of the family had worked in [[Venice]],<ref name="designmuseum" /> [[Bohemia]], and Germany.<ref>Sigwart, Julia D. "Crystal creatures: context for the Dublin Blaschka Congress." Historical Biology 20.1 (2008): 1-10.</ref><ref name="Harvell, Drew 2016">Harvell, Drew, and Greene, Harry W. A Sea of Glass: Searching for the Blaschkas&Apos; Fragile Legacy in an Ocean at Risk Organisms and Environments 13. University Of California Press, 2016.</ref> Leopold referred to this history in an 1889 letter to [[Mary Lee Ware]]: {{blockquote|Many people think that we have some secret apparatus by which we can squeeze glass suddenly into these forms, but it is not so. We have tact. My son Rudolf has more than I have, because he is my son, and tact increases in every generation. The only way to become a glass modeler of skill, I have often said to people, is to get a good great-grandfather who loved glass; then he is to have a son with like tastes; he is to be your grandfather. He in turn will have a son who must, as your father, be passionately fond of glass. You, as his son, can then try your hand, and it is your own fault if you do not succeed. But, if you do not have such ancestors, it is not your fault. My grandfather was the most widely known glassworker in Bohemia.<ref name="schultes" /><ref name="vitreous tract" />}}
Born in [[Český Dub]], [[Bohemia]], and one of [[Joseph Blaschke]]'s three sons,<ref name="Harvell, Drew 2016"/><ref name="heraldica">{{cite web|url=http://www.heraldica.cz/ghmags/2010/ghmag_2010_1-2_article-6.pdf|title=Heraldika a genealogie č. 1 - 2/2010|date=2011}}</ref> Leopold, alone of his brothers, displayed the necessary artistic skills as a child, and was apprenticed to a [[goldsmith]] and [[gemcutter]] in [[Turnov]], a town in the [[Liberec Region]] of today's Czech Republic.<ref name="heraldica"/> He then joined the family business, which produced glass ornaments and [[glass eye]]s.<ref name="designmuseum" /> He developed a technique which he termed "glass-spinning", which permitted the construction of highly precise and detailed works in glass. He also [[Latinised]] his family name to "Blaschka", and began to focus the business on the manufacture of glass eyes.<ref name="urania" />
Leopold married Caroline Zimmermann in 1846 and within four years their son Josef Augustin Blaschka was born.<ref name="heraldica"/> Caroline and Josef died of cholera in a 1850, and a year later his father died. Heartbroken, Leopold "sought consolation in the natural world, sketching the plants in the countryside around his home."<ref>The Story of Rudolf and Leopold Blaschka - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rHOx5H5vNx4</ref><ref name="heraldica"/>
==Glass marine invertebrates== {{main|Glass sea creatures}} [[File:Blaschka 4.jpg|thumb|right|Blaschka model of jellyfish]] In 1853, Leopold traveled to the United States. En route the ship was delayed at sea for two weeks by lack of wind.<ref name="cmog invertebrates" /> During this time Leopold studied and sketched local [[marine invertebrate]], intrigued by the glass-like transparency of their bodies.<ref name="urania" /> He wrote: {{blockquote|It is a beautiful night in May. Hopefully, we look out over the darkness of the sea, which is as smooth as a mirror; there emerges all around in various places a flashlike bundle of light beams, as if it is surrounded by thousands of sparks, that form true bundles of fire and of other bright lighting spots, and the seemingly mirrored stars. There emerges close before us a small spot in a sharp greenish light, which becomes ever larger and larger and finally becomes a bright shining sunlike figure.<ref name="cmog invertebrates" />}}
On return to [[Dresden]], Leopold focused on his family business. In 1854 he married Caroline Riegel<ref name="heraldica"/> - producing glass eyes, costume ornaments, lab equipment, and other such fancy goods and specialty items that only a master [[Lampworking|lampworker]] could accomplish.<ref name="harvard herbaria" /> However, like anyone, he did have free time, and his hobby was to make glass models of plants – as opposed to invertebrates. This would, many years later, become a base for the fabled ''Ware Collection of Blaschka Glass Models of Plants'' (otherwise known as the [[Glass Flowers]]), but, for the moment, such artistry was naught but an amusing and profitless pastime done between his various commissions.<ref name="harvard herbaria"/> Yet, unsurprisingly, given their stunning quality, this amusing hobby – itself born out of seeking consolation in nature upon his first wife's death – attracted attention. Aristocratic attention, as it turned out, specifically the eyes of Prince Camille de [[House of Rohan|Rohan]] who arranged to meet with Leopold at [[Sychrov Castle]] in 1857 - the same year that the Leopold & Caroline's son Rudolf was born.<ref name="heraldica"/> Being something of a naturalist himself, the Prince commissioned Leopold to craft 100 glass [[orchid]]s for his private collection <ref name="designmuseum" /> and, being more than a little impressed by the mastery Leopold's work, in 1862, "the prince exhibited about 100 models of orchids and other exotic plants, which he displayed on two artificial tree trunks in his palace in Prague,"<ref name="cmog invertebrates"/><ref name="heraldica"/> a fateful act which brought the skill of the Blaschkas to the attention of another - man whom the Prince had actually once introduced to Leopold: a certain Professor [[Ludwig Reichenbach]].<ref name="sciencefriday" />
[[File:Blaschka 1.jpg|thumb|right|Blaschka model of sea anemones]]
The director of the natural history museum in Dresden, Prof. Reichenbach, was enchanted by the botanical models and positive that Leopold held the key to ending his own inability to properly showcase marine invertebrates, for in the 19th century the only practiced method of showcasing them was to take a live specimen and place it in a sealed jar of alcohol.<ref name="cmog archive" /> This of course killed it but, more importantly, time and their lack of hard parts eventually rendered them into little more than colorless floating blobs of jelly. Neither pretty nor a terribly effective teaching tool, the Dresden museum director desired something more, specifically 3D colored models of marine invertebrates that were both lifelike and able to stand the test of time<ref name="harvard herbaria"/> and thus, in 1863<ref name="urania" /> Reichenbach convinced and commissioned Leopold to produce twelve model [[sea anemone]]s.<ref name="designmuseum" /><ref name="sciencefriday" /><ref name="berlin" /> These marine models, hailed as "an artistic marvel in the field of science and a scientific marvel in the field of art,"<ref name="wales" /> were a great improvement on previous methods of presenting such creatures: drawings, pressing, photographs and [[papier-mâché]] or wax models.<ref name="urania" />
Knowing this and thrilled with his newly acquired set of glass sea creatures, Reichenbach advised Leopold to drop his current and generations long family business of glass fancy goods and the like in favor of selling glass marine invertebrates to museums, aquaria, universities, and private collectors<ref name="urania" /><ref name="designmuseum" /> - advice which prompted the swiftly and highly lucrative mail-order business that followed. Indeed, "the world had never seen anything quite like the beautiful, scientifically accurate Blaschka models"<ref name="atlasobscura" /> and yet they were available via so common a means as via mail-order per one's local card catalog. Not glorious, perhaps, but highly effective, and museums and universities began purchasing them en masse to put on display much as Prof. Reichenbach had - for natural history museum directors the world over had the same marine invertebrate showcasing problem.<ref name="cmog invertebrates"/> In short, Blaschkas Glass sea creature mail-order enterprise succeeded for two reasons: 1- there was a huge and global demand; 2- they were the only and best glass artists capable of crafting literally scientifically flawless models. Initially the designs for these were based on drawings in books, but Leopold was soon able to use his earlier drawings to produce highly detailed models of other species,<ref name="urania" /> and his reputation quickly spread; the task additionally furthering the training of his son and apprentice (and eventual successor), Rudolf Blaschka.<ref name="designmuseum" /> Indeed, a year after the success of the glass sea anemones, the family moved to family moved to [[Dresden]] to give young Rudolf better educational opportunities.<ref name="urania" />
== Belgium ==
In 1886, [[Edouard Van Beneden]], founder of the Institute of Zoology, ordered 77 Blaschka models in order to illustrate zoology lessons. Some of these models are still on display at TréZOOr, in the Aquarium-Muséum in [[Liège]].<ref>[http://aquarium-museum.uliege.be/en/a-decouvrir/museum/trezoor/ TréZOOr Museum]</ref>
==Contact with Harvard== [[File:GlassFlowers1HMNH.jpg|thumb|left|Part of the Harvard Glass Flowers collection]] In about 1880, Rudolf began assisting his father with the models. In that year, they produced 131 Glass sea creature models for the [[Boston, Massachusetts|Boston]] Society of Natural History Museum (now the [[Museum of Science (Boston)|Museum of Science]]). These models, along with the ones purchased by [[Harvard University|Harvard's]] [[Museum of Comparative Zoology]], were seen by Professor [[George Lincoln Goodale]], who was in the process of setting up the [[Harvard Botanical Museum]]. In 1886 the Blaschkas were approached by Goodale, who had come to Dresden for the sole purpose of finding them, with a request to make a series of glass botanical models for Harvard; some reports claim that Goodale saw a few glass orchids in the room where they met, surviving from the work two decades earlier.<ref name="schultes" /> Leopold was unwilling as his current business of selling Glass sea creatures was hugely successful but, eventually, the famed glass artists agreed to send test-models to the U.S. and, although badly damaged by U.S. [[Customs]],<ref name="cmog flowers" /> Goodale nonetheless appreciated the fragmentary craftwork and showed them widely – convinced that Blaschka glass art was a more than worthy educational investment. His reasons for wanting the models was simple: At that time, Harvard was the global center of botanical study. As such, Goodale wanted the best, but the only used method was showcasing pressed and carefully labeled specimens — a methodology that offered a twofold problem: being pressed, the specimens were two-dimensional and tended to lose their color. Hence they were hardly the ideal teaching tools.<ref name="harvard flowers"/><ref name="goodale" /> However, having already seen Harvard's recently procured glass marine invertebrates, Professor Goodale - like Professor Reichenbach before him - realized that glass flowers would solve his problem<ref name="goodale" /> – for, as glass, they were three-dimensional and would retain their color.
[[File:Glass Flowers gift-bouquet.jpg|thumb|right|A photo of the bouquet of glass flowers which, in 1889, Leopold Blaschka made and gifted to Elizabeth C. and Mary L. Ware which, at some later date, was given to Harvard and is now part of the Glass Flowers exhibit.<ref>Rossi-Wilcox, Susan M. "A Brief History of Harvard's Glass Flowers Collection and Its Development." Journal of Glass Studies (2015): 197-211.</ref>]]
Investments require funds, and to cover the expensive enterprise Goodale approached his former student [[Mary Lee Ware]] and her mother [[Elizabeth Cabot (Lee) Ware|Elizabeth C. Ware]]; they were independently wealthy and already liberal benefactors of Harvard's botanical department.<ref name="wiley" /> Mary convinced her mother to agree to underwrite the consignment of the uncannily lifelike models that enchanted them both.<ref name="schultes" /> In 1887 the Blaschkas contracted to spend half-time producing the models for Harvard.<ref name="emison"/> They continued to spend their remaining time making marine invertebrate models. However, in 1890 the Blaschkas insisted that it was impossible to craft the botanical models for half the year and the sea creatures the other half; "they said that they must give up either one or the other."<ref name="iiif.lib.harvard.edu">Annual reports of the President and Treasurer of Harvard College 1890-1891, pp. 160-163 - https://iiif.lib.harvard.edu/manifests/view/drs:427018526$1i</ref> As such, that same year the Blaschkas signed an exclusive ten-year contract with Harvard to make [[Glass Flowers|glass flowers]] for 8,800 marks per year.<ref name="emison" /> New arrangements were also made to send the models directly to Harvard, where museum staff could open them safely, observed by Customs staff.<ref name="schultes" /> They modeled a great range of plants (finally, 164 taxonomic families) and plant parts (flowers, leaves, fruits, roots). Some were shown during [[pollination]] by insects, others diseased in various ways.<ref name="urania" /> Prof. Goodale noted that the activity of the Blaschkas was "greatly increased by their exclusive devotion to a single a single line of work."<ref name="iiif.lib.harvard.edu">Annual reports of the President and Treasurer of Harvard College 1890-1891, pp. 160-163 - https://iiif.lib.harvard.edu/manifests/view/drs:427018526$1i</ref> In regards to Leopold's feelings for the Glass Flowers enterprise, and the change to it from the successful marine creature business, Goodale wrote the following in the ''Annual reports of the President and Treasurer of Harvard College 1890-1891'': {{blockquote|It has been only within a comparatively short time that I have discovered the cause of the great reluctance of the elder Blaschka to the undertaking at the outset. It appears upon inquiry that he had constructed a few models of plants before beginning the preparation of the animal models to which he owes his wide celebrity; but these models of plants were, he thought, not appreciated by the persons for whom he had made them. The first set of models passed through various vicissitudes, and finally found a home in the Natural History Museum in [[Liege]], where they were at last destroyed by fire. The artist did not have courage to undertake the experiment again, when he was succeeding so well with his animal models. He regards it as a pleasant turn in his fortunes which permits him to devote all of his time to the subject of his earliest studies.<ref name="iiif.lib.harvard.edu">Annual reports of the President and Treasurer of Harvard College 1890-1891, pp. 160-163 - https://iiif.lib.harvard.edu/manifests/view/drs:427018526$1i</ref>}}
==Production of the Glass Flowers== Early in the making of the Glass Flowers, Mary Lee Ware engaged in correspondence with Professor Goodale regarding the making of the collection, one of which contained a remark of Leopold's regarding the false rumor that secret methods were used in the making of the Glass Flowers: ''"Many people think that we have some secret apparatus by which we can squeeze glass suddenly into these forms, but it is not so. We have tact. My son Rudolf has more than I have, because he is my son, and tact increases in every generation."''<ref name="schultes" /><ref name="vitreous tract" /> On this trend, he also once said that ''"One cannot hurry glass. It will take its own time. If we try to hasten it beyond its limits, it resists and no longer obeys us. We have to humor it."''<ref>Blaschka Plants Blend Science and Artistry (NYT) - https://www.nytimes.com/1976/03/08/archives/new-jersey-pages-blaschka-plants-blend-science-and-artistry.html?_r=0</ref>
The Blaschkas used a mixture of clear and coloured glass, sometimes supported with wire, to produce their models.<ref name="emison" /> Many pieces were painted, this work being entirely given to Rudolf.<ref name="schultes" /> In order to represent plants which were not native to the Dresden area, the two studied the exotic plant collections at [[Pillnitz Palace]]<ref name="emison" /> and the [[Botanischer Garten der Technischen Universität Dresden|Dresden Botanical Garden]], and also grew some from seed sent from the United States.<ref name="emison" /> In 1892, Rudolf was sent on a trip to the [[Caribbean]] and the U.S. to study additional plants, making extensive drawings and notes.<ref name="schultes" /> At this point the number of glass models sent annually to Harvard was approximately 120.<ref name="iiif.lib.harvard.edu">Annual reports of the President and Treasurer of Harvard College 1890-1891, pp. 160-163 - https://iiif.lib.harvard.edu/manifests/view/drs:427018526$1i</ref>
[[File:GlassFlowers4HMNH.jpg|thumb|left|upright=1.2|A section of the Glass Flowers exhibit]]
Rudolf made a second trip to the U.S. in 1895. While he was overseas - and eleven years into the project - Leopold died.<ref name="schultes" /> Rudolf continued to work alone, slowing down production so as to achieve higher levels of botanical perfection.<ref name="popular science" /> By the early twentieth century, he found that he was unable to buy glass of suitably high quality, and so started making his own.<ref name="emison" /> This was confirmed by Mary Lee Ware during her 1908 visit to Rudolf in a letter she wrote to the second director of the Botanical Museum, Professor [[Oakes Ames (botanist)|Oakes Ames]].<ref name="schultes" /> This letter appears to confirm the previous statement of Leopold's regarding his son; Miss Ware writes, ''"One change in the character of his work and, consequently in the time necessary to accomplish results since I was last here, is very noteworthy.At that time...he bought most of his glass and was just beginning to make some, and his finish was in paint. Now he himself makes a large part of the glass and all the enamels, which he powders to use as paint."''<ref name="daston" /> This missive to Professor Ames was published in January 9, 1961 by the [[Harvard University Herbaria]] - Botanical Museum Leaflets, Harvard University Vol. 19, No. 6 - under the title "How Were The Glass Flowers Made?"<ref name="leaflet" /> Indeed, and in addition to funding and visiting, Mary took a fairly active role in the project's progress, going so far as to personally unpack each model<ref name="harvard ware" /><ref name="cmog botanical" /> and making arrangements for Rudolph's fieldwork in the U.S. and Jamaica<ref name="harvard ware" /><ref name="cmog botanical" /> – the purpose of such trips being to gather and study various plant specimens before returning to the old style Bohemian lamp-working table at which he (and Leopold) worked.
It should also be noted that, in 1911, Rudolf Blaschka married Frieda (whose maiden name is unknown) in a quiet wedding: "We had only a few guests but a great deal of people here had shown cordial interest...We took a four day wedding trip to visit the Ore mountains and the Zenkerhuette in Josefsthal a 200 year old glass factory where my great-grandfather was master about 130-150 years ago...we reached the remote place easily by the new railroad and we had right the last chance to see the interesting factory building. They are just going to pull it down and it will disappear". Furthermore, the couple hosted Mary L. Ware during the third of her three visits to Dresden, and they became very great friends.<ref name="harvard herbaria"/>
Rudolf continued making models for Harvard until 1938. By then aged 80, old and weary, he announced that he would retire.<ref name="life" /> Neither he nor his father had taken on an [[apprentice]], and Rudolf left no successor - he and Frieda Blaschka being childless.<ref name="urania" /> For Harvard alone, Leopold and Rudolf made approximately 4,400 models, 780 showing species at life-size, with others showing magnified details; under 75% are, as of May 21, 2016, on display at the HMNH, (the exhibit itself dedicated to [[Charles Eliot Ware|Dr. Charles Eliot Ware]], the father of Mary Ware and husband of Elizabeth Ware); the old exhibit contained 3000 models but this number was reduced for renovation purposes.<ref name="emison" /> Unlike the Glass sea creatures – "a profitable global mail-order business"<ref name="harvard flowers" /> – the Glass Flowers were commissioned solely for and are unique to Harvard.
==Legacy== [[File:The grave of Leopold, Caroline, Rudolf and Frieda Blaschka.jpg|thumb|right|upright=1.5|The grave of Leopold, Caroline, Rudolf and Frieda Blaschka]]
Over the course of their collected lives Leopold and Rudolf crafted as many as ten thousand glass marine invertebrate models in addition to the 4,400 botanical ones that are the more famous Glass Flowers.<ref>"Back to Back Bay After an Absence of Ten Years". The New York Times. June 10, 1951. p. XX17.</ref><ref>Geoffrey N. Swinney & (2008) Enchanted invertebrates: Blaschka models and other simulacra in National Museums Scotland, Historical Biology, 20:1, 39-50, DOI: 10.1080/08912960701677036 - https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/08912960701677036</ref>
Leopold and Rudolf and their spouses are buried together in the Hosterwitz cemetery in Dresden.
The Blaschka studio survived the [[Bombing of Dresden in World War II]] so, in 1993, the Corning Museum and Harvard jointly purchased the remaining Blaschka studio materials from Frieda Blaschka’s niece, Gertrud Pones.<ref>Drawing upon Nature: Studies for the Blaschkas’ Glass Models - http://www.cmog.org/publication/drawing-upon-nature-studies-blaschkas-glass-models-0</ref>
==See also== *[[Robert Brendel]] *[[Museo di storia naturale di Pisa]]

page.title: List of traditional territories of the indigenous peoples of North America

revision.comment: /* References */
revision.text: This '''list of traditional territories of the original peoples of North America''' gives an overview of the names of the indigenous "countries" of North America. In this sense, "country" refers to the name of the ''land''...the ''ground''...the ''territory'' of a nation, rather than the name of the nation ("tribe") itself. This article is only about the name for the ''land'' of a nation. For example, the traditional territory (country/land) of the Ho-Chunk (Winnebago) Nation is called ''Waaziija'', meaning "the Grand Pinery". In English, the land of an indigenous nation was historically, and sometimes still is, referred to as a "country", such as "(the) Winnebago country". Some Latinate forms exist in English such as "Iroquoia", "Huronia", and "Apacheria". The distinction between nation and land is like the French people versus the land of ''France'', the Māori people versus ''Aotearoa'', or the Saami people versus ''[[Sápmi]]'' (Saamiland). ==List of traditional territories== {| class="sortable wikitable" border="0" cellpadding="0" style="background:white; text-align:left; font-size'':95%; border-collapse'':collapse; border'':0 solid #aaa;" |- !width=35%|Autonym(s) for the traditional territoryWhen the name of a traditional territory has several possible etymologies, only one or a few English translations are given here (for example ''Ojibwewaki'' = "Land of the Record Keepers" is only one of several possibilities). For more, see the Wikipedia article for each nation and the various folk etymologies and proposed etymologies for their national name. ! class="unsortable" style="width:20%;" |Conventional or historic English monikers for the traditional territory, with various attested spellingsThough the column of conventional and historic English monikers is not meant to be a comprehensive list, and though some of the references are ephemeral, this column does give a snapshot of how the traditional territories have been spoken of in everyday English. ! style="width:14%;" |The nation affiliated with that territory ! class="unsortable" |Further information ! style="width:2%" |Wikipedia article?This column contains links to existing articles about a single nation's traditional territory. Ideally such Wikipedia articles would include a composite map which showed how each indigenous national territory is portrayed in all of these: *key maps from scholars, such as the national boundaries from the ''Handbook of North American Indians'', Alfred Kroeber's culture area maps, and Sturtevant's 1967 "Early Indian Tribes, Culture Areas, & Linguistic Stocks" map. *key maps from general sources, such as the tribal boundaries from National Geographic's ''Indians of North America'' map from 1972. *a map of all treaty lands which that nation is a party, as documented in the Royce land cession maps and the Canadian numbered treaties. *the map(s) submitted by each U.S. Indian Nation during the Indian Claims Commission. *the final ICC "judicially established" map. *the NAGPRA "area of interest" map from each U.S. Indian Nation. *a map showing the location of all former reservation lands. *a map of current reservation and trust lands. *the location of national sites and diasporic populations situated outside of those lands—for example, outlying historic villages (such as the [[Bulltown, West Virginia|Bulltown]] Lenape village in what's now West Virginia, which was never a part of Lenape treaty lands) and modern "satellite" communities (for example, the "at-large" Community Groups of the Cherokee Nation). *a map of the State Designated Tribal Statistical Area (SDTSA) for state-recognized Indian Nations. *and most importantly, "tribally-interpreted", "indigenous-approved" maps, such as the traditional territory maps from the ongoing British Columbia Treaty Process, and depictions of legendary boundaries from oral history. |- style="background:Darkgrey;" |align=center|A AAA |A AAA |A AAA |A AAA | |- |valign=top|? The Aa'ku (Acoma Pueblo) traditional territory—autonym unknown. |valign=top|Athe Acoma country,{{cite journal |first=F.W. |last=Hodge |title=Ascent of the Enchanted Mesa |work=[[The Century Magazine]] |date=May 1898 |volume=LVI |issue=1 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QnYAAAAAYAAJ&lpg=PA18}} the Acoma homeland{{cite web |url=http://www.encyclopedia.com/article-1G2-3048800041/acoma-pueblo.html |title=Acoma Pueblo |work=U*X*L Encyclopedia of Native American Tribes |publisher=Encyclopedia.com |date=2008}} |valign=top|A[[Acoma Pueblo|The Aa'ku (Acoma) Nation]] {{extent}} !{{Na}} |- |valign=top|? The A'aninin (Gros Ventre) traditional territory—autonym unknown. |valign=top|AGros Ventre country,{{cite book |first=Loretta |last=Fowler |title=The Civilization Strategy: Gros Ventre, Northern and Southern Arapahos Compared |editor-last=DeMallie |editor-first=Raymond J. |work=North American Indian Anthropology: Essays on Society and Culture |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FFnaBwUIMdMC&pg=PA223 |year=1994 |publisher=VNR AG |isbn=978-0-8061-2614-2}} the Gros Ventre country,{{cite book |first=Adolf |last=Hungry Wolf |title=Memories of James Boy |work=The Blackfoot Papers Volume Four: Pikunni Biographies |publisher=Good Medicine Foundation |date=2006 |p=991 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5cypuD_j91wC&pg=PA991 |isbn=978-0-920698-86-0}} the Gros Ventre homeland{{cite web |url=http://www.fofweb.com/History/MainPrintPage.asp?iPin=AIW167&DataType=Indian&WinType=Free |title=Facts On File History Database Center |publisher=Fofweb.com |date= |accessdate=2015-05-16 |subscription=yes}} |valign=top|A[[Gros Ventre|The A'aninin (Gros Ventre) Nation]] {{extent}}See also ''Niitsitpiis-stahkoii'', the traditional territory of the wider Blackfoot Confederacy. !{{Na}} |- |valign=top|? French: ''l'Anishinabe Aki''. "The [[Nishnawbe Aski Nation|Nishnawbe Aski]] territory" refers to the land of the amalgamated national identity which was formed in 1983 by the OjiCree-, Ojibway-, Cree-, and Algonquin-speaking bands which were party to the two treaties which cover Northern Ontario.{{cite web |url=http://www.nan.on.ca/article/about-us-3.asp |title=Nishnawbe Aski Nation - About Us |publisher=Nan.on.ca |date= |accessdate=2015-05-16}} See also the entries for ''Ojibwewaki'' (Ojibwa country), ''Bodéwadmiakiwen'' (Potawatomi country), and Omàmiwininiwak (Algonquin) traditional territory. !{{Na}} |- |valign=top|? Francisco Lypez de Gуmara |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=2015-05-16}} !{{Na}} |- | valign="top" |'''Chikashsha Yakni''', '''Chikasha yakni'''{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EsfXxhnvy0IC&lpg=PA366&ots=h5VentXKfl&dq=%22chikasha%20yakni%22&pg=PA366#v=onepage&q=%22chikasha%20yakni%22&f=false |title=Chikasha Okla i Kvnstitushvn Micha i Nan Vlhpisa |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=2015-05-16}} ("Land of Chicksa") |valign=top|AChickasaw Country,{{cite web |url=http://chickasawcountry.com/explore |title=Things To Do In Oklahoma : Visit the Chickasaw Nation |publisher=Chickasawcountry.com |date= |accessdate=2015-05-16}} the Chickasaw country{{cite web |url=https://www.loc.gov/item/2007630424 |title=Map of the Chickasaw country : and contiguous portions of the Indian Territory / | Library of Congress |publisher=Loc.gov |date= |accessdate=2015-05-16}} |valign=top|A[[Chickasaw|The Chikashsha (Chickasaw) Nation]] {{extent}}In Chickasaw legend, "Chicksa" is the name of the second man to come out of the earth.{{cite web |url=https://chickasaw.net/Our-Nation/History/Prehistoric.aspx |title=The Official Site of the Chickasaw Nation | Prehistoric |publisher=Chickasaw.net |date= |accessdate=2015-05-16}} !{{Na}} |- | valign="top" |'''Denendeh''' ("Land of the People") | valign="top" |Athe Dene country{{cite web |author= |url=http://sarahontheroad.com/2012/03/dene-hand-games/ |title=Dene Hand Games… |publisher=Sarahontheroad.com |date=2012-03-18 |accessdate=2015-05-16}} | valign="top" |AThe ''Dene'' name has two primary meanings: * 1) an identity which encompasses six ethno-linguistic communities: the [[Dehcho First Nations|Dehcho (South Slavey) Nation]], [[Chipewyan people|Dënesųłiné (Chipewyan) Nation]], [[Gwich'in|Dinjii Zhuu (Gwich'in) Nation]], [[Sahtu|Sahtúot’ine (North Slavey) Nation]], [[Yellowknives|T'atsaot'ine (Yellowknives) Nation]], and [[Tli Cho|Tłı̨chǫ (Dogrib) Nation]]. These six historic nations—or at least those portions dwelling in the Northwest Territories—prefer to be called the ''Dene Nation''.[http://www.denenation.com/dene_declaration.html ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130906023851/http://www.denenation.com/dene_declaration.html |date=September 6, 2013 }} * 2) In a wider sense, the name ''[[Dene]]'' encompasses all of the [[Northern Athabaskan]] peoples of Canada and Alaska. {{extent}}The name "Denendeh", though now confined to the NWT, could conceivably be employed as a supra-national name for all the Northern Athabaskan traditional territories as a whole, in a similar way that "Anishinaabewaki" transcends modern political boundaries. See also ''Tłı̨chǫ Ndè'' (Dogrib country). !{{Na}} |- | valign="top" |'''Diné Bikéyah''' ("Land of the People"), '''Naabeehó Bikéyah''',[[Navajo Nation#Name]] '''Dinétah''' ("Among the People") | valign="top"|ANavajoland,{{cite web |url=http://discovernavajo.com/ |title=Home |publisher=Discovernavajo.com |date= |accessdate=2015-05-16}} the Navajo country{{cite web |url=http://www.abebooks.com/book-search/title/military-campaigns-navajo-country-northwestern-new-mexico-1800-1846/page-1/ |title=Military Campaigns Navajo Country Northwestern New Mexico 1800 1846 |publisher=AbeBooks |date= |accessdate=2015-05-16}} | valign="top"|A[[Navajo people|The Diné (Navajo) Nation]] {{extent}}In contrast to ''Diné Bikéyah'', the name ''Dinétah'' can refer specifically to the original homeland, in contrast to the wider territory which resulted from the Navajos' westerly expansion in historic times. The name ''Naabeehó Bináhásdzo'' refers to the Navajo reservation jurisdiction and its political government. !{{yes|[[Dinétah|(link)]]}} |- |valign=top|'''Dule Nega''',{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Vom2AgAAQBAJ&lpg=PT128&ots=HCh0VgXXhL&dq=dulenega%20kuna&pg=PT128#v=onepage&q=dulenega%20kuna&f=false |title=Plants and Animals in the Life of the Kuna - Jorge Ventocilla, Heraclio Herrera, Valerio Núńez |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=2015-05-16}} '''Dulenega''',{{cite web |author=Emilio del Valle Escalante |url=http://www.e-ir.info/2014/05/20/self-determination-a-perspective-from-abya-yala/ |title=Self-Determination: A Perspective from Abya Yala |publisher=E-ir.info |date=2014-05-20 |accessdate=2015-05-16}} '''Tulenega'''{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EGRVxZ0ZAt8C&lpg=PA119&ots=R4WpIRFeNa&dq=tulenega&pg=PA119#v=onepage&q=tulenega&f=false |title=Aboriginal Peoples: Toward Self-government - Marie Léger |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=2015-05-16}} ("House of the People"), '''Guna Yala''', '''Kuna Yala''' ("Land of the Kuna") |valign=top|Athe Kuna homeland,{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=sctUJHkFyk0C&lpg=PA206&ots=ZvzyJYmysf&dq=%22kuna%20homeland%22&pg=PA206#v=onepage&q=%22kuna%20homeland%22&f=false |title=Conservation: Linking Ecology, Economics, and Culture - Monique Borgerhoff Mulder, Peter Coppolillo |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=2015-05-16}} the Kuna country,{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=E6iP-owdJHYC&lpg=PA247&ots=3NwOG2zbI7&dq=%22the%20kuna%20country%22&pg=PA247#v=onepage&q=%22the%20kuna%20country%22&f=false |title=Scientifiction - A. Other nations, such as the [[Tuscarora people|Tuscarora Nation]], were adopted by the Haudenosaunee in historic times. {{extent}}French: ''Pays des Iroquois''.{{cite web |author=Jacques Nicolas Bellin |url=http://www.maremagnum.com/stampe/partie-occidentale-de-la-nouvelle-france-ou-du-canada/116883979 |title=Partie occidentale de la nouvelle france ou du canada | 979 |publisher=Maremagnum.com |date= |accessdate=2015-05-17}} ''Haudenosauneega'' or ''Aquanishuonigy'' is traditionally composed of five "countries": 1) "Aquanishuonigy proper" (the traditional territories of the Five Nations in Ontario).{{cite web |url=https://www.loc.gov/resource/g3710.ar071500/ |title=A general map of the middle British colonies in America | Library of Congress |publisher=Loc.gov |date= There were several other, more obscure member nations in the early historic period. {{extent}}French: ''Pays des Illinois'' (not to be confused with the French political territory of the [[Illinois Country]] which was named after the indigenous traditional territory). The original meaning of the autonym ''Inoca'', ''Inoka'' is presently unknown.{{cite web |author= |url=http://www.press.uillinois.edu/wordpress/?p=1521 |title=Illinois Place Name of the Day – November 3, 2008 |publisher=Press.uillinois.edu |date=2008-11-03 |accessdate=2015-05-17}} !{{Na}} |- |valign=top|'''Inuit Nunaat'''{{cite web |url=https://www.itk.ca/front-page-story/circumpolar-inuit-declaration-arctic-sovereignty |title=Circumpolar Inuit Declaration on Arctic Sovereignty | Inuit Tapiriit Kanatami - Canada's National Inuit Organization |publisher=Itk.ca |date=2008-11-07 |accessdate=2015-05-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150518111337/https://www.itk.ca/front-page-story/circumpolar-inuit-declaration-arctic-sovereignty |archivedate=2015-05-18 |df= }} ("Land of the People") |valign=top|Athe Inuit homeland,{{cite web |url=http://inuitcircumpolar.com/index.php?ID=374&Lang=En |accessdate=July 16, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140706165800/http://www.inuitcircumpolar.com/index.php?ID=374&Lang=En |archivedate=July 6, 2014}} the Inuit country,{{cite web |url=http://www.yale.edu/ynhti/curriculum/units/1991/2/91.02.07.x.html |title=91.02.07: The Inuit Family: A study of its history, beliefs, and images |publisher=Yale.edu |date= |accessdate=2015-05-17}} the Eskimo country{{cite web |url=http://content.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,799209,00.html |title=Cinema: Old Master - TIME |publisher=Content.time.com |date=1948-09-20 |accessdate=2015-05-17}} |valign=top|A[[Inuit|The Inuit (Eskimo) Nation]] ''"We Eskimo are an international community sharing common language, culture, and a common land along the Arctic coast of Siberia, Alaska, Canada and Greenland. Although not a nation-state, as a people, we do constitute a nation."'' —Inuit Circumpolar Council-Alaska{{cite web |url=http://www.iccalaska.org/servlet/content/the_beginning.html |title=ICC's Beginning |publisher=Iccalaska.org |date= |accessdate=2015-05-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150706171659/http://www.iccalaska.org/servlet/content/the_beginning.html |archivedate=2015-07-06 |df= }} {{extent}}''Inuit Nunaat'' is used by the international Inuit Circumpolar Council; for example in the April 2009 "Circumpolar Inuit Declaration on Sovereignty in the Arctic."{{cite web |url=http://www.iccalaska.org/servlet/download?id=15 |title=A Circumpolar Inuit Declaration on Sovereignty in the Arctic |publisher=Iccalaska.org |accessdate=2015-05-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150316114339/http://www.iccalaska.org/servlet/download?id=15 |archivedate=2015-03-16 |df= }} Two months later, in June 2009, the Canadian-sponsored Inuit organization changed the name of the specifically Canadian Inuit regions from ''Inuit Nunaat'' to ''Inuit Nunangat''{{cite web|url=https://www.itk.ca/publication/maps-inuit-nunangat-inuit-regions-canada |title=Maps of Inuit Nunangat (Inuit Regions of Canada) | Inuit Tapiriit Kanatami - Canada's National Inuit Organization |publisher=Itk.ca |date=2009-06-10 |accessdate=2015-05-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150518111355/https://www.itk.ca/publication/maps-inuit-nunangat-inuit-regions-canada |archivedate=2015-05-18 |df= }} ("The People's Land, Water, and Ice").{{cite web |url=http://www.goodreads.com/book/show/3663770-inuit-nunangat-the-people-s-land |title=Inuit Nunangat The People's Land: A Struggle for Survival by John Amagoalik — Reviews, Discussion, Bookclubs, Lists |publisher=Goodreads.com |date=2008-07-06 |accessdate=2015-05-17}} The four Canadian Inuit regions are the [[Inuvialuit Settlement Region]] (Northwest Territories and Northern Yukon), [[Nunavut]] ("Our Land"), [[Nunavik]] ("Great Land", Northern Quebec), and [[Nunatsiavut]] ("Our Beautiful Land", Northern Labrador). There is also [[NunatuKavut]] ("Our Ancient Land"), the traditional territory of the [[NunatuKavut people|NunatuKavummuit]] (Inuit-Metis) of southern Labrador. There are seven [[Alaskan Native Corporation]]s (see ANC link for map) which are predominantly Inuit in composition: [[Arctic Slope Regional Corporation]], [[NANA Regional Corporation]], [[Bering Straits Native Corporation]], [[Calista Corporation]], [[Bristol Bay Native Corporation]], [[Koniag, Incorporated|Koniag, Inc.]], and [[Chugach Alaska Corporation]]. The existing Inuit-affiliated political divisions and regional corporations only partially reflect the traditional cultural and linguistic diversity of the Inuitic peoples.[[Inuit languages#Geographic distribution and variants]] For example, the boundaries of the Danish political entity ''[[Kalaallit Nunaat]]'' are bigger than the traditional territory of the [[Kalaallit]] proper (West Greenland Inuit). There are two other Inuitic peoples in Greenland: the [[Tunumiit]] (East Greenland Inuit), who live in ''[[Tunu]]''[[Tunu]] and the [[Inughuit]] (Polar Eskimos) of [[Avannaa|North Greenland]]. !{{Na}} |- |valign=top|'''Jiwére Máyan''', '''Wadodana Máya'''n{{cite web |url=https://sites.google.com/site/threefoldnow/traditional-territories |title=traditional territories - Threefold Now |publisher=Sites.google.com |date= |accessdate=2015-05-17}} ("Land of the Otoes") |valign=top|AOtoe country,{{cite web |url=http://archiver.rootsweb.ancestry.com/th/read/NORCAL/1999-11/0941477605 |title=RootsWeb: NORCAL-L Re: Fw: Story of the Murphy Party - Part I |publisher=Archiver.rootsweb.ancestry.com |date= |accessdate=2015-05-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151208045256/http://archiver.rootsweb.ancestry.com/th/read/NORCAL/1999-11/0941477605 |archivedate=2015-12-08 |df= }} the Otoe country,{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UNYRAAAAYAAJ&lpg=PA141&ots=_x3u-IXFVJ&dq=%22otoe%20country%22&pg=PA141#v=onepage&q=%22otoe%20country%22&f=false |title=Annual Report of the Commissioner of Indian Affairs - United States. So ''Nēhiýānāhk'' serves as a default name for Cree country as a whole, in a similar way that ''Anishinaabewaki'' is based on an Ojibwe spelling, but serves as common name for the entire supra-national Aninishinaabe traditional territory. The traditional territory of the East Crees is called [[Eeyou Istchee (territory)|''Eeyou Istchee'']] and ''Iynu Asci'' ("Land of the People"). ''Eeyou'' or ''Iyyu'' is the spelling in northern East Cree, while ''Iynu'' in southern East Cree. The traditional territory of the Plains Cree in particular is ''Paskwāwiýinīnāhk'' ("In the Land of the Plains Cree"). !{{Na}} |- |valign=top|'''Newe Segobia'''{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=eu5cxvjC3pwC&lpg=PA180&ots=TREw41Ap_h&dq=newe%20sogobia%20earth%20mother&pg=PA180#v=onepage&q=newe%20sogobia%20earth%20mother&f=false |title=Water Follies: Groundwater Pumping and the Fate of America's Fresh Waters - Robert Jerome Glennon |publisher=Books.google.com |date=2004-01-14 |accessdate=2015-05-17}} ("The People's Earth Mother") |valign=top|AWestern Shoshone country,{{cite web |url=http://www.nativeweb.org/pages/legal/shoshone/pamphlet.html |title=How To Kill A Nation |publisher=Nativeweb.org |date=1991-09-05 |accessdate=2015-05-17}} the Western Shoshone homeland,{{cite web |author= |url=http://indiancountrytodaymedianetwork.com/2002/06/01/western-shoshone-fight-87803 |title=The Western Shoshone fight on - ICTMN.com |publisher=Indiancountrytodaymedianetwork.com |date= |accessdate=2015-05-17}} Newe Country,{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ohQOAQAAMAAJ&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=newe+country |title=The State of Native America: Genocide, Colonization, and Resistance - M. O'odham bands are now broken up into 4 federally recognized tribes: the Tohono O'odham Nation, the Gila River Indian Community, the Ak-Chin Indian Community and the Salt River (Pima Maricopa) Indian community."'' (quote from the Tohono O'odham Nation website){{cite web |url=http://www.tonation-nsn.gov/history_culture.aspx |title=Tohono O'odham Nation - History & Culture |publisher=Tonation-nsn.gov |date= |accessdate=2015-05-17}} In contrast to the entire traditional territory, ''O'odham ha-jeweḍga'' refers to the political Tohono O'odham Indian Reservation. ''Tohono'' ("Desert") is the O'odham name for the [[Tohono O'odham|Tohono O'odham (Pagago)]] portion of ''O'odham Jeweḍ''. The Spanish name for this portion is ''Papaguería'', which has also been used in English. The name "Tohono country", "the tohono jewed",{{cite web |url=http://desertmusingsbytbyrd.blogspot.com/2005/09/hang-right-tallest-cactus.html |title=Desert Musings: Hang a right @ the tallest cactus |publisher=Desertmusingsbytbyrd.blogspot.com |date=2005-09-16 |accessdate=2015-05-17}} "Papago country",{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Z_bBEE5mVAsC&lpg=PA76&dq=%22in%20papago%20country%22&pg=PA76#v=onepage&q=%22in%20papago%20country%22&f=false |title=Of Earth and Little Rain: The Papago Indians - Bernard L. The Wah-Zha-Zhi (Osage) traditional territory—autonym unknown. | valign="top"|AOsage country,{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pGiln6g3MoIC&lpg=PA281&ots=smq8Aso9Wd&dq=%22in%20osage%20country%22&pg=PA281#v=onepage&q=%22in%20osage%20country%22&f=false |title=Daniel Boone: The Life and Legend of an American Pioneer - John Mack Faragher |publisher=Books.google.com |date=1993-11-15 |accessdate=2015-05-17}} the Osage country,[https://digital.library.okstate.edu/chronicles/v033/v033p145.pdf ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110523222151/https://digital.library.okstate.edu/chronicles/v033/v033p145.pdf |date=May 23, 2011 }} the great Osage homeland,{{cite web |url=http://www.osageac.org/index.php/aboutus/history/ |title=History : Osage Arts Community |publisher=Osageac.org |date= |accessdate=2015-05-17}} the Osage homelands, the Osage ancestral territory{{cite web |url=http://apps.fcc.gov/ecfs/document/view?id=7521065310 |title=Osage Nation Consultation for Positive Train Control |publisher=Apps.fcc.gov |accessdate=2015-05-17}} | valign="top"|A[[Osage (people)|The Wah-Zha-Zhi (Osage) Nation]] {{extent}}In the Skiri Pawnee language: ''Pasaasiru'' ("among the Osages; in Osage territory"). !{{Na}} |- |valign=top|'''Washeshu Itdeh''',{{cite web |url=https://www.washoetribe.us/contents/ |title=Washoe Tribe - Home |publisher=Washoetribe.us |date= |accessdate=2015-05-17}} '''Wa She Shu E Deh'''''Wa She Shu: A Washo Tribal History'' by Inter-Tribal Council of Nevada, 1976. ("The People from Here") |valign=top|AWašiw lands, Washoe country,{{cite web |author=Michael Makley, Matthew Makley |url=https://muse.jhu.edu/books/9780874178487 |title=Project MUSE - Cave Rock |publisher=Muse.jhu.edu |date=2007-08-27 |accessdate=2015-05-17}} the Washoe country{{cite web |last=Edwards |first=Jerome |url=http://www.onlinenevada.org/articles/pyramid-lake-war |title=Pyramid Lake War | ONE |publisher=Onlinenevada.org |date=2011-01-18 |accessdate=2015-05-17}} |valign=top|A[[Washoe people|The Wašiw (Washoe) Nation]] {{extent}} !{{Na}} |- |valign=top|'''Wazija Haci'''{{cite web |url=http://www.ho-chunkgaming.com/wisconsindells/images/06-dining/SunriseBreakfastMenu.pdf |format=PDF |title=Sunrise Cliffs Cafe : Breakfast Menu |publisher=Ho-chunkgaming.com |accessdate=2015-05-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150226072455/http://www.ho-chunkgaming.com/wisconsindells/images/06-dining/SunriseBreakfastMenu.pdf |archivedate=2015-02-26 |df= }} ("Those who dwell in the pines"), '''Wazija''',{{cite web |url=http://www.hotcakencyclopedia.com/ho.Wazija.html |title=The Wazidja |publisher=Hotcakencyclopedia.com |date=1986-03-05 |accessdate=2015-05-17}} '''Wazidja''',{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mI_U7aIsvj0C&lpg=PA142&ots=egitFJuBU8&dq=wazidja&pg=PA142#v=onepage&q=wazidja&f=false |title=History - Kate Morris |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=2015-05-17}} '''Waazija'''{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nwUaAwAAQBAJ&lpg=PT217&ots=OcfnAE7hQ0&dq=waazija&pg=PT217#v=onepage&q=waazija&f=false |title=Hocak Teaching Materials, Volume 1: Elements of Grammar/Learner's Dictionary |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=2015-05-17}} ("The Grand Pinery") |valign=top|Athe Wazija, the Wazidja, the Hočąk Wazija, the land of the Hočągara, Ho-Chunk country,[http://www.uwalumni.com/weight_words.aspx] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140720080621/http://www.uwalumni.com/weight_words.aspx |date=July 20, 2014 }} Winnebago country,{{cite web |url=http://museum.unl.edu/education/pdf/UNSMWinnebagoGuide.pdf |format=PDF |title=Winnebago Teachers Guide |publisher=Museum.unl.edu |accessdate=2015-05-17}} the Winnebago country,{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OIcFAAAAQAAJ&lpg=RA2-PA13&ots=LyHuB0sNyY&dq=%22winnebago%20country%22&pg=RA2-PA13#v=onepage&q=%22winnebago%20country%22&f=false |title=House Documents, Otherwise Publ. as Executive Documents: 13th Congress, 2d ... - United States. Congress. House |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=2015-05-17}} the Winnebago homeland{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=72jgsHZv2oIC&lpg=PA17&ots=J0IPzdZGQy&dq=%22winnebago%20homeland%22&pg=PA17#v=onepage&q=%22winnebago%20homeland%22&f=false |title=Always a People: Oral Histories of Contemporary Woodland Indians - Rita T. Kohn, William Lynwood Montell |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=2015-05-17}} |valign=top|A[[Ho-Chunk|The Ho-Chunk (Winnebago) Nation]] {{extent}}An early French name: ''pays des Puants''.{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=h88BAAAAMAAJ&lpg=PA138&ots=j8F9O2ScFJ&dq=%22pays%20des%20puants%22&pg=PA138#v=onepage&q=%22pays%20des%20puants%22&f=false |title=Notre histoire: Québec-Canada - Jacques Lacoursiere, Claude Bouchard, Richard Howard |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=2015-05-17}} !{{Na}} |- |valign=top|'''Wendake'''{{cite web |author=C.E. Heidenreich |url=http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/huronia/ |title=Wendake (Huronia) - The Canadian Encyclopedia |publisher=Thecanadianencyclopedia.ca |date= |accessdate=2015-05-17}} ("The Land Apart") |valign=top|AHuronia,{{cite web |url=http://wyandotofanderdon.com/OldSite/index.html |title=Wyandot of Anderdon |publisher=Wyandot of Anderdon |date=2014-03-15 |accessdate=2015-05-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150710025237/http://wyandotofanderdon.com/OldSite/index.html |archivedate=2015-07-10 |df= }} the Huron country,{{cite web |url=http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/07565a.htm |title=CATHOLIC ENCYCLOPEDIA: Huron Indians |publisher=Newadvent.org |date=1910-06-01 |accessdate=2015-05-17}} the Wyandot country,{{cite web |url=http://www.legendsofkansas.com/wyandotindians2.html |title=The Wyandot Indians of Kansas - Page 2 |publisher=Legendsofkansas.com |date= |accessdate=2015-05-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150613231147/http://www.legendsofkansas.com/wyandotindians2.html |archivedate=2015-06-13 |df= }} Wyandotte country,{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VVNHAQAAIAAJ&lpg=PA366&ots=z9CZi8EsE_&dq=%22wyandotte%20country%22%20indians&pg=PA366#v=onepage&q=%22wyandotte%20country%22%20indians&f=false |title=Congressional Series of United States Public Documents |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=2015-05-17}} the Wyandotte country,{{cite web |url=http://www.wyandotte-nation.org/culture/history/wpa-interviews/john-bland/ |title=John Bland |publisher=Wyandotte-nation.org |date= |accessdate=2015-05-17}} the Wendat country,{{cite web |url=http://h-france.net/fffh/the-buzz/boyden-the-orienda/ |title=Hurons and Jesuits Revisited: Joseph Boyden’s The Orenda | Fiction and Film for French Historians |publisher=H-france.net |date=2014-04-07 |accessdate=2015-05-17}} the Huron-Wendat country,{{cite web |author=C.E. Heidenreich |url=http://thecanadianencyclopedia.com/en/article/huronia/ |title=Wendake (Huronia) |publisher=The Canadian Encyclopedia |date= |accessdate=2015-05-17}} Old Huronia{{cite web |url=https://archive.org/stream/wendakeehenorold00jones/wendakeehenorold00jones_djvu.txt |title=Full text of ""Wendake Ehen"; or, Old Huronia" |publisher=Archive.org |date= |accessdate=2015-05-17}} (=''Wendake Ehen'') |valign=top|A[[Wyandot people|The Wendat (Wyandot/Huron) Nation]] {{extent}}French: ''la Huronie'',[[:fr:Huronie]] ''le pays des Hurons'', ''Contrée des Hurons''. In the Abenaki language: ''Ksitegwiiak'' ("Land of the Hurons"). Unlike the Huron-Wendat in Quebec, the three Wendat groups in the U.S. trace their origin to the Tionontati (Petun/Tobacco), Wenro, and Neutral nations, and to only one of the original Huron nations (the Attignawantan nation), rather to the Huron Confederacy as a whole.{{cite web |url=http://www.wyandotte-nation.org/culture/history/ |title=History |publisher=Wyandotte-nation.org |date= |accessdate=2015-05-17}} !{{yes|[[Huronia (region)|(link)]]}} |- |valign=top|'''Wintʰu· Po·m''' ("Land of the People") |valign=top|AWintu country{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=I6b6EEE1YlIC&pg=PA339&lpg=PA339&dq=%22wintu+country%22&source=bl&ots=EVUqIUWRo4&sig=65ys5c0Cfy1_uqAlJZqpMmTYGg8&hl=en&sa=X&ei=ejKrU-bABs6NqAbt0YGYCw&ved=0CB8Q6AEwAA |title=Handbook of North American Indians: California - William C. Sturtevant |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=2015-05-17}} |valign=top|A[[Wintu people|The Wintu Nation]] {{extent}}There are traditionally nine band territories, such as ''wenem memen bos'' ("the middle water place/country"), and ''nomte pom'' or ''Nom ti pom''{{cite web |url=http://stopwintufraud.blogspot.com/2008/02/wintu-bands-just-in-case-you-forgot.html |title=Stop Wintu Fraud: Wintu Bands Geography |publisher=Stopwintufraud.blogspot.com |date=2008-02-21 |accessdate=2015-05-17}} ("In the west country").{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=I6b6EEE1YlIC&lpg=PA324&ots=EVUrKWOPv7&dq=%22nomti%22%20wintu&pg=PA324#v=onepage&q=%22nomti%22%20wintu&f=false |title=Handbook of North American Indians: California - William C. Sturtevant |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=2015-05-17}} !{{Na}} |- |valign=top|'''Wolastokuk''' ("Land of the Beautiful River") |valign=top|AMaliseet country,{{cite web |author=Translated and edited by Philip S. LeSourd |url=http://www.nebraskapress.unl.edu/product/Tales-from-Maliseet-Country,673193.aspx |title=Tales from Maliseet Country - University of Nebraska Press |publisher=Nebraskapress.unl.edu |date= |accessdate=2015-05-17}} the Malecite country |valign=top|A[[Maliseet|The Wolastoqiyik (Maliseet) Nation]] {{extent}}See also ''Waponahkik'' (Wabanaki country). !{{Na}} |- |valign=top|'''X̱aaydag̱a Gwaay.yaay''',{{cite web |url=http://apps.gov.bc.ca/pub/bcgnws/names/61561.html |title=The Province of British Columbia - GeoBC |publisher=Apps.gov.bc.ca |date= |accessdate=2015-05-17}} '''Xhaaidlagha Gwaayaai''',[[Haida Gwaii#Naming]] '''Xaadala Gwayee'''{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WRCHxkQmvGIC&lpg=PT110&ots=8yU4Nlb5gt&dq=Xaadala%20Gwayee&pg=PT110#v=onepage&q=Xaadala%20Gwayee&f=false |title=The Inventor and the Tycoon: A Gilded Age Murder and the Birth of Moving ... - Edward Ball |publisher=Books.google.com |date=2013-01-22 |accessdate=2015-05-17}} ("Islands at the Edge of the World"), '''X̱aayda gwaay''', '''Haida Gwaii'''[[Haida Gwaii]] ("Islands of the People") |valign=top|AHaida country,{{cite web |author=Native Americans |url=http://what-when-how.com/native-americans/haida-native-americans-of-the-northwest-coast/ |title=Haida (Native Americans of the Northwest Coast) |publisher=What-when-how.com |date= |accessdate=2015-05-17}} the Haida homeland{{cite web |url=http://www.museevirtuel-virtualmuseum.ca/edu/ViewLoitLo.do%3Bjsessionid=533677A0495436AEAE6F17E30D75454F?method=preview&lang=EN&id=9141 |title=Haida People: Spirits of the Sea | The Haida Homeland: The History of the Haida People |publisher=Museevirtuel-virtualmuseum.ca |date= |accessdate=2015-05-17}} |valign=top|A[[Haida people|The X̱aadas (Haida) Nation]] {{extent}} !{{yes|[[Haida Gwaii|(link)]]}} |- |valign="top" |'''Yagaocanahagary'''''Handbook of North American Indians'', Volume 13 ("Land Between the Two Points") |valign="top" |APiscataway Country{{cite web |url=http://www.geni.com/people/Mary-Piscataway/6000000010189109442 |title=Mary Piscataway (Kittamaqund) (deceased) - Genealogy |publisher=Geni.com |date=2015-02-01 |accessdate=2015-05-17}} |valign="top" |A[[Piscataway tribe|The Piscataway (Conoy) Nation]] {{extent}} !{{Na}} |- |valign=top|? The Yokot'anob (Chontal) traditional territory—autonym unknown. |valign=top|Athe Chontalpa,[[Chontalpa]] the Chontal homeland{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RZxCCImjN-gC&lpg=PA111&ots=GZNsMa268u&dq=%22the%20chontal%20homeland%22&pg=PA111#v=onepage&q=%22the%20chontal%20homeland%22&f=false |title=Supplement to the Handbook of Middle American Indians, Volume 6: Ethnology |publisher=Books.google.com |date=2010-06-28 |accessdate=2015-05-17}} |valign=top|A[[Chontal Maya people|The Yokot'anob (Chontal) Nation]] {{extent}}In the Nahuatl language: ''Chontalpa'' ("Land of the Foreigners"). In Spanish: ''la Chontalpa''.[[:es:Chontalpa]] "[[Chontalpa]]" remains the name of a Mexican economic planning region coterminous with four political municipalities. !{{Na}} |- style="background:Darkgrey;" | style="text-align:center;"|ZZZZ |ZZZZ |ZZZZ |ZZZZ | |} ==Criteria for inclusion== For the purpose of this list, "nation" refers to the historic, whole national identities, rather than to the fragmented "reservation nations" or "bands". The whole nations are what John Beaucage, Grand Council Chief of the Anishinabek Nation, refers to as "true nations" in contrast with the fragmented "First Nations": {{quote box|quote = “First Nations must work towards the restoration of our own model of nationhood made up of our '''true nations'''. In essence, moving away from '''633''' '''First Nations'''—from Aamjiwnaang to Zhiibhaasing—to governance based on the nearly '''60''' '''indigenous nations''', from the Abenaki Nation to the Wendat Nation and all those in between.”|source = —John Beaucage, “A Vision of a New Assembly of First Nations” (emphasis added), 2009[https://www.straight.com/news/john-beaucage-vision-new-assembly-first-nations John Beaucage: A vision of a new Assembly of First Nations]. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140720160156/http://www.straight.com/news/john-beaucage-vision-new-assembly-first-nations |date=July 20, 2014 }}}} Or what the Government of Quebec calls "the 11 aboriginal nations of Québec" in contrast with their component "55 aboriginal communities".[http://www.autochtones.gouv.qc.ca/relations_autochtones/profils_nations/profil_en.htm Profile of the Nations]. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140726032728/http://www.autochtones.gouv.qc.ca/relations_autochtones/profils_nations/profil_en.htm |date=July 26, 2014 }} And so the criteria for inclusion is not the same as what are named "Indian tribes" by the U.S. Federal Register and the National Congress of American Indians (NCAI), or what are called "First Nations" by the Canadian government and Assembly of First Nations (AFN). It would be interesting to compile the names for the "band territories" of the 633 fragmented First Nations of the AFN, or the names of the "reservation territories" of the 632 fragmented Indian Nations of the NCAI, but that is beyond the scope of this article, except as side notes in the "further information" column. So this list does not include the names for reservations or reserves, but only of the entire national homeland (or the homeland of a confederated identity such as the Haudenosaunee Confederacy or Colville tribes). For example, this list wouldn't give the Cherokee name for the Qualla Boundary reservation, but only the name for "the Cherokee country" as a whole. Ideally a single name could conceivably encompass not only the Contact-era ancestral territory, but also any area which at some time or another was conceived to be part of the national domain, such as post-Removal lands. {{quote box|quote = "Northeastern Oklahoma is the seat of government for the sovereign nation of the Miami Tribe of Oklahoma. However, all of the lands where the Miami have lived over time are still referred to as “Myaamionki” (the Place of the Myaamia)."|source = —The Miami Tribe of Oklahoma.[http://www.miamination.com/~miamina1/newsite/node/11 Tribal Historic Preservation Office]. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140712162840/http://www.miamination.com/~miamina1/newsite/node/11 |date=July 12, 2014 }}}} The names do not have to be from olden days. The names could be recently coined and still be included in this list. Compiling a list such as this can be a difficult and controversial process, as it requires some discernment as to what are the "whole nations" — the "true nations" in Beaucage's words. ==Notes== {{Reflist|group="Note"|colwidth=30em}} ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Traditional territories of the indigenous peoples of North America}} [[Category:Human geography|North America, Traditional territories of the indigenous peoples]] [[Category:Indigenous peoples of North America]] [[Category:History of indigenous peoples of North America]] [[Category:Lists of countries in the Americas]] [[Category:Countries in North America| ]]

revision.comment: added links
added section on Kepler's Harmony of the Worlds
revision.text:
{{redirect|Music of the Spheres}} [[File:Harmonyoftheworld.jpg|thumb|right|300px|
Harmony of the world, 1806
]] '''Musica universalis''' (literally '''universal music'''), also called '''Music of the spheres''' or '''Harmony of the Spheres''', is an ancient [[philosophy|philosophical]] concept that regards proportions in the movements of [[celestial bodies]]—the [[Sun]], [[Moon]], and [[planet]]s—as a form of ''musica'' (the [[Medieval]] [[Latin]] term for [[music]]). This "music" is not usually thought to be literally audible, but a [[harmonic]], [[mathematics|mathematical]] or [[religious]] concept. The idea continued to appeal to thinkers about music until the end of the [[Renaissance]], influencing scholars of many kinds, including [[humanism|humanists]]. Further scientific exploration has determined specific proportions in some orbital motion, described as [[orbital resonance]]. == History == [[File:The music of the spheres.jpg|thumb|150px|left|Engraving from Renaissance Italy (Gafurius's ''Practica musice'', 1496) showing Apollo, the Muses, the planetary spheres and musical modes]] {{See also|Pythagoreanism#Music and harmony}} The discovery of the precise relation between the pitch of the musical note and the length of the string that produces it is attributed to Pythagoras. The Music of the Spheres incorporates the [[Metaphysics|metaphysical]] principle that mathematical relationships express qualities or "tones" of energy which manifest in numbers, visual angles, shapes and sounds – all connected within a pattern of proportion. [[Pythagoras]] first identified that the [[Pitch (music)|pitch of a musical note]] is in inverse proportion to the length of the string that produces it, and that intervals between harmonious sound frequencies form simple numerical ratios.[[#Reference-Weiss-2008|Weiss and Taruskin (2008)]] [https://books.google.com/books?id=q1eobgND8H4C&pg=PA3 p. 3]. In a theory known as the Harmony of the Spheres, Pythagoras proposed that the Sun, Moon and planets all emit their own unique hum based on their orbital revolution,[[#Reference-Pliny-77|Pliny the Elder (77)]] pp. 277–8, (II.xviii.xx): "…occasionally Pythagoras draws on the theory of music, and designates the distance between the Earth and the Moon as a whole tone, that between the Moon and Mercury as a semitone, .... the seven tones thus producing the so-called diapason, ''i.e.''. a universal harmony". and that the quality of life on Earth reflects the tenor of celestial sounds which are physically imperceptible to the human ear.[[#Reference-Houlding-2000|Houlding (2000)]] p. 28: For [[Philolaus]], mathematician and Pythagorean astronomer, working around 400 BC, the world was 'harmony and numbers'; everything is ordered according to proportions that correspond to three basic musical intervals: 2:1 (harmony), 3:2 (fifth), 4:3 (fourth). Nicomachus of Gerasa (also a Pythagorean, towards the year 200 BC) assigns the notes of the octave to the celestial bodies, so that they generate a music. "The doctrine of the Pythagoreans was a combination of science and mysticism… Like Anaximenes they viewed the Universe as one integrated, living organism, surrounded by Divine Air (or more literally 'Breath'), which permeates and animates the whole cosmos and filters through to individual creatures … By partaking of the core essence of the Universe, the individual is said to act as a microcosm in which all the laws in the macrocosm of the Universe are at work". Subsequently, Plato described astronomy and music as "twinned" studies of sensual recognition: astronomy for the eyes, music for the ears, and both requiring knowledge of numerical proportions.[[#Reference-Davis-1901|Davis (1901)]] p. 252. Plato's ''Republic'' VII.XII reads: "As the eyes, said I, seem formed for studying astronomy, so do the ears seem formed for harmonious motions: and these seem to be twin sciences to one another, as also the Pythagoreans say". [[Aristotle]] criticised the notionAristotle, On the Heavens, J.L. Stocks' translation, http://classics.mit.edu/Aristotle/heavens.2.ii.html that celestial bodies make a sound in moving in the context of his own cosmological model.
From all this it is clear that the theory that the movement of the stars produces a harmony, i.e. that the sounds they make are concordant, in spite of the grace and originality with which it has been stated, is nevertheless untrue. Some thinkers suppose that the motion of bodies of that size must produce a noise, since on our earth the motion of bodies far inferior in size and in speed of movement has that effect. Also, when the sun and the moon, they say, and all the stars, so great in number and in size, are moving with so rapid a motion, how should they not produce a sound immensely great? Starting from this argument and from the observation that their speeds, as measured by their distances, are in the same ratios as musical concordances, they assert that the sound given forth by the circular movement of the stars is a harmony. Since, however, it appears unaccountable that we should not hear this music, they explain this by saying that the sound is in our ears from the very moment of birth and is thus indistinguishable from its contrary silence, since sound and silence are discriminated by mutual contrast. What happens to men, then, is just what happens to coppersmiths, who are so accustomed to the noise of the smithy that it makes no difference to them. But, as we said before, melodious and poetical as the theory is, it cannot be a true account of the facts. There is not only the absurdity of our hearing nothing, the ground of which they try to remove, but also the fact that no effect other than sensitive is produced upon us. Excessive noises, we know, shatter the solid bodies even of inanimate things: the noise of thunder, for instance, splits rocks and the strongest of bodies. But if the moving bodies are so great, and the sound which penetrates to us is proportionate to their size, that sound must needs reach us in an intensity many times that of thunder, and the force of its action must be immense.
The three branches of the Medieval concept of musica were presented by [[Boethius]] in his book ''De Musica'':Boethius, De institutione musica, I.2 (p. 187 Friedlein ed.) * ''musica mundana'' (sometimes referred to as ''musica universalis'') * ''musica humana'' (the internal music of the human body) * ''musica quae in quibusdam constituta est instrumentis'' (sounds made by singers and instrumentalists) According to [[Max Heindel]]'s [[Rosicrucian]] writings, the heavenly "music of the spheres" is heard in the ''Region of Concrete Thought'', the lower region of the [[mental plane]], which is an ocean of harmony.{{citation needed|date=August 2011}} == Harmonices Mundi == ''See also: [[Harmonices Mundi]]'' M''usica universalis'', which had existed since the Greeks, as a metaphysical concept was often taught in [[quadrivium]],{{Cite journal|last=Voelkel|first=J. R.|date=1994|title=The music of the heavens: Kepler's harmonic astronomy|url=|journal=Physics Today|volume=48(6)|pages=59-60|via=}} and this connection between music and astronomy intrigued Johannes Kepler, and he devoted much of his time after publishing the [[Mysterium Cosmographicum|''Mysterium'' ''Cosmographicum'']] (Mystery of the Cosmos) looking over tables and trying to fit the data to what he believed to be the true nature of the cosmos.{{Cite book|title=Mysterium Cosmographicum|last=Kepler|first=Johannes|year=1596|location=Tubingen}}{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/28293391|title=Kepler|last=1880-1956.|first=Caspar, Max,|date=1993|publisher=Dover Publications|others=Hellman, Clarisse Doris, 1910-1973.|isbn=0486676056|location=New York|oclc=28293391}} In 1619 Kepler published ''Harmonices Mundi'' (literally Harmony of the Worlds), expanding on the concepts he introduced in ''Mysterium'' and positing that [[Interval (music)|musical intervals]] and [[Harmony|harmonies]] describe the motions of the six known planets of the time.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/36826094|title=The harmony of the world|last=1571-1630.|first=Kepler, Johannes,|date=1997|publisher=American Philosophical Society|others=Aiton, E. J., Duncan, A. M. (Alistair Matheson), Field, Judith Veronica.|isbn=0871692090|location=[Philadelphia, Pa.]|oclc=36826094}} He believed that this harmony, while inaudible, could be heard by the soul, and that it gave a “very agreeable feeling of bliss, afforded him by this music in the imitation of God.” In ''Harmonices'', Kepler laid out an argument for a creator who had made an explicit connection between geometry, astronomy, and music, and that the planets were arranged in intelligently. [[File:Planetary_Musical_Scales_from_Harmony_of_the_Worlds.jpg|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Planetary_Musical_Scales_from_Harmony_of_the_Worlds.jpg|thumb|359x359px|Page from Kepler's ''Harmonices Mundi''. The scales of each of the six known planets, and the moon, placed on five-line staffs.]] ''Harmonices'' is split into five books, or chapters. The first and second books give a brief discussion on [[regular polyhedron]] and their [[Congruence (geometry)|congruences]], reiterating the idea he introduced in ''Mysterium'' that the five regular solids known about since antiquity define the orbits of the planets and their distances from the sun. Book three focuses on defining musical harmonies, including [[consonance and dissonance]], intervals (including the problems of just tuning), their relations to string length, and what makes music pleasurable to listen to. In the fourth book Kepler presents a metaphysical basis for this system, along with arguments for why the harmony of the worlds appeals to the intellectual soul in the same manner as the harmony of music appeals to the human soul. Here he also uses the naturalness of this harmony as an argument for [[heliocentrism]]. In book five, Kepler describes in detail the orbital motion of the planets and how this motion nearly perfectly matches musical harmonies. Finally, after a discussion on [[astrology]] in book five, Kepler ends ''Harmonices'' by describing his [[Third law of planetary motion|third law]], which states that for any planet the cube of the semi-major axis of its elliptical orbit is proportional to the square of its orbital period. In the final book of ''Harmonices'', Kepler explains how the ratio of the maximum and minimum [[Angular velocity|angular speeds]] of each planet (its speeds at the perihelion and aphelion) is very nearly equivalent to a consonant musical interval. Furthermore, the ratios between these extreme speeds of the planets compared against each other create even more mathematical harmonies. These speeds explain the [[Eccentricity (mathematics)|eccentricity]] of the orbits of the planets in a natural way that appealed to Kepler’s religious beliefs in a heavenly creator. While Kepler did believe that the harmony of the worlds was inaudible, he related the motions of the planets to musical concepts in book four of ''Harmonices''. He makes an analogy between comparing the extreme speeds of one planet and the extreme speeds of multiple planets with the difference between [[Monophonic music|monophonic]] and [[Polyphony|polyphonic]] music. Because planets with larger eccentricities have a greater variation in speed they produce more “notes.” Earth’s maximum and minimum speeds, for example, are in a ratio of roughly 16 to 15, or that of a semitone, whereas Venus’ orbit is nearly circular, and therefore only produces a singular note. Mars, which has the largest eccentricity, has the largest interval, a minor tenth, or a ratio of 12 to 5. This range, as well as the relative speeds between the planets, led Kepler to conclude that the solar system was comprised of two basses ([[Saturn]] and [[Jupiter]]), a tenor ([[Mars]]), two altos ([[Venus]] and [[Earth]]), and a soprano ([[Mercury (planet)|Mercury]]), which had sung in “perfect concord,” at the beginning of time, and could potentially arrange themselves to do so again. He was certain of the link between musical harmonies and the harmonies of the heavens and believed that “man, the imitator of the Creator,” had emulated the polyphony of the heavens so as to enjoy “the continuous duration of the time of the world in a fraction of an hour.” Kepler was so convinced in a creator that he was convinced of the existence of this harmony despite a number of inaccuracies present in ''Harmonices''. Many of the ratios differed by an error greater than simple measurement error from the true value for the interval, and the ratio between Mars’ and Jupiter’s angular velocities does not create a consonant interval, though every other combination of planets does. Kepler brushed aside this problem by making the argument, with the math to support it, that because these [[elliptical]] paths had to fit into the regular solids described in ''Mysterium'' the values for both the dimensions of the solids and the angular speeds would have to differ from the ideal values to compensate. This change also had the benefit of helping Kepler retroactively explain why the regular solids encompassing each planet were slightly imperfect. ==Use in recent music== {{Unreferenced section|date=September 2018}} The connection between music, mathematics, and astronomy had a profound impact on history. It resulted in music's inclusion in the Quadrivium, the medieval curriculum that included arithmetic, geometry, music, and astronomy, and along with the Trivium (grammar, logic,and rhetoric) made up the seven liberal arts, which are still the basis for higher education today. A small number of recent compositions either make reference to or are based on the concepts of Musica Universalis or Harmony of the Spheres. Among these are ''[[Music of the Spheres (Mike Oldfield album)|Music of the Spheres]]'' by [[Mike Oldfield]], ''[[Om (The Moody Blues song)|Om]]'' by [[the Moody Blues]], ''[[The Earth Sings Mi Fa Mi]]'' album by [[The Receiving End of Sirens]], ''[[Music of the Spheres (Ian Brown album)|Music of the Spheres]]'' by [[Ian Brown]]'','' and [[Björk]]'s single ''[[Cosmogony (song)|Cosmogony]]'', included in her 2011 album ''[[Biophilia (album)|Biophilia]]''. Earlier, in the 1910s, Danish composer [[Rued Langgaard]] composed a pioneering orchestral work titled ''[[Music of the Spheres (Langgaard)|Music of the Spheres]]''. ''Music of the Spheres'' was also the title chosen for the musical foundation of the video-game [[Destiny (video game)|Destiny]], and was composed by Martin O'Donnell, Michael Salvatori, and Paul McCartney. [[Paul Hindemith]] wrote an Opera (1957), and a Symphony using the same music, called 'Die Harmonie der Welt' based upon the life of the Astronomer Johannes Kepler (1571–1630). == See also == * [[Asteroseismology]] * [[Esoteric cosmology]] * ''[[Harmonices Mundi]]'' * [[Orbital resonance]] * [[This Is My Father's World]] * [[Titius–Bode law]] * [[Ray of Creation]] * [[Sacred geometry]] * [[Shabd]] * [[Space music]] * [[Thema Mundi]] == Notes == {{reflist}} == Sources == *{{Wikicite | id = Davis-1901 | reference= Davis, Henry, 1901. ''The Republic The Statesman of Plato''. London: M. W. Dunne 1901; [[Nabu Press]] reprint, 2010. {{ISBN|978-1-146-97972-6}}.}} *{{Wikicite | id = Hackett-1997 | reference=Hackett, Jeremiah, 1997. '' Roger Bacon and the sciences: commemorative essays''. Brill. {{ISBN|978-90-04-10015-2}}.}} *{{Wikicite | id = Kepler-1619 | reference= [[Kepler, Johannes]], 1619.'' The Harmony of the World'', translated by E.J. Aiton, A.M. Duncan and J.V. Field (1997). Philadelphia: American Philosophical Society. {{ISBN|0-87169-209-0}}.}} *{{Wikicite | id = Pliny-77 | reference= [[Pliny the Elder]], 77AD.'' [[Natural History (Pliny)|Natural History]]'', books I-II, translated by H. Rackham (1938). Harvard University Press. {{ISBN|0-674-99364-0}}.}} *{{Wikicite | id = Smith-1996 | reference= Smith, Mark A., 2006.'' Ptolemy's theory of visual perception: an English translation of the Optics''. Philadelphia: [[American Philosophical Society]]. {{ISBN|978-0-87169-862-9}}.}} *{{Wikicite |id= Weiss-2008 | reference= [[Weiss, Piero]] and [[Taruskin, Richard]], 2008. ''Music in the Western World: a history in documents''. [[Cengage Learning]]. {{ISBN|978-0-534-58599-0}}.}} ==Further reading== * {{cite web |first=Paul |last=Calter |url=http://www.dartmouth.edu/~matc/math5.geometry/unit3/unit3.html |title=Pythagoras & Music of the Spheres |work=Geometry in Art & Architecture |publisher=[[Dartmouth College]] |accessdate=November 26, 2011}} * {{cite web |first=David |last=Plant |url=http://www.skyscript.co.uk/kepler.html |title=Johannes Kepler & the Music of the Spheres |work=Skyscript.co.uk |accessdate=November 26, 2011}} * Wille G. Musica Romana. Die Bedeutung der Musik im Leben der Römer. Amsterdam, 1967. * Burkert W. Weisheit und Wissenschaft: Studien zu Pythagoras, Philolaos und Platon. Nürnberg, 1962 * Richter L. Tantus et tam dulcis sonus. Die Lehre von der Sphärenharmonie in Rom und ihre griechischen Quellen // Geschichte der Musiktheorie. Bd. 2. Darmstadt, 2006, SS.505-634. ==External links== *[http://www.crystalinks.com/musicspheres.html ''Music of the Spheres''] *[https://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b00c1fct The Music of the Spheres], BBC Radio 4 discussion with Peter Forshaw, Jim Bennett & Angela Voss (''In Our Time'', June 19, 2008) {{DEFAULTSORT:Musica Universalis}} [[Category:Pythagorean philosophy]] [[Category:Esoteric cosmology]] [[Category:Early scientific cosmologies]] [[Category:Numerology]] [[Category:Ancient astronomy]] [[Category:Philosophy of music]] [[Category:Acoustics]]
