{{COI|date=April 2018}} {{EngvarB|date=June 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2016}} {{Infobox film | name = ToryBoy The Movie | image = ToryBoy The Movie official release poster.jpg | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[John Walsh (filmmaker)|John Walsh]] | producer = [[Roger James producer|Roger James]] | studio = [[John Walsh (filmmaker)|Walsh Bros Ltd.]] | distributor = [[Fremantle Media]]
[[3DD Productions]] | released = {{film date|df=y|2011|5|11}} | runtime = 100 min. | country = United Kingdom | language = English }} '''''ToryBoy The Movie''''' is a 2011 [[Gonzo journalism|gonzo]]-style British documentary feature film directed by and starring [[John Walsh (filmmaker)|John Walsh]]. It follows Walsh as he becomes a political candidate for the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]] in the north east England constituency of [[Middlesbrough]]. ==Background== A staunch [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]] supporter all his life, Walsh had become disillusioned with the party. When [[David Cameron]] opened the door to allow non party members to run for the Conservative candidacy ahead of the [[United Kingdom general election, 2010|2010 General Election]],{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/politics/conservative/5377839/David-Cameron-to-open-up-candidate-list-to-everyone.html|title=David Cameron to 'open up candidate list to everyone'|author=Chris Irvine|date=24 May 2009|work=Telegraph.co.uk}} John Walsh decided to do just that and document his experiences on camera.[https://youngpeopleinpolitics.org.uk/inspiration/interviews/ John Walsh interview, Young People In Politics, n.d. He came third in the election; Stuart Bell remained the MP of Middlesbrough,{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-13960870|title=Tory Boy takes on Sir Stuart Bell in documentary film|work=BBC News}} but increased the Conservative vote to its highest in thirty years with an 18.8% share of the vote.{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/shared/election2010/results/constituency/c92.stm|title=BBC News - Election 2010 - Constituency - Middlesbrough|work=bbc.co.uk}} ==The film== The film was based on the 72 hours of footage made by Walsh on the campaign trail. It made the case that [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour]]'s [[Stuart Bell]] should not be the [[Member of Parliament]] (MP) of [[Middlesbrough]], as Bell was absent so often from Middlesbrough that he is an unsuitable candidate. Walsh showed the finished film in a free showing a year after the election.{{cite web|url=http://www.gazettelive.co.uk/news/local-news/toryboy-movie-documentary-up-award-3691723|title=Toryboy The Movie documentary up for award|author=gazettelive Administrator|date=5 August 2011|work=gazettelive}} On the ''Who Can I vote For?'' website a humorous warning is given, "this film contains strong language throughout and scenes of politicians that some viewers may find offensive".{{cite web|url=https://whocanivotefor.co.uk/person/493/john-walsh|title=John Walsh for Member of Parliament for Middlesbrough in the 2010 General Election|website=Who Can I Vote For? by Democracy Club}} [[Mike Amesbury]] appeared in the documentary protesting outside the Conservative conference in Manchester.{{fact|date=November 2017}} Walsh paid homage to the great title designer [[Saul Bass]] and recreated his angular animations to create a fresh approach to telling this story. “This map cap comedy best captured the visual style and the transition of the film was making from a serious expose of the political shenanigans in the North East, to a political satire.”http://www.thewhitebalance.com/work/toryboy-the-movie.html Walsh said that he took a risk making this film in an article with Digital Journal "For something like this, an investigative film, there will be some who think that I have exceeded my brief as a candidate. I would say that it is right to look at injustice and in this country people have died so that we may all have the right to question those in authority and those in public office."http://www.digitaljournal.com/blog/11509 ''[[The Northern Echo]]'' discussed the possible of the film forcing a new by election as a result of its findings. Walsh said he had been serious about becoming an MP and had self-funded his £15,000 election campaign. "When I got to Middlesbrough I found a town that politics had forgotten and a MP who was there in name only, a truly depressingly affair.”http://www.thenorthernecho.co.uk/news/9028657.Documentary__could_force_by_election_/ ==Critical reception== The film received positive reviews, with a high score of 8.8 on [[IMDb]]https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1740117/. In 2011 the film was nominated for the [[Grierson Awards]] for "Best Documentary on a Contemporary Theme".http://www.griersontrust.org/grierson-awards/past-awards/2011/the-grierson-awards-2011-shortlist/ http://lfs.org.uk/content/john-walshs-tory-boy-movie-shortlisted-grierson-awards The ''[[Radio Times]]'' film review by Jeremy Aspinall on the film's re-release gave it four stars, and called it "A revealing and droll fly-on-the-wall documentary. It's a fascinating odyssey illuminated by pithily informative animations. Who would have thought politics could be so entertaining?".{{cite web|url=http://www.radiotimes.com/film/c5xq27/toryboy-the-movie|title=Toryboy the Movie|author=Jeremy Aspinall|work=RadioTimes}} Details of the film's award nomination was covered by the Middlesbrough ''[[Teesside Gazette]]''.https://www.gazettelive.co.uk/news/local-news/toryboy-movie-documentary-up-award-3691723 ''[[The Irish Post]]'' Walsh’s “documentary about a rookie Conservative candidate aimed to provide an insight into British political culture, and in doing so uncovered the next big political scandal.” http://irishpost.co.uk/documentary-that-exposed-labour-scandal-back-in-theatres-ahead-of-election/ According to [[Richard Moss]], the [[BBC]]'s North East & Cumbria Political editor, "some silliness aside, it is a thought-provoking insight into the way our political system works or doesn't work on the ground... But I'm not sure he quite nails down a case against Stuart Bell.. And John Walsh doesn't help his case with some of the content in the film." [[Liberal Democratic Party|Liberal Democrat]] commentator Mark Pack wrote on his blog that "John Walsh portrays life on the campaign trail as it really is. It is a hugely enjoyable documentary, which mixes humour, drama and education".{{cite web|url=http://www.markpack.org.uk/29694/toryboy-john-walsh-portrays-life-on-the-campaign-trail-as-it-really-is/|title=ToryBoy: John Walsh portrays life on the campaign trail as it really is|date=1 March 2012|publisher=}} A screening at the [[Frontline Club]] took place on 22 November 2011 followed by a Q&A with John Walsh.{{cite web|url=http://www.frontlineclub.com/toryboy_visits_the_frontline_club/|title=ToryBoy visits the Frontline Club|publisher=}} ''[[Empire (film magazine)|Empire Magazine]]'' gave it three stars and called it a "shit stirring exposé of local politics that will make you cross".[https://www.facebook.com/photo.php?fbid=510147455692929&set=pb.191458757561802.-2207520000.1384175778.&type=3&theater screenshot at Facebook] 20 December 2012{{better source|date=November 2017}} Samuel Scott from review site DVD Compare gave it a B- and wrote "I found this documentary very intriguing and very honest. John is a very likable character, and I wouldn't hesitate in voting for someone with so much passion for a second."[http://dvdcompare.net/review.php?rid=3637 DVD Compare] 14 April 2015 Doc Geeks commented that the film was "a blunt exposé combined with a tinge of lightheartedness. Satirical animation cleverly frames Britain in its political context".[http://docgeeks.com/2011/11/14/review-toryboy-the-movie/ Doc Geeks] November 14th, 2011 On his blog, novelist [[Christopher Fowler]] wrote that ''ToryBoy The Movie'' was "a snapshot of our country’s political apathy in microcosm. It’s heartbreaking to see people blindly supporting their own demise as if they’re playing some kind of long game they’ll probably never live to see the outcome of. Oh, and it’s also very funny."{{cite web|url=http://www.christopherfowler.co.uk/blog/2011/12/02/review-toryboy/|title=Re:View – ‘Toryboy’ - Christopher Fowler|website=www.christopherfowler.co.uk}} When the DVD was released Ben Kamal interviewed Walsh for the Aberdeen student newspaper ''[[Gaudie]]'', and wrote "I was prepared for some careful sneering in the interview and subsequent write-up. This did not (and could not) transpire: firstly because of the film, which comes across as [[Frank Capra]] scripted by [[Evelyn Waugh]]; secondly because of Walsh himself. He is warm, patient and generous, to my own shock I liked him and if you watch the film you'll like him too."[https://issuu.com/gaudie/docs/feb_25] 25 February 2014, p.6 "Dave", a reviewer at the website 60 Minutes With, wrote "''ToryBoy the Movie'' is a fantastic documentary and one in which you will be cheering for John despite what political party you follow. His journey from his Labour roots through to a Tory campaign is superbly documented and will have you both laughing and feeling his frustration in equal measure."[http://60minuteswith.co.uk/reviews/review-toryboy-movie/ 60 Minutes With], 15 November 2016 ''[[The Northern Echo]]'' article by Lucy Richardson she reveals that “at the pre-election hustings, where Sir Stuart does not make an appearance, he tells voters that he will have Sir Stuart jailed before Christmas if elected.”http://www.thenorthernecho.co.uk/features/9120025.Jolt_from_the_blue/ Two years after the film release, Lord [[Michael Ashcroft]] wrote on his blog: "I’d defy anyone with an interest in politics not to enjoy this film".{{cite web|url=http://www.conservativehome.com/platform/2012/05/lord-ashcroft-two-years-on-a-controversial-film-gives-a-witty-thought-provoking-snapshot-into-the-ge.html|title=Lord Ashcroft: Two years on, a controversial film gives a witty, thought-provoking snapshot into the general election|work=Conservative Home}} He went on to say that "despite the zany tone of the film, it also has a hard-hitting message which questions whether one MP in his safe seat, and perhaps other MPs in similar situations, do enough to justify their salary and expenses."{{cite web|url=http://www.lordashcroft.com/2012/05/two-years-on-a-controversial-film-gives-a-witty-thought-provoking-snapshot-into-the-general-election/|title=Two years on, a controversial film gives a witty, thought-provoking snapshot into the general election - Lord Ashcroft|date=6 May 2012|publisher=}} In April 2017 the political Guido Fawkes website also known as Order Order, ran an article entitled “Inside The Greatest Election Scandal of All Time” says that Walsh “lifted the lid on the real-life world of political campaigning.”https://order-order.com/2017/04/28/inside-greatest-election-scandal-time/ [[Vice (magazine)|Vice Mangazine]]’s Joe Zadeh’s article suggests a link between how Labour in Middlesbrough lost the votes of blue collar people and its shift to the right. He cited ToryBoy The Movie as an example of this shift.https://www.vice.com/en_uk/article/ev445j/how-labour-lost-the-working-class In a podcast interview with BritFlicks Walsh talks about ToryBoy and the difficulties in making the film and also his plans to develop lost [[Ray Harryhausen]] film projects.http://britflicks.com/blog.aspx?blogid=24084http://www.nerdly.co.uk/2018/01/01/interview-john-walsh-tory-boy-the-movie-ray-harryhausen-podcast/ ==Controversy== Although not explicitly inspired by the film, Neil Macfarlane, in a report for local newspaper''[[Teesside Gazette]]'', asked "Are Teessiders getting enough from Sir Stuart Bell?" when he failed to answer over 100 telephone calls made to his constituency office.{{cite web|url=http://www.gazettelive.co.uk/news/local-news/teessiders-getting-enough-sir-stuart-3693031|title=Are Teessiders getting enough from Sir Stuart Bell?|author=gazettelive Administrator|date=6 September 2011|work=gazettelive}} The ''Gazette'' story was picked up by national newspapers. ''[[The Independent]]'' asked "is Sir Stuart Bell Britain's laziest MP?"Jonathan Brown [https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/no-surgeries-for-14-years--is-sir-stuart-bell-britains-laziest-mp-2350953.html No surgeries for 14 years - is Sir Stuart Bell Britain's laziest MP?], ''Independent'', 7 September 2011Richard Moss [https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-14847291 Middlesbrough MP Sir Stuart Bell fights laziest MP tag], BBC, 9 September 2011 The ''Guardian'' fact-checked the "laziest MP" claim and found that the laziest MP was [[Roger Godsiff]] but the report did confirm that Sir Stuart Bell did not maintain the pivotal role for a MP, an office in their constituency. {{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/reality-check-with-polly-curtis/2011/sep/08/reality-check-britain-s-laziest-mp|title=Reality check: Who are Britain's laziest parliamentarians?|author=Polly Curtis|work=the Guardian|date=8 September 2011}}: "Bell has been an MP for nearly 30 years and has had a distinguished career in parliament as a frontbench spokesman on trade and industry in opposition and the spokesman for the Church of England in the House of Commons and member of the House of Commons commission until last year. He's part of a breed of politicians – also including the Tory [[Edward Leigh]] and Labour's [[Gerald Kaufman]] – who have been extremely active parliamentarians but not always maintained an office in their constituency. One measure of their parliamentary work is the proportion of votes they turn up to." The Labour Party said it would be totally unacceptable if constituents had been unable to contact their MP. [[Ed Miliband]] and the Labour Party expect the highest standards from Labour representatives. It is totally unacceptable if the public cannot reach their MP.{{cite web|url=http://www.gazettelive.co.uk/news/local-news/labour-launches-probe-middlesbrough-mp-3693109|title=Labour launches probe into Middlesbrough MP|author=gazettelive Administrator|date=8 September 2011|work=gazettelive}} Sir Stuart Bell did have a right of reply, which appeared in the short film ''ToryBoy The AfterMath''.{{cite web|url=http://www.conservativehome.com/platform/2014/05/john-walsh-toryboy-the-aftermath-or-the-town-that-politics-forgot.html|title=John Walsh: ToryBoy – the aftermath (or: the Town That Politics Forgot…)|work=Conservative Home}} The film's expose nearly forced a By Election.{{cite web|url=http://www.thenorthernecho.co.uk/news/9028657.Documentary__could_force_by_election_/|title=Documentary 'could force by-election'|work=The Northern Echo}} The film's re-release in 2015 caused more controversy after a showing in Middlesbrough by [[Teesside University]] was cancelled to avoid breaching union rules on political neutrality in the run up to the general election. According to Walsh's interview with ''[[Teesside Gazette]]''https://www.questia.com/newspaper/1G1-408518499/director-upset-as-toryboy-film-screening-cancelled the film was booked in by the Student Union, but at the last minute the screening was halted.{{cite web|url=http://www.conservativehome.com/platform/2015/04/john-walsh-toryboy-the-move-banned-in-middlesbrough.html|title=ToryBoy The Movie – banned in Middlesbrough|author=John Walsh|work=Conservative Home|date=April 2015}}Matthew Brown [http://mmj.tees.ac.uk/~project22/index5d95.html?p=863 Student Union involved in row over planned screening of controversial Toryboy the Movie], ''[[The North Crowd]]'' 27 April 2015 "I think it's a shame really," said Walsh. "It's a unique opportunity for students to hold me to account."https://www.questia.com/newspaper/1G1-408518499/director-upset-as-toryboy-film-screening-cancelled Teesside Free Education Campaign activists, writing on the website of the [[National Campaign Against Fees and Cuts]], mentioned the union cancelling the film: "A few weeks after the student elections, a planned screening of the film Tory Boy, made by the 2010 Tory candidate for Middlesbrough about his experience standing in the area was cancelled, despite having been screened at schools and colleges up and down the country without controversy." Teesside Free Education activists [http://anticuts.com/2015/09/21/our-year-with-the-worst-union-in-the-country/ Our year with the ‘worst union in the country’] ''Anticuts.com'' September 21, 2015 The [[North Crowd]] featured an interview with John Walsh website where they showed the actual print work that was created by the Student Union.https://mmj.tees.ac.uk//~project22/index5d95.html?p=863 ==Re-releases== The film received a re-release in cinemas in 2015 in the lead up to the [[2015 UK General Election]].{{cite web|url=http://www.irishpost.co.uk/entertainment/documentary-that-exposed-labour-scandal-back-in-theatres-ahead-of-election|title=Satirical film ToryBoy The Movie returns to big screen|work=The Irish Post}}{{cite web|url=http://www.newsshopper.co.uk/news/11807584.BAFTA_nominated_Greenwich_filmmaker_s_controversial_ToryBoy_returns_to_cinemas_before_election/|title=BAFTA-nominated Greenwich filmmaker's controversial ToryBoy returns to cinemas before election|work=News Shopper}} Community cinema screenings were given and included a Q&A from Walsh. http://hithergreencinema.com/2014/05/a-little-bit-of-politics-tory-boy-the-movie-plus-director-john-walsh-and-qa-with-your-local-candidates/ After a digital download version of the film was made available during the [[United Kingdom General Election, 2017]].[https://order-order.com/2017/04/28/inside-greatest-election-scandal-time/ "Inside The Greatest Election Scandal of all time."], [[Guido Fawkes]], 28 April 2017 == Soundtrack == The film used older film ques from films across the last six decades to create a unique soundscape. ''[[Radio Times]]'' described it as "a fascinating odyssey illuminated by pithily informative animations and music from films like ''[[It's a Mad, Mad, Mad, Mad World]]'' and ''[[Midnight Cowboy]]''."{{cite web|url=http://www.radiotimes.com/film/c5xq27/toryboy-the-movie/|title=Toryboy the Movie – review - cast and crew, movie star rating and where to watch film on TV and online|website=Radio Times}}. Other notable films which provided musical material included: ''[[King Kong (1976 film)|King Kong]]'', ''[[The Firm (1993 film)|The Firm]]'' and ''[[The Ladykillers]]''.{{fact|date=November 2017}} ==Home media== ''ToryBoy The Movie'' was issued for the first time on [[DVD]] 1 October 2012 by [[FremantleMedia]]. It included extras on the making of the film and gave Stuart Bell a right of reply, where he denied the allegations levelled against him in the film.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-tees-19936270|title=Middlesbrough MP Stuart Bell dies|date=13 October 2012|publisher=|via=www.bbc.co.uk}} The film was also made available as a high definition download on [[Vimeo]] {{cite web|url=https://vimeo.com/ondemand/toryboythemovie|title=Watch ToryBoy The Movie Online - Vimeo On Demand|first=|last=walshbros|date=4 December 2016|publisher=|via=Vimeo}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.toryboythemovie.com/ Tory Boy the Movie official Website] * {{IMDb title|1740117|title=Toryboy the Movie}} * [http://film.britishcouncil.org/toryboy-the-movie/ ToryBoy The Movie [[British Council]] Listing] [[Category:Films directed by John Walsh]] [[Category:Documentary films about politics]] [[Category:Documentaries about politics]] [[Category:Documentary films about politicians]] [[Category:Films about elections]] [[Category:Biographical films about politicians]] [[Category:2011 films]] [[Category:2010s documentary films]] [[Category:British documentary films]] [[Category:British films]] [[Category:British independent films]] [[Category:United Kingdom general election, 2010]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Documentary films about elections]] [[Category:Documentary films about the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Political satire]] [[Category:Satire]] [[Category:The arts and politics]] [[Category:2010s political films| Satire]] [[Category:British political films]] [[Category:British satirical films]] [[Category:2010 in British politics]]

revision.comment: [[WP:AWB/T|All typo fixes]] on, [[WP:AWB/T|typo(s) fixed]]: Parkinson’s → Parkinson's (20)
revision.text:
{{coi|date=June 2018}} {{Infobox organization | image = File:Van_Andel_Institute_logo.png | alt = | caption = | logo = File:Van Andel Institute.jpg | logo_alt = | logo_caption = | map = | map_size = | map_alt = | map2_size = | map2_alt = | motto = | predecessor = | merged = | successor = | formation = 1996 | extinction = | type = | status = | purpose = | headquarters = [[Grand Rapids, Michigan]] | coords = | services = | language = | leader_title = CEO | leader_name = David Van Andel | leader_title2 = | leader_name2 = | leader_name3 = | leader_title3 = | leader_title4 = | leader_name4 = | board_of_directors = | key_people = | main_organ = | parent_organization = | subsidiaries = | affiliations = | budget = | volunteers = | slogan = | remarks = | formerly = | footnotes = | name = Van Andel Institute | native_name = | native_name_lang = | named_after = | logo_size = 250 | image_size = | map_caption = | map2 = | map2_caption = | abbreviation = | founder = | founding_location = | merger = | tax_id = | registration_id = | location = | region = | products = | methods = | fields = | membership = | membership_year = | owner = | sec_gen = | secessions = | budget_year = | revenue = | revenue_year = | disbursements = | expenses = | expenses_year = | endowment = | staff = >400 | staff_year = | volunteers_year = | mission = | website = {{URL|http://www.vai.org}} }}
'''Van Andel Institute''' '''(VAI)''' is a [[501(c)(3)]] nonprofit [[medical research|biomedical research]] and science education organization in [[Grand Rapids, Michigan]]. VAI was founded by [[Jay Van Andel|Jay]] and Betty Van Andel in 1996 and comprises four divisions: Van Andel Research Institute (VARI), Van Andel Education Institute (VAEI), Van Andel Institute Graduate School (VAIGS), and Purple Community.<ref>{{cite web |publisher = West Michigan Science & Technology Initiative |title=Van Andel Institute |url= http://showcase.wmsti.org/vanandelinstitutespon.htm |accessdate = November 29, 2010}}</ref>
The Institute's research focuses on [[cancer epigenetics]] and [[Parkinson's disease]]. Its educational efforts support teacher development and science education from early elementary through the doctoral level.
David Van Andel, son of Jay and Betty, has served as CEO and chairman of the board since 1996.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://issuu.com/vanandelinstitute9/docs/final_20th_ann._highlights_of_hope_|title=Highlights of Hope 20th Anniversary Edition|work=issuu|access-date=2017-10-19|language=en}}</ref>
==Research== Van Andel Research Institute (VARI) scientists study the epigenetic, genetic, cellular and structural basis of [[cancer]] and [[Parkinson's disease|Parkinson's disease]] as well as [[osteoarthritis]], [[Neurofibromatosis type I|neurofibromatosis type 1]], [[Alzheimer's disease|Alzheimer's disease]], [[prion]] diseases, [[Ewing sarcoma]] and other conditions, with the goal of developing new treatments.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://issuu.com/vanandelinstitute9/docs/vai_mediakit_covers_and_inside_page|title=Media Kit {{!}} Van Andel Institute|work=issuu|access-date=2017-10-24|language=en}}</ref>
As of 2017, VARI employed 32 [[Principal investigator|faculty]] and more than 250<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://vari.vai.org/research-groups/|title=Labs - VARI|work=VARI|access-date=2017-10-24|language=en-US}}</ref> people. Its labs are divided into three groups—the Center for Epigenetics, the Center for Neurodegenerative Science and the Center for Cancer and Cell Biology—that collaborate on multidisciplinary projects.<ref name=":0" />
VARI was named to [[The Scientist (magazine)|The Scientist's]] Best Places to Work for Postdocs in 2009<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.the-scientist.com/?articles.view/articleNo/27149/title/Best-Places-to-Work---Postdocs-2009/|title=Best Places to Work : Postdocs 2009|website=The Scientist|access-date=2017-10-24}}</ref> and 2011<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://photos.the-scientist.com/legacyArticleImages/2011/03/Best-Places-To-Work-Postdocs2011.pdf|title=Best Places to Work Postdocs 2011|last=|first=|date=|website=The Scientist|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> and to The Scientist's Best Places to Work in Academia in 2010.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.marketwired.com/press-release/2010-results-announced-best-places-to-work-in-academia-1283312.htm|title=2010 Results Announced: Best Places to Work in Academia|last=|first=|date=|website=Market Wired|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
=== Center for Epigenetics === The Center for [[Epigenetics]]<ref name=":0" /> was established in 2014 and is led by Chief Scientific Officer Peter Jones, Ph.D., D.Sc. (hon) whose early work helped establish the field of epigenetics.<ref name="Viegas 13546–13548">{{Cite journal|last=Viegas|first=Jennifer|date=2016-11-29|title=Profile of Peter A. Jones|url=http://www.pnas.org/content/113/48/13546|journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences|language=en|volume=113|issue=48|pages=13546–13548|doi=10.1073/pnas.1617318113|issn=0027-8424|pmid=27872276|pmc=5137708}}</ref> Scientists in the Center focus on identifying epigenetic mechanisms in health and disease states, and translating their findings into new treatments for cancer and neurodegenerative diseases.
=== Center for Neurodegenerative Science === The Center for Neurodegenerative Science<ref name=":0" /> was established in 2012<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.mlive.com/business/west-michigan/index.ssf/2011/10/grand_rapidsvan_andel_institut.html|title=For Van Andel Institute's new lead scientist in Parkinson's research, fight against disease is personal|work=MLive.com|access-date=2017-10-24|language=en-US}}</ref> and is led by Patrik Brundin, M.D., Ph.D, one of the top-cited Parkinson's disease scientists in the world.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://content.iospress.com/download/journal-of-parkinsons-disease/jpd10021?id=journal-of-parkinsons-disease%2Fjpd10021|title=Productivity and Impact of the Top 100 Cited Parkinson’s Disease Investigators since 1985|last=|first=|date=|website=Journal of Parkinson's Disease|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> The center primarily investigates the underlying causes of Parkinson's disease and has several lines of research aimed at finding disease-modifying therapies, a current unmet need in the treatment of Parkinson's.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Chaudhuri|first=K. Ray|last2=Bhidayasiri|first2=Roongroj|last3=van Laar|first3=Teus|date=December 2016|title=Unmet needs in Parkinson's disease: New horizons in a changing landscape|journal=Parkinsonism & Related Disorders|volume=33 Suppl 1|pages=S2–S8|doi=10.1016/j.parkreldis.2016.11.018|issn=1873-5126|pmid=27932224|url=https://kclpure.kcl.ac.uk/portal/en/publications/unmet-needs-in-parkinsons-disease-new-horizons-in-a-changing-landscape(c30825cc-9a97-453c-95c4-24310c31b168).html}}</ref> Other diseases of interest include Alzheimer's disease and prion diseases.
=== Center for Cancer and Cell Biology === The Center for Cancer and Cell Biology<ref name=":0" /> is led by Bart Williams, Ph.D., an MIT-trained bone disease expert who was among the Institute's first scientists.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://williamslab.vai.org/|title=Homepage - Bart Williams - Williams Laboratory|website=Williams Laboratory|language=en-US|access-date=2017-10-24}}</ref> It is the largest Center at the Institute and includes investigators studying the mechanisms underlying several cancers, including [[Breast cancer|breast]], [[Pancreatic cancer|pancreatic]], [[sarcoma]] and [[Prostate cancer|prostate]], and other diseases such as [[neurofibromatosis type I]], [[Diabetes mellitus|diabetes]] and [[osteoarthritis]].<ref name=":0" />
=== Core Technologies and Services === The Institute's laboratories are supported by a Core Technologies and Services group that comprises eight shared scientific services:<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://vari.vai.org/core-services/|title=Core Technologies and Services - VARI|work=VARI|access-date=2017-10-24|language=en-US}}</ref> * [[Bioinformatics]] and [[biostatistics]] * [[Confocal microscopy]] and quantitative imaging * [[Cryo-electron microscopy]] * [[Flow cytometry]] * [[Genomics]] * [[Medical imaging|Imaging]] * [[Pathology]] and [[biorepository]] * [[Transgenesis|Transgenics]] and [[vivarium]] In 2017, the Institute established the David Van Andel Advanced [[Cryo-electron microscopy|Cryo-Electron Microscopy]] Suite as part of an expansion of its structural biology program.<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=http://fox17online.com/2017/04/05/van-andel-institute-installs-world-class-microscope-to-help-fight-cancer/|title=Van Andel Institute installs world class microscope to help fight cancer|date=2017-04-05|work=Fox17|access-date=2017-10-24|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://vari.vai.org/news-release-3-28-2017/|title=Van Andel Research Institute installs world-class microscopes to enable discovery of the molecular basis of disease - VARI|date=2017-03-28|work=VARI|access-date=2017-10-24|language=en-US}}</ref> The $10 million investment included the installation of an FEI Titan Krios [[Cryo-electron microscopy|cryo-electron microscope]], a Talos Arctica cryo-electron microscope and a Tecnai Spirit G2 BioTWIN screening microscope.<ref name=":1" />
The Institute also houses a [[College of American Pathologists]]-accredited Biorepository<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/van-andel-institute-saint-marys-health-care-and-mercy-health-partners-to-expand-world-class-biorepository-in-west-michigan-174446221.html|title=Van Andel Institute, Saint Mary's Health Care And Mercy Health Partners To Expand World Class Biorepository In West Michigan|last=Institute|first=Van Andel|website=www.prnewswire.com|language=en|access-date=2017-10-24}}</ref> that contains more than one million [[Histology|formalin-fixed paraffin-embedded blocks]].
=== Large-Scale Collaborations === In September 2014, the Institute partnered with The Cure Parkinson's Trust on its Linked Clinical Trials initiative, which investigates repurposed drugs for use as disease-modifying treatments for Parkinson's.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://vari.vai.org/press-release-9-23-2014/|title=Van Andel Research Institute joins The Cure Parkinson’s Trust to accelerate development of new Parkinson’s disease treatments - VARI|date=2014-09-23|work=VARI|access-date=2017-10-24|language=en-US}}</ref> LCT has supported trials in ambroxol, exenatide, simvastatin, liraglutide and others.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://parkinsonsnewstoday.com/2016/02/24/promising-respiratory-drug-focus-of-new-clinical-trial-for-parkinsons-disease/|title=New Parkinson's Clinical Trial Will Evaluate Drug Already Approved for Respiratory Conditions - Parkinson's News Today|date=2016-02-24|work=Parkinson's News Today|access-date=2017-10-24|language=en-US}}</ref>
A month later, in October, the Institute announced a partnership with [[Stand Up to Cancer|Stand Up To Cancer]] to form the VARI–SU2C Epigenetics Dream Team, a multi-institutional collaboration to translate potential epigenetic treatments for cancer into clinical trials.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://vari.vai.org/press-release-10-20-2014/|title=Stand Up To Cancer Epigenetics Dream Team continues with $7.5 million funding from Van Andel Research Institute - VARI|date=2014-10-20|work=VARI|access-date=2017-10-24|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://vari.vai.org/vari-research/vari-su2c-dream-team/|title=Linked Clinical Trials Initiative|work=VARI|access-date=2017-10-24|language=en-US}}</ref> The team is led by Jones and [[Stephen B. Baylin|Stephen Baylin, M.D.,]], co-head of the Cancer Biology Program at Johns Hopkins University's Sidney Kimmel Comprehensive Cancer Center. It has launched six clinical trials in cancers including metastatic colorectal cancer, myelodysplastic syndrome, acute myeloid leukemia, non-small cell lung cancer and bladder cancer.
=== Research Leadership === In 1999, [[George Vande Woude]], Ph.D., joined VARI<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.mlive.com/business/west-michigan/index.ssf/2013/04/van_andel_institutes_george_va.html|title=Van Andel Institute's George Vande Woude in prestigious first class honored for cancer research|work=MLive.com|access-date=2017-10-24|language=en-US}}</ref> as its founding research director. He previously served as Director of the Basic Research Program at the Frederick Cancer Research and Development Center as well as the Director for the Division of Basic Sciences at the [[National Cancer Institute]]. In the early 1980s, Vande Woude's laboratory discovered the human [[C-Met|MET]] [[oncogene]], which is now an important target in the development of anti-cancer drugs.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Bottaro|first=D. P.|last2=Rubin|first2=J. S.|last3=Faletto|first3=D. L.|last4=Chan|first4=A. M.|last5=Kmiecik|first5=T. E.|last6=Woude|first6=GF Vande|last7=Aaronson|first7=S. A.|date=1991-02-15|title=Identification of the hepatocyte growth factor receptor as the c-met proto-oncogene product|url=http://science.sciencemag.org/content/251/4995/802|journal=Science|language=en|volume=251|issue=4995|pages=802–804|doi=10.1126/science.1846706|issn=0036-8075|pmid=1846706}}</ref> He stepped down from his post as research director in 2009 to devote more time to his research. He is a Distinguished Scientific Fellow at VARI and is a fellow of the [[National Academy of Sciences]] and the [[American Association for the Advancement of Science]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://vandewoudelab.vai.org/lead-investigator/|title=Lead Investigator Bio - Vande Woude Laboratory|work=Vande Woude Laboratory|access-date=2017-10-24|language=en-US}}</ref>
Vande Woude was succeeded by Jeffrey Trent, Ph.D., who served a dual role as research director at VARI and at Translational Genomics Research Institute (TGen) in Phoenix, Arizona.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.mlive.com/news/grand-rapids/index.ssf/2009/02/jeffrey_trent_grand_rapids.html|title=Van Andel Institute partners with TGen of Phoenix, hires new research director|work=MLive.com|access-date=2017-10-24|language=en-US}}</ref> Trent founded TGen in 2002<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.tgen.org/research/research-faculty/jeffrey-trent.aspx#.We-FGhNSxTZ|title=Jeffrey Trent -|website=www.tgen.org|language=en|access-date=2017-10-24}}</ref> after 10 years at the National Human Genome Research Institute, a part of the National Institutes of Health. He left VARI in 2012 to lead TGen full-time.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.mlive.com/business/west-michigan/index.ssf/2012/03/van_andel_institute_and_tgen_e.html|title=Van Andel Institute and TGen end alliance|work=MLive.com|access-date=2017-10-24|language=en-US}}</ref>
In 2013, Peter Jones, Ph.D., D.Sc., was named as the Institute's chief scientific officer after 37 years at the University of Southern California, where he most recently served as director of USC's [[USC Norris Comprehensive Cancer Center|Norris Comprehensive Cancer Center]] from 1993 to 2011.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://news.usc.edu/30693/Peter-Jones-to-Step-Down-From-Cancer-Center-Post/|title=Peter Jones to Step Down From Cancer Center Post|access-date=2017-10-24|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.mlive.com/business/west-michigan/index.ssf/2014/07/vision_for_van_andel_institute.html|title=Vision for Van Andel Institute: Lead scientist details plan for internationally known research center|work=MLive.com|access-date=2017-10-24|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://joneslab.vai.org/lead-investigator-jones/|title=Lead Investigator Bio - Jones Lab|work=Jones Lab|access-date=2017-10-24|language=en-US}}</ref> Jones's work helped established the field of epigenetics, particularly his seminal 1980 discovery that DNA methylation impacts gene expression and cellular differentiation.<ref name="Viegas 13546–13548"/> He is past president of the American Association for Cancer Research<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://ces.b2sg.org/peter-jones-editor-in-chief/|title=Appointment of Peter-Jones, Editor-in-Chief at CE|work=Cancer Epigenetics Society|access-date=2017-10-24|language=en-US}}</ref> and is an elected fellow of the [[National Academy of Sciences]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.nasonline.org/member-directory/members/20036041.html|title=Peter Jones|last=http://www.nasonline.org|first=National Academy of Sciences -|website=www.nasonline.org|access-date=2017-10-24}}</ref> the [[American Academy of Arts and Sciences]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.amacad.org/content/members/newFellows.aspx?s=a|title=Newly Elected Fellows|website=www.amacad.org|access-date=2017-10-24}}</ref> the [[American Association for the Advancement of Science]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.aaas.org/fellow/jones-peter|title=Jones, Peter|date=2016-08-01|work=AAAS - The World's Largest General Scientific Society|access-date=2017-10-24|language=en}}</ref> and the [[American Association for Cancer Research|American Association for Cancer Research Academy]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.aacr.org:80/Membership/Pages/FellowDetailsNoModal.aspx?ItemID=50|title=Peter A. Jones, PhD, DSc|access-date=2017-10-24}}</ref> Jones also serves as director of the Institute's Center for Epigenetics.
==Education== Van Andel Education Institute (VAEI), founded in 1996,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=6717500|title=Van Andel Institute: Private Company Information - Bloomberg|website=www.bloomberg.com|access-date=2017-10-24}}</ref> provides kindergarten to 12th grade inquiry-based science education programs for students, and sustained professional development programs and instructional tools for educators.
=== Leadership === Gordon Van Wylen, Ph.D., was appointed director of VAEI in 1996.<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=https://www.vai.org/history-and-legacy/|title=History and Legacy - VAI|work=VAI|access-date=2017-10-24|language=en-US}}</ref> Before serving as director of VAEI, Van Wylen was elected dean of the Engineering Department at the [[University of Michigan]] in 1965<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.lib.umich.edu/faculty-history/faculty/gordon-j-van-wylen/appointed-dean|title=Appointed Dean {{!}} Faculty History Project|website=www.lib.umich.edu|access-date=2017-10-24}}</ref> and later served as president of [[Hope College]] in [[Holland, Michigan]], from 1972 to 1987.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://digitalholland.org/presidents-of-hope-college/|title=Presidents of Hope College – Digital Holland, Michigan|website=digitalholland.org|language=en|access-date=2017-10-24}}</ref>
Gordon Van Harn, Ph.D., was appointed director of VAEI in 2001 and served in this capacity until 2009.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.mlive.com/news/grand-rapids/index.ssf/2009/01/van_andel_education_institute.html|title=Van Andel Education Institute director Gordon Van Harn to retire|work=MLive.com|access-date=2017-10-24|language=en-US}}</ref> Van Harn was also an Emeritus Provost and Professor of Biology at [[Calvin College]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.vai.org/leadership/trustees/|title=Institute Trustees - VAI|work=VAI|access-date=2017-10-24|language=en-US}}</ref> in [[Grand Rapids, Michigan]].
Marcia Bishop was appointed associate director of VAEI in 2004.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.rapidgrowthmedia.com/features/0511310vanandel.aspx|title=Van Andel Education Institute Growing a Culture of Young Scientists|work=Rapid Growth|access-date=2017-10-24}}</ref> She served in this role until 2011 when Jim Nicolette was appointed to the position of associate director.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.mlive.com/business/west-michigan/index.ssf/2011/06/former_west_ottawa_schools_off.html|title=Former West Ottawa Schools {{sic|nolink=y|offi|cal}} named associate director of the Van Andel Education Institute|work=MLive.com|access-date=2017-10-24|language=en-US}}</ref>
Steven J. Triezenberg, Ph.D., served as director of VAEI between 2009 and 2015. Triezenberg previously served as a faculty member of the Department of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology at [[Michigan State University]] for more than 18 years.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://triezenberglab.vai.org/lead-investigator/|title=Lead Investigator Bio - Triezenberg Laboratory|work=Triezenberg Laboratory|access-date=2017-10-24|language=en-US}}</ref>
Terra Tarango was appointed director of VAEI in 2016.<ref name=":3">{{Cite news|url=http://www.mlive.com/news/grand-rapids/index.ssf/2016/12/van_andel_institute_taps_sde_p.html|title=Van Andel Institute taps SDE president to lead its education initiative|work=MLive.com|access-date=2017-10-24|language=en-US}}</ref> Tarango previously held the position of president of Staff Development for Educators (SDE), a professional development company in New Hampshire, from 2012 to 2016.<ref name=":3" /> Tarango also designed print and digital curriculum for kindergarten through 12th-grade students at [[Houghton Mifflin Harcourt]].<ref name=":3" />
=== Student programs === VAEI's student programs for kindergarten through 12th grade students include:<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://vaei.vai.org/student-programs/|title=Student Programs - VAEI|work=VAEI|access-date=2017-10-24|language=en-US}}</ref> * Summer Camps * Field Experience * High School Journal Club * Out of-School Time Cohort * Science on Saturday
=== Teacher professional development === VAEI designs and provides professional development workshops and instructional tools for kindergarten through twelfth grade teachers.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://vaei.vai.org/prof-development/|title=Professional Development - VAEI|work=VAEI|access-date=2017-10-24|language=en-US}}</ref> Materials include downloadable lesson plans, interactive student journals, and classroom resources.
=== Science education tools === In 2015,<ref name=":4">{{Cite news|url=http://www.grbj.com/articles/83105-vaei-releases-web-platform-for-science-education|title=VAEI releases web platform for science education|access-date=2017-10-24}}</ref> VAEI launched NexGen Inquiry, a web-based instructional tool designed to help students and teachers meet [[Next Generation Science Standards]] (NGSS) as well as other state benchmarks, and provides teachers with the tools they need to incorporate inquiry-based learning in their classrooms.<ref name=":4" />
=== Van Andel Institute Graduate School === Van Andel Institute Graduate School (VAIGS) offers an accredited [[Ph.D.]] program in cell and molecular genetics that is designed to foster problem-based thinking and research leadership. VAIGS also offers an M.D./Ph.D. program in partnership with [[Michigan State University College of Human Medicine]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://mdadmissions.msu.edu/Programs/MD_PhD/MD_PhD.htm|title=MD/PhD Program - Department of Medicine - Michigan State University|website=mdadmissions.msu.edu|language=en|access-date=2017-10-24}}</ref> and [[Western Michigan University Homer Stryker M.D. School of Medicine|Western Michigan University]] Homer Stryker M.D. Medical School.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://med.wmich.edu/node/267|title=MD-PhD Programs {{!}} WMed|website=med.wmich.edu|language=en|access-date=2017-10-24}}</ref>
VAIGS was founded in 2005<ref name=":2" /> under the leadership of then-VAEI director Gordon Van Harn, Ph.D. The first graduating class was in 2012. VAIGS was accredited by the [[The Higher Learning Commission|HLC]] on November 12, 2013.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.vai.org/press-release-11-19-2013/|title=Van Andel Institute Graduate School receives institutional accreditation - VAI|date=2013-11-19|work=VAI|access-date=2017-10-24|language=en-US}}</ref> Steven J. Triezenberg, Ph.D., was named the founding dean in 2006.<ref name=":2" />
== Purple Community == Purple Community, founded in 2009,<ref name=":5">{{Cite news|url=http://www.grbj.com/articles/80784-purple-community-hits-1m-fundraising-milestone|title=Purple Community hits $1M fundraising milestone|access-date=2017-10-24}}</ref> is Van Andel Institute's grassroots community awareness and fundraising program. Purple Community helps individuals and organizations create fundraising events to support biomedical research and science education at Van Andel Institute.<ref name=":5" />
==Architecture== Van Andel Institute is located on the [[Grand Rapids Medical Mile]]. Its 400,000 square foot building<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.vai.org/building-vai-1996-2016/|title=Building Van Andel Institute – From 1996 to 2016|date=2016-07-22|work=VAI|access-date=2017-10-24|language=en-US}}</ref> was designed by architect [[Rafael Viñoly]] and was constructed in two phases;<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.mlive.com/business/west-michigan/index.ssf/2009/11/van_andel_institute_architect.html|title=Van Andel Institute architect Rafael Viñoly visits Grand Rapids to see nearly completed design|work=MLive.com|access-date=2017-10-24|language=en-US}}</ref> the first phase was completed in 2000<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Duesbery|first=N. S.|last2=Teh|first2=B. T.|date=2007|title=Cancer: biology and therapeutics – A tribute to George Vande Woude|url=http://www.nature.com/onc/journal/v26/n9/full/1210257a.html?foxtrotcallback=true|journal=Oncogene|language=en|volume=26|issue=9|pages=1258–1259|doi=10.1038/sj.onc.1210257|issn=0950-9232}}</ref> and second phase opened in December 2009.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.mlive.com/news/grand-rapids/index.ssf/2009/12/with_opening_of_addition_van_a.html|title=With opening of addition, Van Andel Institute prepares to expand into new areas of research, speed delivery of results to West Michigan|work=MLive.com|access-date=2017-10-24|language=en-US}}</ref> It includes 27,500 square feet of laboratory space, 71,000 square feet of laboratory support space, a demonstration lab, an auditorium and on-site cafeteria. The Institute's Phase II was awarded [[Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design|Leadership in Energy & Environmental Design (LEED)]] Platinum status by the [[U.S. Green Building Council|United States Green Building Council]] in 2011.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.mlive.com/business/west-michigan/index.ssf/2011/04/van_andel_institute_earns_high.html|title=Van Andel Institute earns highest green building award|work=MLive.com|access-date=2017-10-24|language=en-US}}</ref>
The lobby features a 14-foot tall glass sculpture called "Life"<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.erhardtcc.com/Projects/Commercial-Office/Chihuly-Sculpture-Installation-at-Van-Andel-Instit.aspx|title=Erhardt Construction - Commercial & Office Projects|website=www.erhardtcc.com|access-date=2017-10-24}}</ref> created by [[Dale Chihuly]] designed to be an artistic representation of a [[DNA]] double helix.
==References== {{reflist}}

[[Category:Cancer organizations based in the United States]] [[Category:Medical research institutes in the United States]] [[Category:Genetics or genomics research institutions]] [[Category:Medical and health organizations based in Michigan]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1996]] [[Category:Independent research institutes]]

revision.text:
'''Waldsee''' ("Lake of the Woods") is the [[Germany|German]] [[language immersion|immersion]] program offered by [[Concordia Language Villages]]. Located near [[Bemidji]], [[Minnesota]], Waldsee is also the site of North America's first certified [[passive house]], which uses 85% less energy than a house built to the Minnesota Energy Code.<ref name="greenline">{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Waldsee BioHaus: First Certified Passive House in the U.S. | work = | publisher = | date = 2008-01-20 | url = http://www.zigersnead.com/current/blog/post/waldsee-biohaus-certified-passive-house/01-20-2008/696/ | format = | doi = | accessdate = 2016-01-29}} </ref>
Waldsee is America's oldest and largest immersion program for German language and culture. Over 1,550 young people participate yearly, coming together from all 50 of the United States and many foreign countries. In 2009 Waldsee was recognized as a U.S. National Center of Excellence for its cultural immersion program by the [[American Association of Teachers of German]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aatg.org/programs/kinder-lernen-deutsch/189-kld-centers-of-excellence.html|title= New Center of Excellence in 2010|work=AATG KLD Centers of Excellence|accessdate=24 February 2011}}</ref>
==History== Waldsee was the brainchild of professors Gerald Haukebo and Erhard Friedrichsmeyer at [[Concordia College, Moorhead|Concordia College in Moorhead, Minnesota, USA]]. In 1961, the first two-week session of "Camp Waldsee" was held for 72 villagers.<ref name="clv history"/> The tuition was $75 and Erhard Friedrichsmeyer served as the dean of the program. Over the next decade, Waldsee began to grow in both the number of villagers attending as well as the number of weeks that the camp ran each summer. Waldsee's first "adventure program," Alpenland, was held at the Rising Wolf Ranch in [[Montana]], where villagers learned German while enjoying [[hiking|hikes]] in the mountains and [[horseback riding]].
In 1970, the [[high school]] credit program was launched, providing a four-week intensive instruction for high-school students equivalent to a full year's instruction in a traditional classroom. In 1973, Waldsee launched its first [[study abroad]] program, offering [[backpacking (travel)|backpacking]] and [[biking]] trips to [[Germany]], [[Austria]], and [[Switzerland]].
In the early 1980s, the permanent Waldsee site began to be built on Turtle River Lake, near [[Bemidji, Minnesota]].
In 2010, Waldsee celebrated its 50th anniversary. Events in 2010 included a major "Waldseefest" on July 24, 2010 and six different alumni weekends.
===World connections=== Waldsee enjoys a continuing [[sister city]] relationship with the German town of [[Bad Waldsee]], located in [[Baden-Württemberg]].
[[Horst Köhler]], the former President of the Federal Republic of Germany, was the official patron (Schirmherr) of Waldsee, as was his predecessor, [[Roman Herzog]]. Many German Ambassadors and other dignitaries have visited Waldsee. World leaders have endorsed Concordia Language Villages, notably former [[United Nations]] Secretary-General [[Kofi Annan]], and former U.S. President [[Bill Clinton]], whose daughter Chelsea attended Waldsee for six summers.<ref name="clv history">{{cite web | title = About Us | publisher = [[Concordia Language Villages]] | url = http://www.concordialanguagevillages.org/newsite/About/history.php | accessdate = 3 September 2009}}</ref>
==== Notable Past Villagers and Counselors ==== *[[Chelsea Clinton]] *[[William Lee Scott]] *[[Emma Hitchcock]]
===Waldsee deans=== {| class="wikitable" border="1" |- ! Years ! Dean ! Site |- | 1961–1962 | Erhard Friedrichsmeyer | [[Alexandria, Minnesota|Alexandria]] (Luther Crest Camp) |- | 1963–1965, 1968–1969 | Hedi Oplesch | " |- | 1966 | Norbert Benzel | " |- | 1967 | Dale Whitesides | " |- | 1968–1969 | Kerry Koestler | " |- | 1970–1979 | Bill "Dieter" Schleppergrell | Alexandria (Luther Crest Camp); [[Cass Lake, Minnesota|Cass Lake]] (Camp Minne-Wa-Kan); [[Menahga, Minnesota|Menagha]] (Camp Emmaus) |- | 1980–1983 | JoAnn "Hanna" Tiedemann | [[Vergas, Minnesota|Vergas]] (Camp Trowbridge); Bemidji |- | 1981- | Dan "Karl" Hamilton | Vergas (Camp Trowbridge); Bemidji |- | 1983–1987 | Andrew "Gustav" Staab | Bemidji |- | 1988–2000 | Erin "Ilse" Jennings | Cass Lake (Camp Minne-Wa-Kan); [[Hackensack, Minnesota|Hackensack]] (Camp Patmos); Bemidji |- | 1995–2006 | Carl-Martin Nelson | Cass Lake (Camp Minne-Wa-Kan); Vergas (Camp Trowbridge); Bemidji |- | 2001- | Jon "Berndt" Olsen | Vergas (Camp Trowbridge); Bemidji, MN |}
Waldsee offers one-, two- and four-week living and learning experiences in German language and culture for beginning through advanced 7- to 18-year-olds.
The German Language Village has been cited as a model of innovative education by a wide variety of educators and organizations, including the [[American Association of Teachers of German]] and the [[Goethe Institut]] Inter Nationes. It has also been featured in such media as [[Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung]], [[Basler Zeitung]], [[ZDF]] German Television, [[CBS]] American Television, ''[[The New York Times]]'', ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'', ''[[German Life Magazine]]'', ''Oskar's'' and ''[[Deutschland (magazine)|Deutschland]]'' magazines, and been the subject of award-winning journalistic essays and various doctoral dissertations.
===Daily life=== [[Image:Waldsee, Bemidji Panorama.JPG|thumb|right|Waldsee ''Marktplatz.'' The ''Gasthof'' dining hall can be seen at left, and the ''Bahnhof'' is in the background.]] Waldsee offers programs that serve youth (7–18 years old), families of all ages, and adults; one of the high school credit programs travels abroad. During the academic year, Waldsee also hosts school groups.
The Waldsee credit program offers traditional instruction as well as credit programs in environmental learning and German (''die Gruene Welle'') and in [[medieval history]] and [[theater]] (''der Maerchenwald''). In the German apprentice program, starting in 2010, participants work half-time in the village stores, in gardening and green roof maintenance, music, the arts and the kitchen and bakery, and also learn half-time in intensive German language groups.
Waldsee's non-credit programs include programs that focus on producing [[FM radio]] broadcasts at a live [[radio station]], learning about [[Swiss culture]] in tandem with the nearby French village [[Lac du Bois (camp)|Lac du Bois]] and the Italian village [[Lago del Bosco]], learning about the [[Natural environment|environment]], performing [[improvisational theater]] based on medieval lore and legends, and exploring German grammar in depth.
Villagers can choose different activities every day. Waldsee offers a wide range of European sports from [[soccer]] to [[fencing]]. There is also traditional American [[Summer camp|camp]] activities such as [[human swimming|swimming]] and [[canoeing]] at the beach. Waldsee also has a few giant [[chess]] sets and a giant Mühle ([[Nine Men's Morris]]) game.
===Locations === Waldsee is currently located at a culturally authentic site on Turtle River Lake north of [[Bemidji]], [[Minnesota]]. Since its founding in 1961, Waldsee has also leased numerous sites across Minnesota. It also offers a credit program that travels abroad.
====Permanent site==== [[Image:WaldseeBemidjiMarktplatzAtDusk.jpg|thumb|left|Waldsee ''Marktplatz'' near [[Bemidji, Minnesota]]. The culturally authentic ''Gasthof'' dining hall can be seen in the background.]] The Waldsee permanent site, which opened in 1982, is located at {{Coord|47|33|33.78|N|94|44|19.36|W|type:landmark_region:US}} near [[Bemidji]], Minnesota on Turtle River Lake, along with six other [[Concordia Language Village]] sites. In all, Waldsee can house up to 240 people (typically, there are about 170 students and 40-50 counselors).
The site is styled after a typical German village and is centered around a ''Marktplatz'', which is the center of most activity at ''Waldsee''. The ''Bahnhof'' is a large building near the entrance of the village that houses class and administrative rooms. The ''Gasthof'' is another building that serves as a dining hall and houses most indoor activities. There is an artists' colony, named ''[[Worpswede]]'', which has about 6 small cabins and houses the arts and crafts activities.
The first building on the campsite was "''Haus Katja''", which is a log cabin that was built by a group of villagers. The first professionally built building was the ''[[Schwarzwaldhaus]]'' or [[Black Forest house]], which can house 64 people in four units as well as several more in separate sleeping rooms on the first floor. A twin to the ''Schwarzwaldhaus'' is the ''Max Kade Haus'', which was built a few years after the SWH and is very similar in design.
Two new medium-sized residences have been recently built. The ''Erich Markel Haus'' (Oberammergau and Unterammergau) has room for 24 people in two units. The ''Robert Bosch Haus'' houses the healthcare center (''Heilbronn'') and another residence (''Stuttgart''). The newest building at ''Waldsee'' is the ''BioHaus'', the first certified [[passive house]] in North America. The ''BioHaus'' is an integrated environmental learning center and residence for up to 30 people, including a small apartment upstairs. There is also ''Café Einbeck'', where villagers can sample candy, soft drinks, and other foods from Europe or listen to a jukebox playing German-language music. ''Waldsee'' also has a ''Laden'' at which villagers can make purchases using ''Euro''.
====Leased sites==== Waldsee has also operated at leased sites since its founding in 1961. Waldsee has been located in [[Alexandria, Minnesota]], [[Vergas, Minnesota]], Menagha, Minnesota, Hackensack, Minnesota, and [[Cass Lake, Minnesota]]. Waldsee departed from Vergas in the summer of 2006 to make room for [[Al-Wāḥa]], the [[Arabic]] language village, which was founded that year.
====Abroad==== Waldsee travels abroad to [[Germany]], [[Austria]], and [[Switzerland]] with smaller groups of high school students studying German in their summer for credit.
==BioHaus (Passive House)== In 2006, Waldsee opened the ''BioHaus'', the first certified [[passive house]] in North America, on its permanent site near [[Bemidji, Minnesota]]. It is built to the German passive house standard for energy conservation and renewable energy use, and uses 85% less energy than a house built to the Minnesota Energy Code.<ref name="greenline"/>
The construction of the BioHaus was funded in part through a grant from the [[Deutsche Bundesstiftung Umwelt]] (DBU), which is the world's largest foundation dedicated to environmental practice, education and construction. The Waldsee passive house marked the first time that DBU had awarded such a grant in North America.<ref name="standards">{{cite news | last = | first = | coauthors = | title = Waldsee BioHaus Attains "Passive House" Standards | work = | pages = | language = | publisher = Pro/E Community | date = 2006 | url = http://www.proe.com/feature_full.php?cpfeatureid=15148&PHPSESSID=e7a31dac772a2f | accessdate = 2008-09-23}}</ref>
In 2007, the BioHaus won the [[Minnesota Environmental Initiative Award]] in the category of Air Quality and Climate Protection. It was a 2007 Nominee for the [[World Clean Energy Award]] in the construction category.<ref name="initiative">{{cite web | last = Initiative for Renewable Energy in Architecture | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Case Studies: Waldsee BioHaus Environmental Living Center | work = | publisher = | date = | url = http://www.rearch.umn.edu/case_biohaus.html | doi = | accessdate = 2008-09-23}}</ref>
===Cultural importance=== The fixtures are German, and the house helps to introduce students to the "new Germany" as well as preparing them for responsible and ecological citizenship in the global community, the mission of Concordia Language Villages. The modern house itself pays homage to the [[Bauhaus]] school of 1920s architecture, and floor-to-ceiling windows recall the symbolic transparency built into [[West German]] government buildings post-[[World War II]].<ref name="germanyinfo">{{cite web | last = German Embassy, Washington, DC | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Letters Home from Camp: Lessons from Waldsee's BioHaus, the First Passive House in North America | work = | publisher = | date = 2008-08-28 | url = http://www.germany.info/relaunch/info/publications/week/2008/080822/misc1.html | doi = | accessdate = 2008-09-23}}</ref>
===Design=== The house was built using eight critical design strategies: Passive Solar Design, Superinsulation, Advanced Window Technology, Airtightness, Ventilation, Space Heating, Efficient Lighting and Electrical appliances.<ref name="greenline"/>
The building replaces 100% outside air; no air is recirculated through the system. Two underground tubes exchange outside and inside air eight feet beneath the ground, passively warming or cooling the air to match the temperature of the ground (~55°F year round). The house transfers heat between the outgoing air and the incoming air before it reaches the rooms, resulting in a difference of less than 10°F between the incoming fresh air and the desired room temperature, even in the midst of Minnesotan winter.<ref name="greenline"/>
Water in the house is heated by [[solar hot water|solar thermal heat panels]] on the roof, rather than [[photovoltaic]] solar cells, which would convert solar energy directly to electricity.<ref name="germanyinfo"/>
Low-growing plants make up the building's green roof, reducing rainwater runoff and adding another layer of insulation to the building.<ref name="germanyinfo"/> Additionally, the western half of the lower level of the structure is tucked into the slope, enabling natural insulation based on the soil.<ref name="initiative"/>
